deck_description: The strategy/combo sheet is linked here, step by step:  https://imgur.com/a/ApcEMo0  Deck was inspired by and directly copied from the HERO deck, which this DM deck is called the HERO Archetype Theory for a reason. This DM deck can set up at least 3-6 negates in 1 turn.

deck_excerpt: Witchcrafter's arcane defense body with a Dark Magicians banish cannon mounted on top! Draw, discard- Obliterate as spellcasters unite! least its supp
deck_description: Basically- I'm a master duel casual and I'm pretty new but i have thinking about buying a deck just to play for fun. I wanted Dark magician for the nostalgia but i wanted something that would be a little different than the average take. Slamming a Dark Magician, Eternal Soul + Dark Magical Circle engine on top of a Witchcrafter deck seemed like a lot of fun, and i was right.  The main problem i suffered from while playing Dark Magician decks seemed to be monster effects, well-  Madame Verre takes care of that all on her own, and if you get grass off, her and Haine have ammo for days. You want to be building your dark magician banish engine asap but its ok to focus on cycling your Witchcrafters, they are basically the base of your strategy providing defense and cover for all of your other cards while you dig.  Navigate is a really fun hit tro bring out DM and WH, straight into your XYZ shenanigans, Chocolate for draw/ defense on top of other cycling and draw effects, its really usually just a matter of hitting grass or starting to hit draw cards to hit off combos.  Selene. is definitely a star of the show but i think the added in synchro paired with the Knightmares give a lot of flexibility; the side deck is just complimentary genarics that i think fit multiple satiations. No expert.

deck_excerpt: Galaxy-Eyes deck for Master Duel more consistent(?)
deck_description: There's still dead draws and bricking here and there but not really that that much. This deck build doesn't focus on the OTK of Prime Photon dragon. (Deck was made through TCG Banlist I just transfered it to YGO MD so adjustments can be made that suits OCG banlist more which YGO MD uses.)  The deck focuses on summoning Starliege Photon Blast Dragon, Solflare Dragon, and Number 90: Photon lord for turn 1 and you can even add a Number 38: Hope Harbinger summon if you got a very good hand. (Always leave a photon dragon to your hand if possible for Solflare Dragon's Effect or take Photon Dragon through Number 90's effect on your opponent's turn if you already have Photon Dragon you can take Galaxy Trance for backup.)  For turn 2 you can do the first turn combo but summon Prime Photon Dragon instead of Photon lord. OTK is not always possible in the deck because I only took 2 copies of Photon dragon because I think its one of the major issues why dead draws is being frequent. Though I suggest always do combo's that fits the situation and not recklessly always go for Prime Photon Dragon.     I always summon Starliege Photon Blast Dragon if possible cause of its meat shield effect that protects my important monsters on the field and if you have an extra Photon Orbital you can even equip it to Starliege Photon Blast Dragon for full protection of your monsters on the field.  I removed rank 5 Xyz summons and took only 2 copies of galaxy soldier because I think it barely goes in to play and most of the time I have one galaxy soldier hanging around on the field I use it for Forbidden Droplet tribute or for Solflare Dragon summon for its toolbox effect. I replaced rank 5 Xyz summons with Twin Photon Dragon because of its special summons and it can even save your normal summon to do more combo's.     And for the extra deck as the usual either play AA-Zeus or Black Luster Soldier · Soldier Of Chaos for late game and the rest is just part of combo's or for the late game.  For the side deck you can replace Galaxy Expedition with a 3rd copy of Trade-In or a 2nd copy of Astral Kuriboh and if you have no Forbidden Droplet you can use Hyper Galaxy instead.     (I got Platinum 3 (S3) with this deck within 1 week got 6-8 win streaks with the deck sadly I can't play more per day because of school stuff and job.)

It has great combo, great capacity to destroy the opponent board, can still make comeback after a whipe. Very good in general, you need to play in second turn to bring up all it's potential, just lack in power monster, hard to OTK. The Kaiju helps to kill negate monster as they cannot cancel the invocation.

deck_excerpt: My take on Fluffals for Master Duel.
deck_description:
Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with a Fusion deck that I've been so anxious to play and test for a long time (for whatever reason that I myself too do not know), Fluffals. "Why play this deck?" Fluffals, or as what I prefer to call it, "Five Nights at Freddy's" the deck. Fluffals, they're cute. Fluffals, they're a Fusion deck, that does not xeno lock you into anything, which is the best kind of Fusion deck, but also means that it can Link climb (to an extent), and make Xyz plays because they're all of the same Level for the most part. Fluffals, a deck that most people say "will OTK the shit out of you if you do not know where to hit it" which after various testings, I do agree. Fluffals, a deck that gave me a reason to play the disgusting Tornado Dragon + Artifact Scythe engine. That's Fluffals. Also you'll be seeing a lot of "Toy Vendor" but anyway, the list. The Main Deck: Monsters • The Fluffals (Dog, Penguin, Dolphin, Bear, Owl, Octopus, Cat, & Wings) - Fluffals, your main deck monsters that you need to uh, you know... play a Fluffal deck. Here's their effects, if you do not know.
  1. Dog - Your main searcher for your Edge Imp Sabres in particular, for some reason, and any Fluffal monster, except itself. It just sucks that it can sometimes miss timing because it's a "When..: You can" but so is Stratos but, you know... whatever. Clearly a 3 of, as per every main searcher, for understandable reasons.
  2. Penguin - Your main Normal Summon, I think, because having both Penguin and Dog on the field is better than having just Dog. It also lets you draw 2 cards then discard a card upon getting used as a Fusion Material. Both effects are hard once per turns, and also a 3 of.
  3. Dolphin - It recycles your Toy Vendor and sends an Edge Imp Sabres or any Fluffal monster from your Deck to the GY, which is crazy good. It also recycles any 1 of your Fusion or Polymerization Spells in your GY or is banished if it is sent to the GY as Fusion Material, which is again, crazy good. Two is fine, I think. You could play 3 if you want.
  4. Bear - Your "searcher" for Toy Vendor, which is the heart and soul (and sometimes the bane) of this deck for reasons I'll discuss later. It also has an effect to Tribute itself to add back a Polymerization from your GY to your hand, although it targets. You can only use one or the other of its effects for some reason, which is I think the worst kind of restriction in game but I digress.
  5. Owl - I used to play 2 or more copies of this because it searches a Polymerization from the Deck and is a walking Polymerization itself at a cost of just paying 500 LP... until I realized that it has the "one effect or the other" type of restriction, so I cut it down to just 1 because it's searchable anyway.
  6. Octopus - This is the funniest card I have read for a Fusion archetype. Upon its Normal or Special Summon, it lets you add back any Fluffal or Edge Imp monster from your GY to your hand, which is neat and pretty normal, but if it is sent to the GY as a Fusion Material, it lets you return back to the GY up to 2 of your banished monsters. Usually, this only means that you get to recycle Fluffal Wings + another Fluffal banished for its cost, or better yet, it can bring back a banished Artifact Scythe. We don't have to worry about this interaction yet but in the TCG/OCG, its effect can be used to return back to the GY, a banished Dasher and Celestial that you used as Fusion Materials for Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, that you used to draw 2 cards for later use.
  7. Cat - The only reason I gave Cat a slot is because I think 1 Wings is manageable enough and also because recycling a Polymerization instantly after using it is just good to have. Feel free to cut it if you don't like it, but I personally do.
  8. Wings - The weirdest card in this list, at least I think so, because it does not immediately do anything since it needs a specific set up first of being in the GY alongside another Fluffal monster, having a live Toy Vendor to fully utilize its effects. It's a hard once per turn, and it's a draw 2 IF it completely resolves, but that's a massive IF.
• The Edge Imps (Chain, Sabres, & Scythe) - Edge Imps, the other half of your monsters that you need to play this deck. There's really nothing much else to talk about Chain because it's the most well known due to it being used as a search engine for generic Fusion decks. Scythe is one of the newest addition to the archetype, it's a hand trap that lets you Fusion Summon during your opponent's Main Phase, including itself. It also has a replacement effect, in case a "Frightfur" Fusion Monster(s) you control would be destroyed by battle or card effect by banishing itself instead, which is always great to have. And x3 Ash, because it's a free hand trap, I guess. It could literally be any hand trap you want. Spells • Frightfur Fusion - A Miracle Fusion for Fluffals. Combined with Frightfur Tiger, you could completely wipe out your opponent's entire board or it can turn your Frightfur Wolf into an absolute war machine if you decided to play it. Searchable one of, don't need more of it I think, at least in this version, idk you decide. • Polymerization - A Fusion Deck needs a Fusion Spell, understandable. We only play two of because it's searchable and you don't want to open too many of it. • Frightfur Patchwork - Your main searcher Spell. Hard once per turn but is a mandatory three of, since it searches and Edge Imp monster and a Polymerization. • Foolish Burial Goods - Triggers your Toy Vendor search effect. Also a mandatory three of despite also being a hard once per turn because you could always pitch it for Toy Vendor. • Foolish Burial - A must have one of for any deck that likes having monsters in the GY. • Monster Reborn - Reborns a monster, understandable. • Frightfur Repair - It's nice because it helps you recycle your Frightfur Fusion Monsters from the GY and Special Summon 2 monsters from your GY, one being a Fluffal and the other being an Edge Imp monster. It also allows you to summon 1 Fluffal and Edge Imp monster from your hand by banishing itself from your GY. The only acceptable card in this archetype to have the "only one or the other" restriction effect. • Called By The Grave - Protection. Understandable. • Toy Vendor - Speaking of the goddamn devil, I have so much stuff to talk about this one because this one's a literal gamble card. Let's start with the pros: It's a draw power at a cost of a discard, which is great if you can manage to pitch specifically either another Toy Vendor, Edge Imp Chain, or Fluffal Wings, because they can either search you a Fluffal or an Edge Imp monster, a Frightfur card, or to just set up Wings to the GY since you can, respectively, and if you draw specifically a Fluffal monster which consists 35% of your main deck since this is a 42 card list, you get to Special Summon any monster from your hand. The problem is that if your drew anything else, you must send it to the GY, which can only be good if you also specifically drew either another Toy Vendor, Edge Imp Chain (or Edge Imp Sabres), or Fluffal Wings. There's a way to alleviate this, and that is to fix your hand and stack your deck, by using Edge Imp Sabres' effect which thankfully, is a specific Fusion Material needed for Frightfur Tiger. This card... I'm not saying it's bad, in fact I think it's perfectly balanced... perhaps too perfectly balanced, even. We're not playing any traps in this deck btw. If you wanna play Infinite Impermanence, go ahead, feel free to do so. The Extra Deck: • The Frightfurs (Frightfur Cruel Whale, Frightfur Sabre-Tooth, Frightfur Kraken, & Frightfur Tiger) - You'll most definitely be summoning both Cruel Whale and Tiger during your opponent's turn with Edge Imp Scythe. I'm only playing Sabre-Tooth because there's an extra space and I really can't play the DPE engine so the slot for Verte Anaconda is not really that worth it, I think. I mean, you can still play Super Polymerization and its targets even if it's at 2 if you want. • Bahamut Shark + Toadally Awesome - Self-explanatory free negate engine. Allows you to recycle a WATER monster in your GY if it gets sent there. •  Tornado Dragon + Artifact Dagda - The DPE + Scythe Lock at home, before the DPE + Scythe Lock was cool and when Pendulums were the only one that uses and abuses it. Same principle as its equivalent, but not as better. • Sacred Tree Beast, Hyperyton - No I am not playing True King of All Calamities. If you want to be THAT GUY, do it, but not me. Actually to be honest, I think this one's better, because if you or your opponent activates any Spell, it allows you to attach a card of the same card type from your GY as Xyz Material, which is most definitely going to be Toy Vendor, and guess what, if your opponent activates a Spell card, you can negate it by detaching the said Toy Vendor, which also triggers its effect since it got sent to the GY so yeah, screw VFD, play this instead. • I:P Masquerena + Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess - Free monster negates that are protected by Lightning Storm, understandable. • Cross-Sheep - Helps Fusion decks in general to either Link Climb, make Xyz plays, or just Fusion spam. Final Thoughts: It should not be surprising. I obviously loved this deck, because first of all, it's a Fusion Deck that can be played either pure or as a toolbox deck. That's always a plus for me because it allows room for deck building creativity. Secondly, it's just as toolbox-y as Shaddolls, and I fucking love Shaddolls for the same reason as the first. And third, I don't know what's with the DUEA era Fusion strategies, or just strategies released in that period in general, man but they just have this level of charm and simplicity to them. They're simple, but not foolproof. They're not complex, but they're not pushovers. They're not straightforward, but not to the point where it gives you choice paralysis. I legitimately think I'll be building this deck too in real life except for the Toad engine because that's still pretty expensive for some reason, all while people are still wasting their money in Branded, which I cannot afford because of the goddamn scalpers but I digress. As per usual, if you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.

deck_excerpt: Sacred Beast searchers and Eldlich consistency make this a very effective grind deck.
deck_description: This is a simple yet effective deck that makes use of the consistent search and summoning of the "Sacred Beast" searchers (Dark Beckoning Beast, Spirit Gates, Piri Reis Map) to have bodies on the board and additional summons to establish low investment interruptions which can be scaled up to far more menacing boards that are difficult to deal with. Eldlich as an additional tool is a bit overused but since this deck will usually have a spell/trap or two that can be used to summon him, as well as him being level 10 (sacred gates recovery) it has an effective grind game and seral tools to out an opponents monster.

The previous pipelines ran through Ukraine, which secured them a bit, as the safety of these pipelines was of interest to Russia. What is happening now, while thousands of Ukrainians are killed, starved and is buried under the rubble: - Germany,  is against the real sanction. Germany introduces illusory sanctions on Russian banks. Sanctions on Russian banks except 2 largest Russian banks and the rest of the Russian banks make transactions through them. - The european union pays € 800 million Russian for energy resources every day.  Germany, France and Netherlands is against sanction on these raw materials. I appeals to common sense, leaders of many countries, because I have no reason to appeal to their decency. An attack on another country or maybe blowing up a few nuclear power plants in Ukraine, or maybe some other step and we are one step away from an even greater tragedy, even WW3. Will you enjoy your fortune, luxury houses and yachts when the world turns into a nuclear deserts ?!   Thank also to all users yugiohpro for understanding. deck_description: May I please get some advice on how to make my deck better?  First I apologize for the rambling I wish to only share that I am aware of certain things for my deck.  Cyber Dragon deck that I use in Master Duel and made IRL with my Cyber Dragon deck that I've been slowing putting together for years. I own an Accesscode Talker (was lucky to get the gold version) but I don't own Predaplant Verte Anaconda but I do have plans on trading for a copy. I know of Cyber Revsystem but unfortunately mine got lost in the mail and also have plans on getting it again. I also need more back row removal but can't afford Lightning Storm.  My strategies are: To get Chimertech Rampage Dragon out (Preferably on Power Bond) with Cyber Dragon Seiger as well as Cyber Dragon Infinity, basically hit fast and hard before my opponent can do much. If I can't then I can summon Cyber Eternity Dragon till I can clear my opponent's board.

deck_name: My Adult Redesign of my Childhood Warrior Decks
deck_excerpt: Redesign of my old Warrior Decks
deck_description: I'm 26 now, and I thought I'd do a redesign of decks I used back in the classic days.

Yura (that's me) is making a series of decks called the Mashup Series. I'm randomly spinning for archetypes and the first 2 will be combined to make a possibly wacky, possibly awesome and always fun deck. As a challenge you can use these decks for casual play and see which works best.  This first deck is Chaos Batteryman. The 2 archetypes were randomly decided, and I did my best to make a good deck. All it needs is staples like foolish burial and pot of avarice, and the challenger can modify it in any way.  Enjoy!

deck_excerpt: let me know what you think, my first try at a sky striker deck.
deck_description: cool sky strikers deck to try out.

This is a deck that although definitely needs interaction in the gy (which certainly can be shut down by most hand traps) but has the ability to disrupt and otk your opponent, and I think is fun to play with. Even if one of your starting effects get ashed there are usually other things you can do and ways to get your boss machinas or orcust out. Even though the orcust cards lock you into dark machine or just dark monsters that is no problem for Machina Ruinforce going into the next turn since he is dark machine or if you even want to go into Accesscode Talker. The strategy has a handful of ways of setting up your board for disruption. For example, you can end on galatea with machina overdrive set, babel on the field with dingirsu and cymbal skeleton in the gy. Of course you will have to activate overdrive first if you decide to and not the orcust cards first to get the overdrive pop and summon citadel from the deck (or citadel in the gy depending on how you set it up) before you get locked into dark machines and when you do, use cymbal skeleton effect to summon dingirsu from the gy to send an opponents card to the gy or attach an banished machine. In my opinion Machina gearframe, unclaspare, and redeployment are the most important machina cards in the deck since gearframe lets you add a machina like unclaspare, then once unclaspare is added, you use it effect to special summon and send a machina to the graveyard. If you have machina ruinforce or citadel in your hand then dump them with fortress. Go into rank 4 with Gear Gigant, use gigant effect to add Girsu, the orcust mekk-knight, summon fortress from the gy by sending a high enough level machine monster from your hand then link of into galatea and go into your orcust effects after sending an orcust (Orcust knightmare most of the time) to the gy and on your next turn you possibly have enough machine monsters in your gy to go into ruinforce for added otk on your battle phase. Another thing you can do is use the scrap combo which works well if have citadel in the gy. Summon Scrap recycler and send citadel to the gy, send orcust knightmare to the gy by fortress effect, link into Scrap wyvern and use effect to summon back recycler then destroy recycler triggering citadel to summon it, summon scrap golem from the deck then destroy wyvern then use golem effect to summon recycler then send rosenix to the gy, rosenix eff to ss a token, link off into I:P Masquerena (include the token) then into  Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess. This would however of course with apollousa would be better with a machine monster and overdrive on the field and/or Orcust knightmare in the gy (In which you would have to still have machine monsters in your hand to summon fortress again then link off fortress and knightmare into galatea) to go off into your orcust combos.  Any suggestions and recommendations are welcomed. If there any changes I would make next, I am strongly considering putting in urgent schedule, Heavy freight train derricrane or Express bullet train to make the scrap combo into apollousa more consistent.

deck_excerpt: Mekk-knights for plat in master duel
deck_description: This is the master duel deck that I have been using in master duel for a couple of months now. This deck can deal with most decks you will find in ranked, as long as they let you go second. Sangan is the second best normal summon that this deck has, most of the time you will search Mekk-knight orange or World legacy chalice, but Maxx c or Ash are great targets when you have enough Mekk-knights already.  Without this deck I wouldn't of been able to get to plat 1 last month, I was playing dinosaur at that time which doesn't match up well against Maxx c or backrow decks and is kind of inconsistent. This deck doesn't really care that the opponent has Summon-limit, Gozen or Skill drain, when you can just hit them with a couple of Mekk-knights each turn and Pot of prosperity for 6 into Lightning storm is always an option. Against good Tri players or Drytron you will need a good hand with specific counters like for Tri (Lightning storm to bait out Revolt and called by for the handtraps they will have drawn), for Drytron (A Kaiju and Lightning storm or Forbidden droplet and Lightning storm).
For the starter, easily to play

This is one variation of Relinquished Decks I find good in the current meta of Master Duel. This deck at best is a casual and fun deck that can steal some games off meta decks. There are a lot of combo paths for this deck depending on starting hand, preferably we start going 2nd: NS = Normal Summon, SS = Special Summon, LS = Link Summon, SyS = Synchro Summon, FS = Fusion Summon, RS = Ritual Summon 1. Righty Driver Synchro Combo 1 - NS Righty -> SS Lefty (Activate effect to bait Impermance/Veiler) -> LS Halqifibrax -> SS Deskbot 001 -> LS Auroradon -> SS 3 Tokens + Deskbot -> SS Beast-o-Lion (Tribute Auroradon+Token) -> SyS Borreload (Equip Auroradon) + SS Token (Beast-o-Lion effect) -> SyS Herald of the Arc Light End board: Borreload w/ 3 Omni-negate (4050 ATK) + Herald of the Arc Light (Omni-negate + floating effect for Relinquished Ritual Card/Monster) 2. Righty Driver Synchro Combo 2 (in the case of Beast-o-Lion is in hand since preferably you must never hard draw it) - NS Righty -> SS Lefty (Activate effect to bait Impermance/Veiler) -> LS Halqifibrax -> SS Deskbot 001 -> LS Auroradon -> SS 3 Tokens + Deskbot -> SyS Baronne de Fleur (3 Token + Deskbot) End board: Baronne de Fleur (1 Targeting Destruction + 1 Omni-negate) + Auroradon (Can be Linked into Accesscode if it survive the opponents turn) 3. Interrupted Kaiju Combo 1 (Tuner on hand except for Righty Driver) - Activate Interrupted Kaiju Slumber -> SS Radian on Opponent side, Machine Kaiju on your side -> NS Tuner -> Either go into Baronne/Borreload depending on starting draw Endboard: Borreload+Herald/Auroradon+Baronne 4. Interrupted Kaiju Combo 2 (No Tuner on hand) - Activate Interrupted Kaiju Slumber -> SS Radian on Opponent side, any Kaiju on your side -> NS Monster -> LS Verte -> Verte Effect FS Starving Venom Endboard: Starving Fusion Venom Dragon (Non-targeting Destruction for SS'd monsters if destroyed on the field) 5. Relinquished Bait Combo (If we can Ritual Summon Relinquished with Relinquished fusion in hand) - RS Relinquished -> Absorb one 1 targetable opponent monster -> Attack or go into MP2 -> Set Relinquished Fusion -> Opponents Standby Phase/Main Phase, Activate Relinquished Fusion -> FS Millennium-Eyes -> if opponent activates monster effect, activate Millennium-Eyes effects to negate and absorb the card (Better to absorb their starter or any problematic cards) Endboard: Millenium-Eyes Restrict (1 Monster Negate) As stated above, there are a lot of combo lines possible, and you can even combine some of them for a decent end board with 3 negates (Borreload+Herald+Millenium-Eyes) or even OTKs in some cases. Union Driver can bring out Illusionist Faceless as an insurance to allow Relinquished/Millennium-Eyes to bounce back from GY or even equip a Buster Dragon Destruction to any of your boss monster to lock opponents off the Extra Deck. The deck is very susceptible to Nibiru (as with other combo decks) as we summon a lot of monsters during our turn, though enemies top decking Nibiru if they have only 1 copy is rare, nonetheless the threat is still there. In this case, we can always summon Relinquished last to absorb Nibiru, ending with a big stat stick token, and a 3000 ATK Relinquished. Ash and Maxx C can be manageable, if we draw into Called by the Grave. We can also reduce some Kaijus and Tuners to include a few copies of Ash Blossom or add a few more going second cards like Lightning Storm or Evenly Matched.

deck_excerpt: Budget Friendly @Ignister Deck with combos listed
deck_description: I personally love this deck. This is something I have been working on for a while, and from all of my experimentation, I believe this is the best version. It's also budget friendly.  Just remember, the core of this deck is cheap. BUT you can run whatever hand traps you really want to. That is entirely up to you.  Reasons I run certain cards:  Rituals: Water Leviathan recycles links in grave, paladin can SS Gatchiri which give protection, cynet ritual can SS 2 cyberse tokens so you can go into Wicckid or Splash Mage.  Wind Pegasus: Clears backrow, also has a bounce effect  Light Dragon: Protection for links, SS a link from grave if another cyberse monster deals damage to your opponent  Monster Reborn: I feel like it  Eagle Booster: Good protection  2 Hiyari vs. 1: I love drawing the card and it is a nice extender. Also I just do so try me  Main Combos:  Going First:  Achichi + Pikari/Doyon/Hiryari: Achichi -> Search Pikari or Doyon -> Dark Infant -> Search Ignister A.I. Land -> Pikari -> Search Reborn -> Cyberse Wicckid -> Doyon/Hiryari -> Search Bururu and banish Dark Infant -> Splash Mage -> Bururu -> Send Doyon/Hiryari to GY -> Splash Mage Effect: Doyon -> Synchro Wind Pegasus -> Use Bururu Effect on Doyon -> Dark Templar -> Doyon Effect: Add Achichi to hand -> Achichi -> Dark Templar Effect Hiyari/Pikari/Bururu -> The Arrival Cyberse @Ignister. Endboard: The Arrival Cyberse @Ignister  Going Second:  Achichi + Doyon/Pikari: Summon Achichi -> Search Doyon/Pikari  (Which ever one you don't have) -> Dark Infant -> Search Ignister A.I. Land -> Summon Pikari -> Search Reborn -> Splash Mage -> Use Splash Effect to bring back Pikari -> Transcode -> Use Trans Effect to bring back Splash -> Accesscode Talker -> Doyon -> Reborn Pikari -> Light Dragon --- Endboard: Accesscode Talker + Light Dragon  Hope you guys like the deck! Also if you have any feedback or questions just DM me on discord at Lt. Banger#9530

deck_excerpt: Dark Magician, Red-Eyes Dragoon,The Dark Magician's,Master of Chaos,Illusion of Chaos,...
deck_description: The deck works with the 2 key cards, they'll remain on the board.You need "Eternal Soul" to special summon your dark magician or dark magician,the dragon knight,from your hand or GY. The spell "Dark Magicial Circle" allows you to banish one card on the field your opponent controls,if you special summoned a dark magician. The Dark Magician,the Dragon Knight helps you to protect your spells from destroying,also,if a dark magician or dark magician the dragon knight enter the fiel,these both cards are unafflected by your opponents card effects or destroying by card effects,until the card "Eternal Soul" remains on the board. To push your deck with more speed to draw,you need monsters like "magician's rod" which allows you to take a dark magician spell to your hand,or "magician souls" to send a dark magician or dark magician girl in your GY,and/or special summoned this card from the GY. Illusion of Chaos is maybe the strongest searcher,and monster card (released by battle of chaos. It allows you to take every monster from your main deck who specally list the "dark magician" or "dark magician girl". So you can take the new Timaeus monster (released by battle of chaos) to make a fusion summon for "red-eyes black dragoon" or "dark magician the dragon knight". .

The deck works around the normal blue-eyes white dragon monster to use the multitude effects. The Key card is "the white stone of ancients"which allows you to special a blue-eyes monster from your main deck. If you do, and you have a blue-eyes white dragon normal monster in your GY or field,you can special summon the blue-eyes abyss which allows you to take a ritual spell when this card is specialled.Also you can take a Lv 8 Monster from your main deck at the End phase. If you take a level 8 monster,decide to blue-eyes jet dragon,which allows you to special this card ,if a card is destroyed on the board from your opponent or your side. When the Jet-dragon remains on the board,other cards cannot be destroyed by card effects on your field. The ritual spell "high ritual art" allows you to special a ritual monster from your main deck, you must only tribute one white dragon (normal monster) from your hand which you can take from your GY by bannishing one "white stone of ancient rules". The ritual summoned monster remains until the end phase of your opponent if this card is nor earlier destroyed or tributed. My favorite monster for this ritual summon is "Amorphactor Pain, the Imagination Dracoverlord". The effect declares,that your opponent must skip his next main phase 1 and start directly in the battle phase without cards on the board, if it was your first turn.

deck_name: D/D/D Deck - Master Duel - April 2022 (Kali Yuga Lock)
deck_description:
D/D/D with a Kali Yuga lock using Artifact Scythe and Dagda. For the Kali Yuga lock, all you need is Kepler, Swirl Slime, and any other D/D monster in hand, which is pretty easy to get because of the amount of searches this deck (and D/D as an archetype) has. Kali Yuga lock combo:
  • Summon Kepler, search Dark Contract with the Gate, use that to search a fourth monster. Or, if you already have a fourth via something like drawing with Allure of Darkness, or already have Gate in hand, search Dark Contract with the Swamp King.
  • Use Swirl Slime and 1 monster to Fusion Summon Genghis.
  • Banish Swirl Slime to summon the fourth monster from hand.
  • Genghis procs, summon the monster from GY.
  • Summon Dagda, then Gilgamesh.
  • Using Gilgamesh, place Orthros and Thomas in pend scales.
  • Use Thomas to add Kepler back to hand.
  • Use Orthros to pop Thomas and any other card.
  • Put Kepler into Pend Scale.
  • Pend Summon Thomas, and use Thomas to summon Abyss Ragnarok.
  • Using Ragnarok and Thomas, go into Kali Yuga.
  • Wait for opponents Draw Phase, pop Scythe, and now you've scythe-locked your opponent with D/D/D.
Pretty big combo but its really easy to do, just a bunch of steps not too much thinking. This also sets up future plays with Kali Yuga to grab Swamp King back from the GY, then use it to Fusion Summon something like Caesar Ragnarok. On turn 3 I've had huge boards set up with this, my best being Caesar Ragnarok, Purple Armageddon, Kali Yuga, Siegfried, High King Genghis, and Abyss Ragnarok. Traded the Purple Armageddon for a second Gilgamesh though, just to be able to get monsters from Field to Grave easier in case anything gets messed up.

its a deck

Uses the basic strategy of searching for branded fusion to summon Lubellion using Fallen of Albaz and Despian Tragedy. Chain block Lubellion's fusion summon effect with Despian Tragedy to bring out Mirrorjade. Use Mirrorjade to banish a monster and send Albion to set Branded in Red in the end phase. In draw phase of the next turn, activate Branded in Red to summon Masquerade using Mirrorjade and Ad Libitum and then re-summon Mirrorjade using the effect of Ad Libitum. 1 banish and a bunch of burn damage if it works out.  Three Kitt in this deck because I'm poor and can't afford Aluber but she essentially serves the same purpose of searching any of the branded spell/traps that you need, also helps cycle some of the garnets back into the deck. Keeper of Dragon Magic does the same except sucks more.  Dogmatika Package helps send the Shaddoll stuff to the grave and adds bodies to the field. Helps send N'tss if needing a pop.  Only one Ash Blossom because I'm poor. The other hand traps help survive. This deck is deathly allergic to spell and trap removal. Monster negates are all up in here though

deck_excerpt: Zombie Eldlich but I put expensive cards in it
deck_description: I've tried my hardest to construct what I think is the best version of Zombie Eldlich. I'm probably dead wrong with this list.   There are inherent non-synergies within the list. Obviously, Rivalry + Zombie World locks you out of your non-zombies too. The idea is that this should hurt your opponent much more than you. This deck can go first or second. It's a little awkward when you have your going second pieces going first and vice-versa but this deck was made to both be good at clearing boards and also meant to have fairly strong starts / be able to set up locks. Like I said, this is my take on it. Feel free to criticize and suggest changes.

deck_excerpt: A deck I'm considering taking to a local tournament.
deck_description: Get Domain and/or one of the Fiends on the field and hope your opponent doesn't have any way to get rid of them.

I run 3 Linkslayer because it's very versatile. It can special summon itself to make for Tribute material, you can Tribute summon it for Domain's effect or combo it with Stormforth to get rid of an opponent's card, its discard effect is good backrow removal and a way to get Pantheism or Prime into the GY, and it can act as a serviceable body if you brick and just want to have something on the field.  2 copies of Majesty's Fiend because its 2400/1000 stats allows it to use Tenacity of the Monarchs and Return of the Monarchs, and 3 Vanity's Fiend because its effect is incredibly powerful even though it doesn't have the Monarch stats.  Seleglare can be searched by Ehther, and its effect can be useful for getting a low-atk card away from your opponent for a turn. It can also use Tenacity and Return.  I choose Proof of Pruflas over Squires or Vassals because Ash Blossom can't stop Proof like it can Edea, and I often found myself bricking because I'd draw multiple Squires or cards that search Edea (like RotA or One For One) but no tribute monsters.  Change of Heart was unbanned, and I can see that being great for getting tribute fodder.

deck_excerpt: Turbo out powerful boss monsters like Baronne De Fleur, Number F0: Utopic Draco Future and Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, Accesscode Talker and Zeus with
deck_description:
Utilizing both older support and new toys from recent sets like Burst of Destiny, Grand Creators and Battles of Chaos, R3NK Adventurer turbos out Extra Deck heavyweights like Utopic Draco Future, Baronne, Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer and Divine Arsenal Zeus! With a 52 card pile featuring 14 handtraps, even your handtrap ghost girls are starters, since they are simultaneously tuners and level 3 monsters! Facing an already established board? No problem, the new Ghostrick support allows for an easy 4 material Zeus to reset the board! Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer’s +2 draw for the following turn usually finishes the game off with Accesscode Talker!

ARCHETYPES, ENGINES AND DECKBUILDING

This deck’s defining characteristic are level 3 monsters because they spam the board en-masse, are easy to special summon and because of their amazing utility.  There are three types of level 3 monsters in this deck, each with their own use and strategy:
  • The Adventurer cards in the Main Deck consist of 10 cards:
3 Aquamancer of the Sanctuary, 3 Rite of Aramesia, 1 Wandering Gryphon Rider, 1 Fateful Adventure, 1 Dracoback and 1 Foolish Burial. The Adventurer Engine is used in this strategy to provide blanket protection and bait from interruption. More importantly the easy to summon and search Aquamancer of the Sanctuary is level 3!
  • The Ghost Girl cards in the Main Deck consist of 9 cards:
3 Ash Blossom, 3 Ghost Ogre and 3 Ghost Belle. Each of these ladies can be used in a pinch as a level three to get your plays started. They are also tuners, and they can be used to make Halq or Baronne!
  • The Level 3 Monster Spam cards in the main deck consist of 19 cards:
3 Emergency Teleport, 3 Psychic Wheeleder, 3 Psychic Tracker, 3 Junk Forward, 3 Kagemucha Knight, 1 P.U.N.K Madame Spider, 1 P.U.N.K Dangerous Gabu, 1 Danger! Tsuchinoko, and 1 Danger! Jackalope. These level 3s easily summon themselves to the field in one way or another. The optimal target using Emergency Teleport is Madame Spider, which searches a relatively free trap interruption from deck. There are other sets of cards in this deck that support their boss monster, or the strategy as a whole:
  • The Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer Package cards in the Main Deck consist of 3 cards:
1 Destiny Hero Celestial, 1 Destiny Hero Dasher, and 1 Fusion Destiny.  1 Verte Anaconda and 1 Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer are in the Extra Deck. These cards are garnets, but they lead to a very potent boss monster, Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, and a +2 draw and free special summon the following turn.
  • The Ghostrick cards in the maindeck consists of only 1 card (most cards for this package reside in Extra Deck):
1 Ghostrick Shot. 1 Ghostrick Alucard and 2 Ghostrick Angel of Mischief are in the Extra Deck. Being one of the one of the win conditions for this deck, these cards can create Zeus and Number F0 – Utopic Draco Future with just two level 3 monsters. Ghostrick Shot is recyclable with Alucard, giving you a monster reborn for Ghostricks every turn so they can serve as materials to make your Extra Deck bosses. Ghostrick Shot also turns into a 3 material Zeus, as explained later in the combo section.
  • The Staple cards in the maindeck consists of 10 cards:
3 Crossout Designator and its targets; 1 Impermanence, 1 Nibiru, 1 Droll and Lockbird, 1 Artifact Lancea, 1 Effect Veiler, 1 Called by the Grave and 1 Forbidden Droplet. Designator can also negate the commonly used Adventurer cards, if your opponent happens to use it. This deck is 52 cards so that there is the least possible chance to draw into this deck’s 7 bricks: Ghostrick Shot, P.U.N.K Dangerous Gabu, Wandering Gryphon Rider, Fateful Adventure, Dracoback, D-Hero Celestial and D-Hero Dasher. If you draw Ghostrick Shot, the Utopic Draco Future combo is dead. While drawing most bricks wouldn’t be catastrophic, it is less than ideal – hence the 52 card deck. I intentionally didn’t include Auroradon/Deskbot 001 combo in here, since I anticipate it will be on the future banlist. I also think that Anaconda and the Adventurer Engine will get affected by the future banlist, but these two synergize with the deck so much I had to use it. A card to add for consideration in R3NK Adventurer is Small World, since it easily searches Aquamancer of the Sanctuary with any level 3 in the deck. Another engine to add can be Illusion of Chaos + Magician Souls for extra draw power and another free body on board.  

COMBOS AND GAMEPLAN

The gameplan with this deck is to spam the board with as much level 3s as possible, then proceed to turbo out boss monsters from the Extra Deck. Any two level 3s monsters make Utopic Draco Future, Accesscode, Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, and Zeus. Ideally, this deck likes to go first so it can make a board, interrupt the opponent, then OTK the turn afterwards. Going second this deck can easily turbo out a 4 material Zeus or play through interruption to OTK with Accesscode. GOING FIRST, the R3NK duelist can make a board consisting of Utopic Draco Future, DPE, with perhaps some handtraps in the hand. If a hand is amazing, the end board can also consist of Baronne or an intact Adventurer Token + Gryphon Rider combo. Everybody and their mom already know the Adventurer, DPE and Halq/Accesscode combo, so I’ll only be explaining the combos to make Utopic Draco Future and Baronne. 2 level 3 monsters -> Utopic Draco Future:
  1. XYZ summon Ghostrick Alucard using the two level 3 monsters.
  2. Overlay Ghostrick Angel of Mischief on Alucard.
  3. Detach Ghostrick Alucard from Angel of Mischief to search Ghostrick Shot from deck.
  4. Activate Ghostrick Shot to resurrect Alucard from GY.
  5. Overlay Ghostrick Angel of Mischief on Alucard.
  6. XYZ Summon Number F0: Utopic Future. Alucard will activate once sent to the GY, and retrieve Ghostrick Shot from GY (follow-up for next turn).
  7. Overlay Number F0: Utopic Draco Future on Utopic Future. (With leftover material on board, you can make Baronne, Anaconda->DPE, or if going second, go for Zeus/Accesscode).
Adventurer Engine + Level 3 Tuner -> Baronne: Creating Baronne is hand/situation dependent, but this deck can still make her fairly regularly. There are two ways to create Baronne, and both involve using up leftovers of the Adventurer Engine:
  1. Any level 3 tuner + Gryphon Rider creates Baronne. If Baronne uses up her negate, she can tag back into Gryphon Rider during standby phase for another omni-negate!
  2. Alternatively, the level 4 Adventurer token + level 3 tuner + level 3 non-tuner can make Baronne.
GOING SECOND, the R3NK duelist can slow down the opposing player with handtraps then break the board with Zeus. The battling monster of choice here is Fortune Tune since it has protection. After the battle phase it can be overlayed by our favourite Zeus pilot Downerd Magician for an extra Zeus activation. Once the board is reset, you have a choice of building your board as if you’re going first. Ghostrick Shot is a 1 card 3 material Zeus if Alucard is already in the GY. This set-up (Alucard in GY and Shot in hand) is usually accomplished the turn after you create Utopic Draco Future. The combo is as follows: Shot resurrects Alucard -> Banish Shot to attach a Ghostrick card from GY to Alucard. Overlay Alucard ->Downerd->Attack -> Zeus. This turns Ghostrick Shot into a 1 card fieldwipe! If you feel confident you can OTK, this deck can play through interruptions, generate 8000+ ATK and easily clear the board with Gryphon Rider’s bounce, Baronne’s destruction effect and Accesscode’s multiple destructions so you can swing for game!  

GENERAL TIPS

  • Before you start off with your opening plays, try to bait out your opponent’s handtraps/interruption by using the Adventurer cards first.
  • Don’t forget that Crossout Designator can negate other staple cards as long as the same cards are present in your deck – notable examples being Called by the Grave, Rite of Aramesia and Destiny Hero Celestial.
  • If all your plays are stopped, try to at least get two monsters on field so you can make Anaconda -> DPE. If you survive until next turn, you can potentially make a comeback with the +2 draw and special summon that Celestial and Dasher provide in the GY.
  • Once you complete making your Utopic Draco Future, you can use your Adventurer Token + Gryphon Rider to make Anaconda->DPE. If your opponent tries to stop Anaconda, Utopic Draco Future will negate their handtrap!
  • A Baronne with a spent negate can tag back into Gryphon Rider during Standby Phase for another omni-negate, given that the Adventurer Token is still on the field. Also, if you want to play offensively, she can tag back into a tuner you can make Halq -> Accesscode!
  • Unfortunately, this deck is ridiculously expensive ($1200USD as of this writing) and there are stronger ways to use the boss monsters in R3NK Adventurer in other decks (Swordsoul or B.A.S.E.D for example).
  • This deck loses hard to floodgates like Gozen Match and Skill Drain. This deck’s answer to these floodgates is Dracoback. If facing a floodgate-based opponent, be sure to side in backrow removal.

CONCLUDING COMMENTARY

After watching MBT’s Youtube Ghostrick video on Youtube (check him out, he’s hilarious), it has motivated me to create my own rank 3 spam creation. After MBT issued a challenge for another duelist to put the Ghostrick -> Utopic Draco Future combo in another deck, so I took it! Also, I’ve been playing too much JRPGs, and the I wanted to create a deck based on the stereotypical questing party – with R3NK Adventurer being the result! I strongly believe in projecting my imagination in my duels with the things I like since it greatly enhances my love of the game, so I imagine every duel with R3NK Adventurer as an exciting journey to defeat the villains (nerdy I know lol)! Baronne, DPE, Utopic Draco Future, Accesscode and Zeus are all members of your questing party, ready to destroy your enemies in your mission to win duels! I hope you have as much fun as I do piloting this deck online and IRL. And with that, I’m taking this deck to Locals this week, wish me luck! That’ll be all for now, GLHF Duelists!
VENDREAD (APRIL 2022)

deck_excerpt: HEROs haven't really changed that much, even with 2 regional WCS toppings...
deck_description: Video link is in the description down below: ( https://youtube.com/watch?v=Su-mpNPeQDE&t ) So remember how everyone and their cousin wants the fusion snek gone for reasons that have to do with deck fusion? Well the saints on the day of our lord had came to me to give some reprieve on that solution, and they told me to try it on HEROs. Now while this archetype has a long track record of having some of the most laughably bad monsters, spells, and overall track records out of any anime based archetype that came out of the Yu-Gi-Oh franchise; it is needless to say that most of the archetypes that came out of the original Yu-Gi-Oh animes (DM, GX, 5Ds, and Zexal) were all either lackluster or straight up bad up until after their initial airings. However HEROs tend to be more of a tragedy of their own, mainly because of how archaic the fusion summoning was up until this point; the fact that it took many years for HEROs to get solid support it needs to speed itself up; and the fact that it had multiple banlist hits from Elemental HERO Stratos to even the grand jewel of all fusion cards, Super Polymerization. Now to note on where and why I think that HERO will be one of the few fusion decks to survive against the banning of Predaplant Verte Anaconda is quite simple: it's because this deck doesn't simply run need to run it at all. Arguably, I can say that the reason it was in HERO builds to begin with was to further increase versatility and speed at board building. Truthfully however even without it the speed has taken a slight dip, but doesn't mean that the versatility from the snek has left them. Especially now with Despia and Branded builds running around, the opportunity for HEROs to approach the situations at its pace has come; hence why I have with two silver bullets that can be used for Super Polymerization: Mudragon of the Swamp and Predaplant Triphyoverutum (as one can wipe boards ASAP, and the other can snipe potential threats from any Dark monsters a quick pace). Next part involves what changes I added for the maindeck as a whole (to which there isn't too many, the ones I made are quite decent nontheless). First off instead of Celestial and Dasher, comes Malicious and Denier; simply because I find this to be a lot more consistent than to wait and pray for an empty hand. Next comes the introduction of Destiny HERO - Drawhand: one of the newer Destiny HERO monsters (released in 2020) that if special summoned by an effect of a HERO monster (which is a lot likely), you and your opponent can draw a card; but if this triggers with Masked HERO Dark Law on the field, he banishes one random card from your opponents hand. Then comes the addition of Triple Tactics Talent because I'm not playing a lot of handtraps. Finally, there is nothing really serious that changed about this deck at all, and until it happens that either branded expands into opening itself more than the Dark/Light attribute, or there is someone that can make HEROs into a defensive deck; this might be where they be stuck being for a very long time...

deck_excerpt: In depth about Prediction Princess in Master Duel
deck_description: If there is 1 thing that Yu-gi-oh players are unable to do, that would be reading. With Prediction Princess being relatively low-profile to most players, especially the players who've been introduced to the game through Master Duel, nobody truly understands how to play against it effectively until they start using their brain and actually read your cards. Because Deus X-Krawler doesn't have an Effect that triggers upon it being flipped face-up, despite it being a Flip Monster, your opponents, who have never seen the card before, will usually not realize that it is basically a one-sided Skill Drain. Due to this, you can cheese a lot of games strictly because your opponent refused to read. Prediction Princess is a really fun Ritual Deck which revolves around Prediction Princess Tarotrei and you aim to utilize Pot of the Forbidden, Deus X-Krawler, and an assortment of Rank 9 Monsters to run your opponent out of resources and plays. We run 3 Prediction Princess Tarotrei because she is the centerpoint of the Deck. During the End Phase, she Summons a Flip Monster from your hand or GY and as HOPT and only 1 Effect per turn, you can flip a monster on the field face-down or flip one face-up. Not only does this activate the Effects of your Flip Monsters, but it can also prevent some of your opponent's Extra Deck Summons by flipping a key monster face-down. 3 Impcantation Chalislime. This card basically Summons an Impcantation from Deck at the cost of pitching 1 card (which can be itself), and you usually do not have to worry about the 2500 burn during the End Phase since you are most likely Ritual Summoning right after anyways. It gives you greater access to your Impcantations for Ritual Monsters and Spells and it can be searched off of Preparation of Rites which is great. 1 Sauravis, the Ancient and Ascended. If your opponent targets a monster you control with an Effect, you can discard this to negate that. Tarotrei is a prime target for removal and negation because she enables all of your plays. Sauravis can protect her from Effect Veiler, Infinite Impermanence, Paleozoic Dinomischus, or basically anything relevant that targets. It can easily be cut for gem reasons, but if you have it, it is just another layer of protection. 3 Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring of course as a staple. 3 Spirit of the Fall Wind. Tarotrei needs at least 1 Flip Monster in rotation for her to do her magic and because you usually never Normal Summon in this Deck, Spirit of the Fall Wind is a good choice for those reasons as it searches Flip Monsters upon Normal Summon. 3 Impcantation Talismandra and 2 Impcantation Candoll. Talismandra searches Ritual Monsters and Candoll searches Spells and because Impcantations can Summon each other from Deck, because we are running more Ritual Monsters, running more Talismandra means more access to Candoll and Ritual Spells. 2 Deus X-Krawler and 2 Pot of the Forbidden. Deus X is a one-sided Skill Drain as long as it remains face-up after being flipped and it can search Tarotrei if it is destroyed. Pot of the Forbidden is a HOPT Pot of Greed, Giant Trunade, Raigeki, or The Forceful Sentry. Usually, you are using the Giant Trunade Effect to go for game or the Raigeki Effect to board wipe. The Pot of Greed Effect rarely does come up, but The Forceful Sentry Effect is good for preventing your opponent from potentially gaining advantage while you are in a winning board state. More often, you would like to see Deus X more than Pot of the Forbidden since Deus X's one-sided Skill Drain is much stronger than something like a Raigeki from Pot of the Forbidden, but they are the 2 best Level 9 Flip Monsters so it's fine. For the Spells/Traps, 3 Pre-preparation of Rites and 2 Preparation of Rites. Pre-prep searches out Tarotrei and Prediction Ritual so 3 is most optimal. As for Prep, it searches either Chalislime or Sauravis and it can recycle a Ritual Spell if need be, but as it doesn't get you immediate access to Tarotrei, 3 can be bricky. 3 Prediction Ritual which Summons Tarotrei. Also, on the turn that it wasn't sent to the GY, it can banish itself to add a Tarotrei to hand. This reduces the need to constantly see Impcantations and Pre-preps, so that is pretty nice. 1 Impcantation Inception. This card basically is a 4th copy of Prediction Ritual if the situation ever comes up. 3 Pot of Prosperity as it is just an all-round great searcher card. 3 World Legacy Monstrosity which Summons 2 Level 9's (Pot of the Forbidden and Deus X) from Deck if you target Tarotrei with it. This can give immediate access to a Rank 9 or it can be used to put Flip Monsters into rotation for Tarotrei. Also something to keep in mind is that you can Book 1 monster Summoned by Monstrosity to prevent it from being destroyed during the End Phase. However, despite the destruction during the End Phase being mandatory, in Master Duel, it actually happens after the window in which you are allowed to activate Tarotrei's End Phase Effect, so you will not be able to Summon the other monster back which is really unfortunate. However, the destruction will trigger Deus X which allows him to search a Tarotrei for next Turn. Lastly, we have 3 Infinite Impermanence. Imperm cannot be banished by Called by the Grave in the same way Effect Veiler can be, so it is a better card for disruption. The Extra Deck has 1 Divine Arsenal AA-ZEUS - Sky Thunder, 1 Number F0: Utopic Future, and 1 Number F0: Utopic Draco Future. These are great cards to go with Xyz Decks, but you can definitely only choose to play the 1 Zeus for budget reasons. 3 Number 92; Heart-eartH Dragon. This card is usually fodder for Prosperity, but it is pretty hard to out if you do ever make it unless your opponent is actively running removal. 2 Phantom Fortress Enterblathnir. This card is removal, and just like Pot of the Forbidden's The Forceful Sentry Effect, it can be used to hinder your opponent further while you are in a winning game state. 3 Infinitrack Earth Slicer. This card is absolutely insane for removal. 3 Nine-Lives Cat. This is mainly just for budget purposes, but its revival Effects can come in handy. 1 True King of All Calamities which is absolutely insane because it was banned in the TCG and OCG for a reason. I would advise against playing Jormungandr, Generaider Boss of Eternity because it doesn't accomplish much in this Deck other than being a beefy body. Another potential Rank 9 you can play is Sacred Tree Beast, Hyperyton, but you would rather make that early in the game which this Deck usually falls to Xyz later on in the game. More cards I would recommend playing would be Dark Ruler No More since this Deck isn't the greatest trying to break a massive negation board without help. Called by the Grave is good against Ash, Veiler, and Droll. Maxx "C" is great for draw power which is very useful in a Ritual Deck. Gizmek Kaku, the Supreme Shining Sky Stag is a free Level 9 monster on board if there is a monster in the EMZ and it can act as removal for your opponent's monster in the EMZ. It gives good Rank 9 access and is pretty good removal. Kaijus are another great choice for this Deck. Thunder King and Mecha-Thunder-King are the only Level 9 Kaijus and both are Summonable off of Interrupted Kaiju Slumber and both give Rank 9 access. Mecha-Thunder-King can also bring itself back during the End Phase as a OPD and it can act as another body on the field or Rank 9 access for next turn. Monster Reborn is great because you can get back a Tarotrei your opponent destroyed. Harpie's Feather Duster and Lightning Storm are good against backrow and so is Red Reboot. This Deck only has access to backrow removal in the Extra Deck, so having some options in the Main Deck is good if you can afford it. Whirlwind Weasel and Guard Dog are Imperial Order/Royal Decree and Vanity's Emptiness respectively, but they are not that optimal to run as it hurts consistency massively and they can be seen as more of a hinderance than an asset.

Drytron is lowkey really sweet in this format. It's pretty obvious that the ban list is quite different in Master Duel than it was in the TCG or OCG at this point in comparable metas, and in many ways it is quite favourable to the deck. Drytron is literally full power, and the archetype already has a lot going for it - Heralds are obviously really strong, Benten abuse is insane, Eva is nuts, and it can toolbox the extra deck to really play to what you like, or already own. There are a couple of big downsides to the deck, namely Skill Drain monke Eldlich, but much more importantly, the strong presence of Maxx "C", as well as Gamma's increased presence despite a semi-limit (BO1 means you have to main the tech). So, it's a struggle - you literally can't run enough outs for Skill Drain and Maxx "C" at the same time, particularly with the pretty close to required number of consistency cards and combo pieces. However, there's a really strong reward if you could solve those problems. This version is a compromise leaning on the "dodge Lich" side, which loses hard to Droll but has pretty solid game against Maxx "C". You could consider different ratios, depending on what you see, where you are on the ladder, and your own playstyle. I will be making suggestions for alternatives, budget options, and cards to consider.  Drytron, for the uninitiated, is a combo deck based on abusing Drytron monsters and generic Fairy ritual support from a variety of archetypes. Your basic goal is to use Drys to tribute Benten as many times as possible to get as many searches as possible, and you're trying to ritual summon a Herald as early in the combo as feasible to protect the combo while holding up interruptions. Your final goal is to fill your hand using Eva, which can be sent from the deck in a variety of ways.  So, I want to talk about interruptions. Obviously, beating Maxx "C" is important to me. I usually rely on around 5-7 cards to beat Maxx "C". This list is quite in the middle, on 6. Herald of the Orange Light is like Gamma without the restrictions or the brick... For a cost, which is pitching a Fairy. You search these throughout the combo, as a back-up in case Herald gets Kaiju'd or something. But they're also really here to be your anti-handtrap cards. In order to facilitate these, we are also running 14 Fairies, 3 Heralds and 11 other cards. You could run Called By, which would give you some game against random Drolls, and it would be good - I decided it conflicted too much with the 1 of Extra-Foolish, and that I'd rather run Ash on the basis of being an actual hand trap, wheras the other interaction spots are filled by Spell/Trap removal to answer floodgates. Maybe I get Ordered, but at least I can out the Skill Drain. I'm also on 2 Lancea, high impact in some matchups, at least useful in most, and it helps meet the criteria for having random Fairies in my hand for Orange Light. You could maybe get away with running Called By over Lancea, but I'd suggest running 1, because it can be game sometimes, and you can just search it. I think when you're deciding what hand traps to run, you have to be really worried about being able to out most floodgates, and have game against Maxx "C", and I don't think there's space for a ton of interaction in the deck. Gamma is another great option in this deck, especially if you're hurt for Ultys.  So, for Dry names I'm on 2 Alpha, 2 Zeta, 1 Gamma, and 1 Delta. Alpha Zeta is full combo, and it is insane, but you have so many consistency cards, both in the main and in the Extra deck. You're going to full combo with a ROTA + either Alpha or Zeta, whereas 2 Alphas are just sad Alphas. In total we have 10 consistency cards that search out your missing Dry name - 3 Cyber Emergency, best ROTA, 1 Foolish Burial, cause Drys are insane, 2 Nova and 2 Fafnir, with the basis being seeing either of these in multiple are bad, but they're slightly better as a pair, and each is better in different situations even though they're both effectively copies of your HOPT Nova, and 2 Mathematician, the decks main NS starter. Mathman is run over Scrap Recycler here because it can send Eva in addition to Drys, but recycler has applications if you want to use Scrap Wyvern into Nightmare Unicorn going second, so if you have Wyvern there are upsides to running Recycler. I do think access to Eva is way more important. Also, Recycler is a fine budget option - 90% of the time corporate can't tell the difference. There may be hands where you don't want to start with Mathman - your basic combo can search out Diviner of the Heralds for great value, which also helps make Beatrice, and in addition if you don't need Mathman to get plays started, holding onto it to send Eva or play through an interuption is probably correct anyways. Diviner is a fine combo starter in its own right, if you have Zeta you send Arc Light to search Benten, if you have Alpha you send Arc Light for the Ritual Spell. We're running 2 of the Ritual spell, because A) you do need this to do your combo and do want to just see it sometimes, and B) you can search out and use multiple copies of the ritual spell, or even hold a copy for follow-ups.  The next part of the deck is just 5 copies of Benten. You want to hard see Benten, and in the absence of Benten you want ways to search Benten. If you don't have Benten it is optimal so search Benten. If you're searching with Benten, Benten searches for Benten, and it is sometimes correct to just chain Benten. We're running a 1/1 mix of Prep and Extra-Foolish. Prep is great, and you could consider 2, but I've found often you can't pick up 2 Ritual spells when you see both copies of Prep anyways, and when you can you can rarely use the spell for much anyways. Plus, the first copy of Extra-Foolish may put us off Called By and occasionally gimp Cosmic, but it is also access to the Ritual spell, which really is the secret key to unlocking this deck, how do I get the ritual spell, as well as high-level rituals, such as Herald of Ultimateness, and occasionally the Drytron 12s (its a ritual you can search that you can tribute to ritual summon, then ritual summon from the GY...)  There's a small Cyber Angel package here. Idaten is crazy, you can abuse Idaten to ritual summon so many times and just Link climb and make Xyz monsters. Natasha is for the grind game, a tool to link climb into Accesscode for a big finish, but also weirdly fine as this sort of passive value engine. It's way better in a world with 3 Benten, and people swear by it with 1. Ultimateness could be Perfection if you're looking for a budget option - it is effectively doing the same thing. While it is worse in many ways that actually literally do really matter, it's also just so busted despite that that in most games you won't notice. Its also searchable with Prep, if you're on 2 or 3 Prep (it's still fine, it's not a HOPT). Likewise for the Drytron ritual - the Ulty is way better as a card, but the Secret is fine and has fringe utility, and 90% of the time corporate can't tell the difference. Its literally just searchable tribute fodder. For Ultys in the main you literally only need 1 Diviner, and 1 of the Ritual spell, if you're looking to start out in Master Duel - in the Extra deck you'll want to build a good collection of pretty generic extra-deck cards most likely, but in a pinch I'd say you only really need 1 Beatrice, 1 Herald of the Arc Light, 1 Mu Beta Fafnir, and 1 Linkuriboh - if you have to choose 1 choose Beatrice, not because it is that good in any other deck (BA? more like BO) but because it is core here. After that, you can fill the deck with whatever generic Link monsters you have - the real goal is just Ultimateness negates, as long as you can Link Idaten away after searching a bunch with Benten and making Ultimateness/Perfection you're doing it right ;)  I think the deck has some meta-game challenges that make it exciting to deck build, but a lot harder to play than in the TCG. But in terms of pure unadulterated power it is hard to get better than Drytron, and I do think the format has the tools for Drytron to be a contender within it. I also think that while it is a slightly complicated deck at first, it is actually pretty quick to pick up and very rewarding to play. I'd also call it a good budget entry option to Master Duel for experienced Yu-Gi-Oh! players interested in Master Duel, but not looking to spend a lot of money.

deck_excerpt: Turn the tide of duels by taking advantage of the toolbox options the Rank 4 slot has to offer in one of its most safe iterations (until we get Crysta
deck_description:
A classic list in recent Trinity history that has kinda fallen off of the radar due to the number of adjustments affecting the Rank 4 and Synchro 8 slots. That said; however, the deck's still all kinds of fun to pilot and use to navigate gamestates that most other decks would have issues with. You play an answer to every situation in the Extra Deck with this build and if it's missing, it can probably just be teched in over something else! Pros:
  • Easy Starts: Buzzsaw Shark or a combination of any two cards that summon themselves out gets you rolling. Your opening play should always consist of making a Rank 4 either disrupt or defend going first.
  • Interaction: Since the deck's lines all just primarily feature ways to turbo Rank 4s, a good chunk of the deck's dedicated to simple interaction in the form of staples and handtraps.
  • 7 Colored Fish?: It's a Normal Monster- which helps with getting around the summon limit in a lot of instances! Due to this status, it's also synergistic with some alternative choices in deck building that we'll cover by the end.
Cons:
  • Rank 4 Chunkiness: If you fail to open Buzzsaw Shark (or it gets disrupted) or fail to find an extender in addition to a normal summon, you'll be behind by quite a bit. While this isn't a super common occurrence, it can set you back in a duel pretty far. Fortunately, the toolbox options in the Extra Deck help with comebacks.
  • Specific Extenders:  To improve the ability to turbo out Rank 4s more consistently by turn 1, some cards like Ice Knight, Goblindberg, Kagetokage, and ZS Armed Sage were added and while they absolutely do their job perfectly, a good portion of the deck tends to conflict with some of their effects. It's important to keep these in mind when determining the starter for each line, especially if you happen to have Silent Sea Nettle or Silent Angler in hand!
  • Prone to Disruption: Most decks will want to interact with you by your second summon, before the Xyz touches down. Sometimes they'll interact with you on the Xyz Summon itself. Either way, when this happens and you don't have follow-up in the form of an extender, it can be quite rough. It's one of the caveats of playing a pseudo-traditional Xyz strategy in a format with capped summons.
Now with that out of the way, let's get into some of the demo setups you'll be wanting to aim for.
OPENERS The hand quality and/or number of extenders in the hand will always make the permuations of the gamestates more or less challenging to emulate; though, this much was obvious. That being said, in the 1st turns of the duel, you ideally just want to have a conga line of Xyzs rolling out. This can be enabled by the following:
  • Defensive Line: Having Hope: Leading with Number 37: Hope Woven Dragon Spider Shark isn't the worst thing you can do, especially if it's made using Buzzsaw Shark. Being able to threaten a 1k drop across the board on top of resurrecting your one card starter makes it exert some pressure while also doubling as a decent attacker. It shines best alongside others or backrow.
  • Exosister Avatar: The introduction of Exosisters left much to be desired for their status in Trinity; however, their Xyz Monsters are great if you have the space. With Traptrix Rafflesia gone and this list not featuring Bagooska, if you're aiming to prevent a specific aspect of your opponent's gameplan, then turboing Mikailis is up your alley. Pick up the Exosister Arment and set it. During your opponent's turn you can either tag into Usophiel who prevents GY effects (and if she survives, is just a compulse) or Jibrine who is more of a supportive card to help you push for early lethal if your opponent's off to a slow start. If you happen to open Arment, simply make Jibrine instead and open up the option of tagging into Mikailis for her Quick Effect banish! Kaspitell's also great, but is more specific to certain match-ups.
  • Post-Siding Negation Snowball: The other two options are really solid and should cover most of your average experiences with the deck; however, post-siding, if you notice that your opponent's list is extremely reliant on Monster Effects to resolve to get their engines rolling, you can opt to side in The Iris Swordsoul, Giant Hand, Ice Barrier, and the Ice-Bound God. These cards all serve as very easy ways to prevent those effects from going off while also generating a lot of pressure and recurring advantage in some way (besides Giant Hand). Paleozoic Marrella and Swordsoul Emergence help get to each of these side strategies faster.
As you can tell, the openers and lines can be pretty linear. Most of the advanced tactics comes from summon management using the non-Effect Monsters and choosing the right Xyz for the job. Rarely will your opponent be generous enough to give you a second or third chance at answering their board. MIDGAME & CLOSERS There's only a few real setups to aim for if you find yourself in the midgame grind or aim to end the game outright.
  • Drill Driver Vespenato: This card's basically another copy of Number 37; however, it's also a piercer! Its utility usually comes up whenever you unfortunately cannot find Whitefish Salvage nor Avarice.
  • Valiant Shark Lancer: This card when paired with Abyss Dweller or Number 37 can easily close out games pretty quickly. Unfortunately, due to its Rank being 5, the setups for it are mostly specific to Buzzsaw Shark, Lantern Shark, and Penguin Squire. However, if achieved successfully, you have now earned yourself a Quick-Effect monster pop. Usually an opponent should aim to take out your Dweller or Number 37 because it turns of Valiant from being a Quick-Effect and removes both forms of pressure at once. When this happens, you'll be able to stack your deck with any sacky option of your choice. I recommend White Mirror, Whitefish Salvage, Pot of Avarice, Instant Fusion, and Monster Reborn.
  • Graydle Dragon: This isn't super consistent to pull off but can be a bit easier if you side in the Ice Barrier engine to find Squire more often. When Graydle Dragon resolves in this deck, you should almost always be using it to clear two cards. Don't settle for just one, Tornado Dragon or Light Dragon @Ignister can do that instead. Graydle Dragon also being able to float is massive as well- although the monster will just be a generic material more than anything else.
Games should usually resolve themselves by midgame. The grind game in this deck isn't the best per se.
While simple in nature, the deck's playstyle favors decision-making and proper risk assessment for problem solving. There's no Numeron Dragon OTK for you to get out of situations easily. Things will have to take patience and proper identification of win conditions to achieve consistent victories with this deck. Here's a handful of ideas just to throw your way should you aim to adjust this baseline into something more focused elsewhere: Tenyi Core, Piercing the Darkness, Dogmatika, Dinosaur, Traptrix Myrmeleo, Super Team Buddy Force Unite!!, Performage Core, Sea Monster of Theseus w/ a Synchro 9, Legacy of the Duelist, Number 101 & C101, ZEXAL, and a whole roster of Rank 4s to slot in instead like Dark Rebellion Xyz Dragon! Thanks for reading, and I hope this has convinced you to give the deck a try! It's a lot of fun to innovate on and revisit a modern classic like this in today's Trinity. I hope you have a fin-tastic time trying it out!

deck_excerpt: Simple budget ABC-Dragon Buster deck, built with some booster cards and singles
deck_description: My strategy with this deck is usually summon enough monsters (by Gold Gadget, Silver Gadget or Union Hangar) to link summon Platinum Gadget or Knightmare Phoenix sending B-Buster Drake or C-Crush Wyvern to the GY, then use these monster's effects from the GY to summon other ABC-Dragon Buster parts and special summon ABC-Dragon Buster using these same parts from the GY and/or field. You can also use any card effects (such as Hand Destruction and Lightning Vortex) to discard ABC-Dragon Buster parts and send them directly to your GY allowing you to summon ABC-Dragon Buster, it isn't optimal because you don't benefit from the effects activated when you send monsters from the field to the GY, but it helps if you're in a tight spot. Then it's just a matter of banishing everything your opponent tries to set or summon so you can keep summoning other ABC-Dragon Buster (by either discarding the parts with ABC-Dragon Buster effect or summoning them on your field) and other link monsters such as Gaia Saber, the Lightning Shadow or Decode Talker to attack your opponent directly, and also remember to use some of the traps to protect yourself and negate monster, spell and trap cards (if you didn't managed to ban all of them while they're face-down). (P.S.: I know some cards aren't really the best options for this kind of deck... but it's what I have available, so I'll have to work with that by now. I hope to keep updating this deck in the future with new cards)
