deck_excerpt: Wanna rule the battle phase without being extremely anime about it? (Looking at your Dragonmaids)- well then, Gladiator Beasts may be the deck for you
deck_description:
Maybe I've been enjoying too much Edison lately, but man does this deck feel great to play- when you can play it. They're back from their 2010s glory with a fresh coat of "wait, Andal's actually bad" paint and a theme park sheen that'll probably convince opponents that this thing's actually pretty competitive. The spell and trap line-up should definitely change with each iteration of the format and any future releases; however, the core that's presented here is probably long-standing enough to supplement future variants. Let's get into the list. Pros:
  • Safety Nets: The sheer amount of disruption and answer cards we're running in this list make it so that our plays are usually insulated in some way. We should never, ever really be in any remote danger during a game as long as we have a Gladiator Beast and a backline to back them up.
  • Amazement Engine: This engine isn't the best, but it's definitely non-intrusive and cycles through enough psuedo-disruption and removal that's relevant enough to run parallel to our gameplan here. Honestly, this archetype goes hand-in-hand with Gladiator Beasts as a whole. Just mind your normal summon.
  • No Andal!: Rescue Rabbit openers and lines are great for getting into Panther or Dragases or setting up a three material fusion but boy did it suck drawing into that card and not having it be able to tag out like the others. Well, there's none of that anymore. We've compromised the Andal combos and random chance of drawing into Rescue Rabbit before it in the interest of having more playable hands overall. Just protect your guy(s) and run over the opponents. There's no need for any fancy business.
Cons:
  • They're all Garnets. All of them: Opening a Gladiator Beast will probably have you saying "man, I wish this one stayed in the deck or was another Gladiator Beast." That's basically this deck's entire experience and why we're only playing the ones that matter. Sadly, that little dilemma will always remain in this deck and there isn't much to be done about it outside of Contact Fusing or bringing out Augustus. It feels even worse that a Trinity is being spent on Proving Ground just to increase the odds of finding a Glad, especially in a pinch. Pick a Glad and pray.
  • Extra Deck:  The Extra Deck will usually be useless sometimes if you find yourself in a situation where you need to break down a board before you start committing to anything flashy. It's for this reason that we're not on any Extra Deck Trinities here and I'd personally advise against it. Fortunately, this does also mean that we're pretty insulated against cards like Titanocider which is pretty popular this format.
  • Forehead Girl is an FTK: Ash solos. Godspeed.
Now with that out of the way, let's get into some of the demo setups you'll be wanting to aim for.
OPENERS This list isn't about finding gas, it's about opening defenses and protecting your Gladiator. You'll ideally be wanting to always go first. If you're going with no backup, I'd strongly encourage just combat tricking out the opponent. There isn't any specific opener you'll want to look for since Gladiator Beasts take on a midrange playstyle here (without Andal anyway), so your opening hands determine your line of play. Here's a few pointers though if you're inexperienced with them or the Amazement engine:
  • Phalanx: Control a Gladiator Beast and protect them with backrow. If there's something you can use to either change a monster's battle position to make them vulnerable on your turn or modify combat stats so your monster will survive the attack, that's ideal.
  • The Blender: The Amazement engine does well to shake up the usual flow of some games. If you happen upon a Ticket and you're not sure what to do with it entirely, going for Comica and setting Horror House is perfectly fine. If you know you'll be able to beat the monster you book, then you can resolve it on the opponent's monster. If you're confident you can get a lot more mileage out of Comica, use Horror House during the Draw Phase and equip it directly to her. This will enable her to act as a monster negate or book of moon on the dime. I recommend trying to be greedy with Comica when possible, especially if you have back row to back her up. Cashing in for the set effect from Horror House is great too, but the monster effect negation is basically infinite for as long as you can maintain it. Grabbing Coaster or Arlekino are fine as well. Arlekino should primarily be used as a means of removal more than just being a body. You don't really need those in this deck.
  • Ob-Noxious: If you've opened Noxious and backrow, feel free to set those cards and outright pass. Usually people will just attack you outright, so you punish with Noxious. Bin either something you want to bring back with Darius (who Noxious will tag out into after) or bin something you don't want to draw, like Augustus. Tag as appropriate.
The openers aren't always ideal and will vary from game-to-game, especially post-siding. The main thing to do is plan ahead. Measure your options and weigh your forms of interaction well. Everything in your deck is an extremely limited resource and this deck lacks card draw. MIDGAME This is where Gladiator Beasts shine really. You'll be doing your best Unchained-meets-Dragonmaid impression here... despite preceding both of those archetypes. Hmm.
  • Bestiari: Your Spell/Trap removal. This card's also really important for making Gyzarus who is your Icarus Attack on-summon. S/T hate's pretty restricted across the board in Trinity format and most decks only rely on generics to get it done. Since Glad Beasts tag out often, you have this form of removal going for you on top of the generic removal you're already running here. It's worth noting that this card's effect to destroy is mandatory, so don't summon it willy-nilly otherwise you might end up having to pop your own backline.
  • Murmillo: Your Monster removal. This card's your go-to for checking the board and clearing potential threats. Its combat stats leave much to be desired, but it doesn't have to partake in combat if it's already won now has it? Use it for fusion material when you can, or take an open attack. Don't get greedy with the fish.
  • The Tag Team: Gladiator Beast War Chariot's an amazing Counter Trap and since most win conditions in Trinity format revolve around Monster effects, having access to this is nothing to scoff at. Samnite grabs this for you and Equeste loops this for you. Loop these two as necessary to keep up the War Chariot pressure and you'll have your opponent on the ropes.
Games should usually resolve themselves by midgame due to all of the removal, but Gladiator Beasts can definitely go into a late or grind game. LATEGAME & CLOSERS The killing blow. Leave absolutely no room for a comeback. This is the Gladiator's Proving Ground.
  • Secutor: Resolving Secutor once basically wins the game on the spot. Resolving it during the opponent's turn? Well, that's probably traumatizing to say the least. Ideally you'll be wanting to bring out those that are all-stars in the midgame (as listed above); however, if you're ready to go in for the kill, summon out Laquari or Vespasius instead for fusion setups we'll cover just below.
  • Domitianus: Monster effect activation negation with no cost whatsoever and dictates who attacks who during your opponent's turn? Make this when you know it's a valid win condition. Just keep in mind that it only tags out into only 1 other Gladiator Beast. This card is really bad to use mid game as a result since, if it would fall, you would be put severely behind for the contact fusion play. Don't be greedy with Domitianus.
  • Heraklinos: Your Spell/Trap activation negation station. This card ain't even once per turn. As long as you have cards to discard, you can keep up the suffocation against your opponent. Unfortunately, this card doesn't have a tag out nor a float, so it should be used exclusively as a finisher where you're confident it will win. If it happens to get removed, you'll be set back pretty far.
The most important thing to note about this list is that any and all Spell/Traps selected here can and should be experimented with and swapped out to fit your playstyle with the deck in a given format. This is not a one size fits all situation and due to the variance concerning the hands, the learning curve with deciphering the best way to spend one's opening turns is definitely pretty steep. Regardless, here's a handful of ideas just to throw your way should you aim to adjust this baseline into something more focused elsewhere: Melffy engine with Andal, Traptrix/Gokipole engine, Trinities on Gladiator Beast's Comeback, Geartown engine, Loop of Destruction, Ancient Warriors - Ambitious Cao De, Amazement Ambassador Bufo, Amazement Precious Park, Archfiend's Staff of Despair, Gladiator Beast's Battle Manica, Burden of the Mighty Thanks for reading, and I hope this has convinced you to give the deck a try! This deck's a classic in Yu-Gi-Oh! history and it's honestly incredible to see it in a playable state in modern Trinity's climate. But don't just take my word for it- step on up into the Colosseum to Disarm, Parry, and Lash out against any and all who oppose your bestial fury!
Non-competitive Machina deck

deck_excerpt: An experimental ABC build utilizing the soon-to-be-released-in-the-TCG Therions archetype alongside Epigonen, the Impersonation Invader which allows f
deck_description: This ABC deck, which be viable in the TCG in late May, utilizes Therions' "King" Regulus which functions as both an omni-negate and an extender given you can summon whatever ABC piece that Regulus will end up equipping in order to summon itself. Epigonen, the Impersonation Invader is still part of the deck given the sheer power of the card in ABC.  While you're looking to end on Therions' "King" Regulus, Predaplant Verte Anaconda, DESTINY Hero - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, ABC Dragon Buster, and I:P Masquerena - be sure to destroy Verte with DPE before reviving DPE during the standby phase so that you have enough monster zones to utilize Dragon Buster's tag out effect. Nevertheless, you'll have four forms of disruption with Masquerena leading into the summon of an Appolousa with four negates or Underworld Goddess of the Closed World, which can be summoned with an opponent's monster, when paired with the pieces summoned through Dragon Buster's ability to tag out.  If you open optimally, you can also end, if you so  wish, on Regulus, Verte, DPE, Dragon Buster, and an Appolousa with three negates and with an immunity to destruction effects via Masquerena's effect. You'll still want to clear Verte from the field for the aforementioned reason. I wish I didn't have to remove the PSY-Frame engine from the main deck but it's still present in the side.  I've updated the deck to utilize Artifact Dagda and Artifact Scythe. Whether you choose to rely on the Scythe lock, potentially to the detriment of bearing additional forms of disruption, is up to your preference and the matchup at hand. Although, if you open optimally, you can end on I:P + Verte + Regulus + ABC Dragon Buster (+ Dagda?) with a set Artifact Scythe. Whether Dagda is to be used as material for Verte or be left on the field is dependent on your opening but be sure to ensure there is enough space for Dragon Buster to tag out by destroying Verte and Dagda if necessary via DPE's effect on your own turn. All in all, it is rather easy to set up the DPE and Scythe combo, with there being paths to which enable the combo depending on your opening, in this build for the sake of abusing the Scythe lock.
Salamangreat - Master Duel Version.

deck_excerpt: Mostly budget build using the Albaz Strike and Shaddoll Showdown structure decks as a basis.
deck_description: This was an improvised semi-budget build using the Albaz Strike and Shaddoll Showdown structure decks as a basis. I prefer BLS to Levianeer and added Branded in Red, Ecclesia the Virtuous and a single extravagance for consistency. Additionally I opted for El Shaddol Fusion over Super Poly because it can be recovered using the Shaddoll fusion monsters.  For a more true budget friendly build: Ecclesia and Prosperity in the main can be swapped for golden swordwoul and a third copy of extravagance, and Selene/Accesscode in the extra deck can be swapped for a second copy of Brigand and a copy of Triple Burst Dragon.

Activate Ogre Dance adding Ze amin~ Normal summon Ze Amin~ Activate its effect and add Foxy Tune~ Activate Foxy sending other card from your hand to special summon Dia Note from your deck ~Synchro summon Chaos Ruler ~chain 1 Chaos ruler effect and chain 2 Dia Note ~Dia Note summons back Ze Amin and Chaos Ruler mills 5 and add one dark or light ~link summon Halqifibrax ~halq summon 001 from deck ~Link summon Auroradon ~summon tokens, summon 001 back ~Synchro summon Cupid Pitch ~Cupid effect to rise its level by 1 ~now, if you wanna make Borreload Savage you just summon its directly, but if you wanna shenshen you need to synchro summon Accel Synchro Stardust and then use its effect to summon back 001 ~Independent of what you've chosen, you used cupid pitch so you can search for Destiny Hero - Plasma ~Chaos ruler second effect, banish Ogre Dance and Cupid from gy to special summon itself ~Tribute Auroradon, his last token and Chaos ruler to special summon Plasma. deck_excerpt: Just another Scythe Lock variant that uses my favorite engine: Mill
deck_description:
Okay, before you ask why I don't play Grass, just let me tell you one thing: This Deck objective is NOT milling half your Deck. Surely it's a "Lightsworn" and "Chaos" Deck, but those are just the engines used to turbo out Scythe Lock. As someone who dislikes and wishes that Scythe is banned forever and ever because of how annoying and toxic it is, I'm very ashamed to say that I got to Plat 1 this season with 9 winstreaks using Scythe Lock Turbo. Probably my most successful Deck so far, even beating my Adamancipator Deck. And all it takes is just ONE. BAD. DAY. I was playing Dragon Link a while ago (because I have like 80% of the cards), and drop from Plat 2 to Plat 4 in just an hour or so. So I just decided to ruin people day with Scythe Lock the next day, and I got to Plat 1 along the way. There are multiple variants of Scythe Lock Turbo, and I chose Chaos Danger! Lightsworn because it's my favorite Deck. And now I have tainted it...

Objective

This is a Combo Deck, but I'm not gonna show a 1-2 card Combo because the Combo varies and have many different lines. However, all of the Combo really are trying to accomplish one thing: Scythe Locking your opponent. Ok, I haven't explained what a "Scythe Lock" is. For people who lived under a rock and never heard of it, Scythe Lock is basically a floodgate caused by the effect of Artifact Scythe. If Artifact Scythe is popped during your opponent's turn, it will Special itself from GY and if it's Special Summoned during your opponent's turn, your opponent cannot use their Extra Deck for the rest of the turn, and this is a Lingering effect, meaning that after it resolves, it can no longer be negated. So basically Dimensional Barrier but stronger. Scythe Lock was never been consistent in the past, that is until Crystron Halqifibrax and Artifact Dagda came into the game (They happened to came out from the same Set. Oh Konami, maybe you planned this?) Crystron Halqifibrax can banish itself to Synchro into T.G. Wonder Magician (yes this is treated as a Synchro Summon) whose on Summon can pop 1 Spell/Trap (in this case pop your own Scythe). Artifact Dagda can Set an Artifact directly from your Deck when a card or effect on the field is activated. And after that, you can Quick Synchro Scythe and Wonder Magician into Baronne. And boi, those two Link Monsters are SO GENERIC. And it got way worse when DPE came out. Literally any 4 monsters = Scythe Lock while also giving you a broken Boss Monster that pop things and come back every single turn. Ok now let's actually go into the Deck's objective:

Starter

You will start your play with either Charge of the Light Brigade or Emergency Teleport into Psi-Reflector. Psi-Reflector is a 1 card Halqifibrax/Chaos Ruler, the Chaotic Magical Dragon. Psi-Reflector can search Assault Beast on Summon and Assault Beast can discard itself to search Assault Mode Activate. Psi-Reflector can then reveal the Assault Mode Activate to Summon Assault Beast from GY and increases Assault Beast's Level by 1-4. Charge of Light Brigade can mill 3 cards as COST and search Raiden, Hand of the Lightsworn. Raiden can mill 2 cards for free (and bait a handtrap if your opponent isn't smart) and just happened to be a Level 4 Tuner, which is an important factor. Then you can Summon a Level 4 monster, either through Raiden's mill (Wulf, Lightsworn Beast or Performage Trick Clown) or from your hand (Danger! Mothman!/Danger! Chupacabra!, White Dragon Wyverbuster/Black Dragon Collapserpent, or Chaos Valkyria). Black/White Dragon can be searched through Chaos Space. With those 2 monsters, you can then Synchro into Chaos Ruler which can excavate 5 cards, add 1 LIGHT or DARK monster from it, and send the rest to the GY. You can easily chain block Chaos Ruler with Black/White Dragon to avoid getting ashed. There's also an alternative line where you have neither Charge/Raiden or E-Tele/Psi-Reflector. In this case, you can just spam DARK monsters in order to Link into Curious, the Lightsworn Dominion. This is easily achievable thanks to the Danger! archetype. All the Danger! used in this Deck has different Types while also being DARK. This is enough to fulfill Curious's materials. Not only that, these Danger! also happened to have different Types with your other DARK monsters (Dragon, Zombie, Psychic).

Goal

Chaos Ruler was just an Extender to get a ton of card advantages before actually setting up your Scythe Lock. All you have to do to set up the Scythe Lock is Link into Halqifibrax using any resources you have and Summon Jet Synchron from Deck, then you can Link Jet Synchron into Linkuriboh and Jet Synchron can revive itself from GY so you can make Dagda. You don't need to Trigger Dagda on your own turn as it will Trigger from Halqifibrax 2nd Effect on your opponent's turn. Additionally, if you have Chaos Ruler on the field already, instead of Linking into Linkuriboh, you can Synchro Jet Synchron and Chaos Ruler into Hot Red Dragon Archfiend Abyss. Then you can revive Chaos Ruler and Jet Synchron with their own respective Effects to make Dagda.

Extra Objective

This part is optional and only happens when you're lucky enough to have the resources to do so. If you happen to have Chaos Dragon Levianeer, you can make Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy with it and Chaos Ruler. It can protect your monsters from battle (once) while also being a Spell Negate. Curious can then used to make 2 material Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess. It's not much, but it can at least protect you from Nibiru. You can easily caught your opponent off guard on this 6th Summon because your opponent probably won't Nibiru 2 monsters, including Curious (which can add ANY card from GY if it gets Nibiru'd). If you have some Extra Level 4 monsters, you can make Abyss Dweller. Dweller can completely prevents your opponent from activating GY Effects for an entire turn (or 2 turns even, since it has 2 materials), and this is yet another Lingering Effect just like Scythe. Dweller might win you games on its own against certain matchups like Drytron or Tri-Brigade who relies on GY Effect to make plays. Dweller is also a go-to card to make when you get Maxx "C"-ed and don't want to give your opponent too many advantages while also making a decent board to not die. After Dagda does its job and Set Scythe, you can use it as Link Fodder for Apollousa.

Deck Breakdown

Main Deck

3x Charge of the Light Brigade; 3x Raiden, Hand of the Lightsworn; 2x Wulf, Lightsworn Beast

This is the Lightsworn Engine. This is not exactly a Lightsworn Deck, that's why I only play 3 different Main Deck Lightsworn cards. So basically, the way the Engine works is very simple. Charge of Light Brigade mill 3 cards and search a Lightsworn. The mill is a cost and the actual Effect is the search, so if it got negated (by Ash or something), you still mill 3 cards regardless. Then you can Normal Summon Raiden (searched by Charge) which can mill 2 cards which is funny because a lot of people decided to Ash, Veiler, or Imperm it despite having such a mediocre Effect. Raiden is also a Tuner, so its perfect for Chaos Ruler and Halqifibrax. Lastly we have Wulf, a Level 4 monster that Special itself when sent from Deck to the GY. Its a dead card if you draw it, otherwise Free Summon. I only play 2 copies because I cut the 3rd one for Trick Clown which is basically Wulf, but Special itself when sent to the GY regardless from where (Wulf isn't once per turn though).

3x Chaos Space; 2x Chaos Dragon Levianeer; 2x Starliege Seyfert; 1x White Dragon Wyverbuster; 1x Black Dragon Collapserpent; 1x Chaos Valkyria

This is the Chaos part of the Deck. Not too many Chaos monsters, but I picked the best ones out there. Chaos Space search any LIGHT or DARK Level 4-8 monster that cannot be Normal Summoned/Set by sending a monster with the opposite Attribute from hand to GY. This pretty much searches all your Chaos monsters. It also has a neat GY Effect to recycle your banished LIGHT or DARK monster that cannot be Normal Summoned/Set to the bottom of your Deck and draw 1. Your best target for Chaos Space is Black/White Dragon. But if you already have them or milled them, you can search Levianeer (DARK) or Valkyria (LIGHT) instead.

Levianeer is pretty much the best Extender you can ever ask for. Easy to Summon, great Effects with great versatility. You can either shuffle 1 card from your opponent's hand into the Deck or Special ANY monster from GY in Defense, or even pop 2 cards without targeting if you go 2nd. Seyfert can banish itself from GY to add back Levianeer from GY and Levianeer inherent Summon is not once per turn. I only play 2 copies of Levianeer though, because I don't want to see it in my opening hand without any GY setup.

Black/White Dragon is a Free Summon from hand and searches each other when sent from the field to the GY. Since you will be searching them with Chaos Space 90% of the time, you can actually use Chaos Space 2nd Effect to recycle your banished Black/White Dragon so you can get 2 searches instead of 1. Chaos Valkyria serves the same purpose, except she doesn't replace herself with another monster like Black/White Dragon does. But since all of their Special Summon Effect are once per turn, its better to play Chaos Valkyria than a 2nd Copy of the dragons. Also, Chaos Valkyria can send ANY LIGHT or DARK monster from Deck to GY when banished. Although, just like Shooting Riser Dragon, you can't use their Effects this turn. Best target for this is Snow. If you already milled Snow, Seyfert and Levianeer is the best target for follow-up.

3x Psi-Reflector; 2x Emergency Teleport; 1x Assault Beast; 1x Assault Mode Activate

This is the Psi-Reflector Engine. As I mentioned earlier, Psi-Reflector can search up Assault Beast on Summon and Assault Beast can search Assault Mode Activate by discarding itself. Then, Psi-Reflector can reveal Assault Mode Activate to Summon Assault Beast from GY, modifying its Level to 5-8 allowing you to Synchro into a Level 6-9 Synchro. And guess what? Psi-Reflector just happened to be a Psychic, meaning that E-Tele can Special it from Deck. So you can go into Chaos Ruler without your Normal Summon. If you milled Assault Beast, that's no problem because Psi-Reflector can also search Assault Mode Activate itself. But if you milled Assault Mode Activate, your engine is dead.

3x Danger! Nessie!; 3x Danger! Mothman!; 3x Danger! Chupacabra!; 2x Danger!? Jackalope?; 2x Danger!? Tsuchinoko?

The Danger! archetype just happened to synergize very well with Lightsworn, because if you draw a garnet, you can use the Danger! in order to put them to the GY while going pluses. Being able to freely Summon themselves while discarding a card at random, then draw 1. When they discard themself, they have some good Effects too. They also happened to have different Types, so you can go into Curious easier than ever.

You want to prioritize Mothman and Chupacabra because they're Level 4 and try avoiding using a Danger! that you have 2 ofs in your hand, because the chances of discarding themselves are doubled (unless you want their discarded Effect).

2x Destrudo the Lost Dragon Frisson; 2x Plaguespreader Zombie; 1x Jet Synchron

These are the Tuners that can Special Themselves from GY. Destrudo pretty much Special almost for Free by paying half your LP, Plague by returning a card from hand to topdeck, and Jet by sending a card from hand to GY. Destrudo and Jet are once per turn while Plague isn't. Jet will be your main target for Halqifibrax, and if you already milled Jet, Summon Plague instead. You can make Destrudo Level 4 by targeting Jackalope or Tsuchinoko. I only play 1 Jet because it's searchable with Halqifibrax and only once per turn.

1x Artifact Scythe; 1x Foolish Burial; 1x Performage Trick Clown; 1x Fairy Tail - Snow; 1x Gokipole

I already explained everything with Scythe so I'm gonna skip it. Foolish Burial is just a good card to play in a GY Deck, you shouldn't use the card immediately, Set it first and use it last to send an Important combo piece that you're missing. Trick Clown is basically Wulf but better. Snow is an amazing card that serves as both an Extender and a disruption, just don't overuse its GY Effect since we don't play Grass. Gokipole is a Free +1, it's basically Shaddoll Beast but better because it searches Mothman when sent to the GY.

3x Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring; 3x Effect Veiler; 3x Maxx "C"; 2x PSY-Framegear Gamma; 1x PSY-Frame Driver

These are your handtraps. Not much I can say about them, except for the fact that Gamma is a +2. When you Charge, Chaos Space, or E-Tele and got Ash-ed or Maxx "C"-ed on your Danger! Just Click Gamma and boom, your opponent loses a card for no reason and you just got 2 monsters for Free (1 from hand, 1 from Deck), and Gamma just happened to be a Tuner and their combined Levels are 8, which is Chaos Ruler. There's a reason why Gamma is at 2 (at 1 in OCG right now) while other handtraps are unlimited, even though you must play a garnet (Driver) for Gamma.

 

Extra Deck

1x Baronne de Fleur: That one generic Level 10 Synchro that Negates things. You don't usually Synchro into Baronne on your own turn, except for going 2nd. That's because you can just do it during your opponent's turn with Wonder Magician and Scythe. Baronne also have a once per turn pop for some reason. And the 3rd Effect does come up, if you accidentally milled Scythe, don't worry because Baronne can bring Scythe back on Standby Phase (Scythe doesn't need to be popped to Lock your opponent, just Special Summoned). 1x Hot Red Dragon Archfiend Abyss: Since you're playing Chaos Ruler and Jet Synchron, why not make this guy? This guy has a unique Negation Effect because it targets. Since you're summoning Baronne on your opponent's turn, Abyss is the Omni-Negate that you want to Summon on your own turn. Sadly it can't Negate hand and/or GY effects (can't be chain blocked though). It has a 2nd Effect, to revive a Tuner from GY when it inflicts damage. 1x Chaos Ruler, the Chaotic Magical Dragon: Very balanced card I guess, mill 4 add 1. AND it revives itself from GY with some little cost that is by banishing 1 LIGHT and 1 DARK from hand or GY. Also, mandatory for Abyss's Synchro material. 1x T.G. Wonder Magician: Halqifibrax target, can pop Scythe, and Quick Synchro into Baronne. 1x Number 38: I'm not saying its full name because that would be 2 colons (:) which is confusing to read. Anyway, good card because it can protect your monsters from battle once per turn by directing the attack into itself. If your opponent doesn't read, good for you. Also it can Negate Spell once per turn. You need to use Levianeer to Summon it because there's no other Level 8 monster in the Deck (Omega is Level 8 but I'm not wasting that for Xyz). 1x Minerva, the Exalted Lightsworn (previously PSY-Framelord Omega): Ok, I didn't take into consideration about going 2nd, that's why I thought Minerva wasn't that good since I'm only playing 5 Lightsworn Main Deck monsters and thought, why not just go Dweller if you have the materials? Turns out Minerva is very good at baiting negation. If your opponent let your Minerva resolves, you have the "potential" to draw 3 cards. Even if they Negate and destroy it, they have to Negate the GY Effect too, or they "might" lose 1-3 cards for no reason. Omega is the one I replaced, because it was the least useful EX monster. 1x Abyss Dweller: Literally the best Rank 4 I can think of. Forget Minerva and Dugares, if you have 2 Level 4s, just make Dweller. Can win you games on its own against certain matchup as it disables your opponent GY Effect for potentially 2 full turns. 1x Curious, the Lightsworn Dominion: Foolish Burial + 3 mills. Actually its not just Foolish Burial because it can send Spell/Trap too. You will most likely mill Plague, or Destrudo, or maybe Snow. Also, it floats into adding any card from GY to hand. 1x Accesscode Talker: The big boy himself, as long as you can spam monsters, Accesscode will always be in your EX. 1x Knightmare Unicorn: It's mandatory at this point to play Unicorn if you play Accesscode, there's no other good generic Link-3. 1x Knightmare Phoenix: I'm genuinely too lazy to write anything about this card. 1x Artifact Dagda: Set Scythe from Deck, that's it. Wait, it has a 2nd Effect? No one told me that! 1x Crystron Halqifibrax: Ok, how many times do I have to talk about this card? Hopefully next Combo Deck won't play Halq so I can finally stop explaining the same Effect over and over again. So basically, Halq Summon a Level 3 or lower Tuner from Deck, "but it cannot activate its effects this turn" and still get abused anyway. It can also Summon a Tuner Synchro from Extra for some reason. If 1 broken Effect is not enough, why not give it another? 1x Linkuriboh: You need Linkuriboh to convert Jet Synchron into 2 monsters for Dagda. It doesn't happen very often in this Deck, but still happen occasionally 1x Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess: Just a monster Negate that you can Summon if you have too many extra monsters that you don't need (I'm just gonna leave Halq blank like that, don't ask why)

Conclusions

First and most importantly, is the Deck consistent? Surely you're playing plenty of garnets, but I gotta say, this Deck is very consistent. All you need is just 2 monsters, including a Tuner and you have Full Combo. And to answer the reason why I don't play Grass, that's because there's not that many GY Effects really in this Deck, so Grass is not really needed. This Deck can play through multiple handtraps due to the number of Extenders it has, the choke point is pretty much Chaos Ruler or Halqifibrax. Unfortunately, this variant of CDL cannot play through Nibiru as good as the other variants can, because you don't turbo out Baronne like usual. For handtraps, we have 11 handtraps which is around 60% chance to open 1 of them on your opening hand. Can this Deck play through Maxx "C"? Bro. Just. Draw. The. Gamma. Jokes aside, yes you can play through Maxx "C". It definitely can't Deck them out, but just Scythe Lock your opponent and their 20+ cards means nothing (If they draw an equalizer or Called By, you're screwed). Just Dweller pass them if you got Maxx "C"-ed. I don't play Called By because I don't have the space for it. Looks like 60-card is just not enough because there's just too many good cards to play. I can't just replace handtraps for it because I'm telling you, you're gonna need those handtraps going 2nd. The weakness of the Deck is... It loses to Control Deck. There's nothing you can do about it, unless you want to play Lightning Storm/Twin Twister which is sure, go ahead. But Combo/Midrange Decks are just more common in the Ladder compared to Control. Also, playing both Danger! and hantraps SUCKS. Sometimes you just have to sacrifice your handtrap for extending and there's nothing that you can do about it. If you have any question about the Deck, or any suggestion to make, feel free to tell me in the comments, I'll try answering them as much as possible. As someone who hates Scythe Lock with PASSION, I have learned something important from this Deck: "If you can't beat them, join them :)" (This is the non-optimized Decklist that I used that got me to Plat 1) 23 Apr 2022: Replaced PSY-Framelord Omega with Minerva, the Exalted Lightsworn

deck_excerpt: Yes, It's possible after some mental gymnastics we got to this moment today.
deck_description: Yeah so after a month of tweaking and experimenting I got this monstrosity of a deck. It has about the consistency of an Exodia deck and is bound to confuse your opponent. This deck can probably play through an ash blossom maybe two and if your royal magical library is negated by impermanence or effect vailer it isn't the end of the world. The strat is this you want to draw out of your deck four level four special summons (this can include royal magical library) Xyz summon an Angle of Misceif and a Zoodiac with 2 of your monsters. Then Rank climb until you get Seven materials attached to your monster. Use Shien's spy on that monster to give it to your opponent. Xyz summon Mischief and use the spell Overlay Capture to raise Mischief to 10 materials and enjoy your opponent's confusion.

deck_excerpt: An updated, more competitive version of my Charmer Control deck I featured back at February. Control the board, then OTK! Expecting your opponent to f
deck_description: An updated, more competitive version of my Charmer Control deck I previously featured back in February. For a more detailed explanation of this deck, click here. This decklist is just so I can do test-hands on my phone so I can practice for locals. The idea is to go first, control the board, then OTK. OTKs are easily enabled by "Awakening of the Possessed" boosting up your monster's attack to ridiculous levels for each attribute on your field. The Adventurer and Dogmatika Engine provide free special summons/attributes for the OTK, as well as interactions that hinder your opponent. Lord of the Heavenly Prison also greatly enhances the deck, since it is a massive free body on board, and searches out any of your important spells like Rite of Aramesia, Spirit Charmers, or Nadir's Servant. Ice Dragon's Prison and Crackdown are the normal traps of choice for this deck, since they eviscerate current meta decks and also provide link material so you can link your opponent's monster away for your Extra Deck charmers. When you're expecting your opponent to force you to go second, you side in the Kaijus and going second cards by replacing the trap cards + Lord of the Heavenly Prison. Kaijus pick apart your opponent's board then the Kaijus are bounced back to your hand by Luna and Dracoback. This deck has surprisingly won me many games online in Yugioh OMEGA and Masterduel vs. competitive decks as they are usually caught off guard by it. This deck is also very consistent and can shrug off many of the negates/interaction present in Yugioh nowadays, since it's a backrow control/beatdown deck. However, this deck relies on you to win the die roll and predict your opponent to force you to go second. If that happens you usually win with these charming spellcasters! Enjoy and GLHF Duelists!

deck_excerpt: A version of my Antimeta Stun deck updated to April 2019 which almost made me win a local tournament!
deck_description: Just a revisited version of my old Antimeta from 2012. At the time, in May 2019, I wanted to go back and play a few games after a 7-year break, therefore I took one of the strongest old decks and adapted to the active banlist (April 2019) and I also achieved the 2nd place in a local tournament! The core idea of the deck is to summon some good troublemakers as Fossil Dyna and/or Rai-Oh whose effects will start blocking the opponent's moves. You want to do everything you can to defend the one which stops your opponent as much as possible and you have plenty of choices to do so. The Doomcaliber is quite predictable, but a nice attacking monster which also creates some troubles. Also the Grand Mole is useful to push back the Synchros from where they come from. The Veiler is for emergencies and the Banisher of the Radiance is good if the opponent uses the graveyard (which is quite common) Cards will go away very quickly from your hand and field since you will activate lots of traps and spells, that's why we have the Morphing Jar for a quick reload (might as well disrupt the opponent's plans) and the Pots of Duality do no interfere with our plans since we do not special summon a lot. The extra deck is not relevant to our purposes except for what we could summon in the very rare occasion we use the Veiler as a tuner or when we activate the Starlight Road. In the side deck we can keep cards based on the meta, but a strong suggestion is King Tiger Wanghu, which might literally ruin the day of an opponent and could easily be swapped in instead of the Banishers or any of the monsters we play according to the deck we are facing. Please feel free to explore my uploaded decks to find the evolution of my favourite one through the years in a way that reflects a little the story of the game itself! Leave your comments and like if I brought you back some sweet memories!

The best strategy I've found is using Revealer's effect to first turn Gungnir or Trishula zero, if you have Speaker in hand to special summon. you can also stall by simply summoning defender. It's probably not the best deck and could use some work but this is so far better than my first draft. I feel I need to replace Dance Princess but since I can't bring myself to doing so she shall remain for now.  If you wanted to go for a more stall deck, running Dai Sojo and Secret Guards is a great idea with Defender. It also wouldn't allow me to add Maxx "C" to the side deck so that's what's currently missing. Glad my Ice Barriers got some love at some point after I stopped playing and I can now potentially make my IRL deck better, if I get back into playing! I don't know link monsters well enough yet to know what can be used but there is room to shorten your Extra deck, I'd suggest keeping 2 Gungnir though since he is the easiest to summon, with the best effect.

deck_excerpt: Simple Needlefiber deck for beginners, ends on Accesscode+extenders
deck_description: Easy deck I made for my friend who's very new to the game, thought I'd share for anyone who's got a friend who's new or for any inexperienced players looking to get used to link summoning or simple needlefiber combos.     Basic combo is as follows: 1) Summon needlefiber using diva, junk converter, unknown synchron + normal summon, goblindbergh, etc.  2) Search plaguespreader zombie with needlefiber  3) Link summon decode talker  4) Plaguespreader effect from grave to special summon  5) Accesscode talker  6) Set traps if applicable and pass  The combo is easy enough for a newbie to pick up imo and ends on a link 4 which I think is satisfying enough. You could use a different link 4 here, and you could also edit the combo a little bit to include some synchro summoning if you wanted.  p.s. auroradon and deskbot are in the side deck in case my boy is feeling particularly adventurous one day :)

deck_excerpt: A verdadeira joia do Deck é a sua Magia que invoca qualquer Dragão nível 7 ou 8 diretamente do Cemitério, sem restrições, e pode ser usada depois para
deck_description: Este Deck de 40 cartas celebra a estratégia pioneira de dragões de alto nível criada por Seto Kaiba no Yu-Gi-Oh da TV. Inclui novos Dragões de alto nível que banem cartas do oponente quando Invocados e ganham mais Pontos de Ataque para cada carta que eles banem. Também estão incluídos novos monstros devotos dos Dragões – guerreiros de baixo nível fáceis de invocar que ajudam a colocar seus Dragões de alto nível em jogo rapidamente. A melhor parte é que esses Guerreiros trabalham com quaisquer dragões de alto nível, incluindo Dragões de outros Decks e boosters. A verdadeira joia do Deck é a sua Magia que invoca qualquer Dragão nível 7 ou 8 diretamente do Cemitério, sem restrições, e pode ser usada depois para proteger seus Dragões de serem destruídos, sem desvantagens ou limitações. Uma carta fundamental para um Deck do Dragão!

Here is my Branded Shaddoll decklist I hope you like it

yes i admit that some others archetype work even better for ice barrier's synchro than its own but you can build the hybrid way of using generals for field defense before the boss comes out (cant say dragon cuz brionac is sea-serpent)  anywho, here's my deck profile

deck_excerpt: Do you remember Lightsworn Shaddoll? Yeah it's bascially that except it has waifus and can fusion summon from the gy.
deck_description: This deck is excatly what you expect, you ns a Tearalament, mill some cards, activate some gy effects, fusion summon a bunch of times and end on winda + some other stuff.  Here is the stuff which makes it different to shaddoll invoked:  It can make Winda in the opponents turn without using schism. How? Simple you use Haufenis to summon herself and mill 3 cards or If you went first end made your board with Kitkalos and Salic, you negate an opponents monster eff with salic and send Kitkalos to the gy to mill 5 cards. Then If you milled an Shaddoll and a Tearalament you can use those to summon Winda. It sounds pretty rng based at first, but in the end it comes up more often than you would expect, especially if you used Kitkalos to mill 5.  It has access to Bahamut Shark, so it can make Toadally Awesome! The basic combo would be Rainoheart + any other Tearalament: Ns Rainoheart, Send a Tearalament monster to the gy, fusion summon Kitkalos, eff Kitkalos to Send Rainoheart, eff Kitkalos to ss Rainoheart, Overlay both Rainohearts for Bahamut Shark while also getting a mill 5 off of Kitkalos.  You always have some fuel for your schism, since you mill your entire deck in a couple of turns.  And the last point is that you basically have infinite Windas since you can just use a tearlament to recycle the Winda, so 2 Windas are a infinite loop (Hey That's the dante/cir loop, but in better). Btw I play 3 Windas, just because.. ehm... actaully idk it either. You can probably replace it with something else like a 2nd Gravity Controller, Abyss Dweller or a link monster like Underworld Godess or Knigmare Unicorn.     Is it better than Shaddoll Invoked and Shaddoll Invoked Dogmatika?  Maybe, only time will tell, but there's definetley some potential here. It could definetley be better depending on the support we will get in Darkwing Blast, I personally think that it's either a Link-1 or another Fusion. And no matter what it is, if it's on the same level as the scareclaw link-1 then it could definetley be a meta contender.     So yeah that's for the Shaddoll varient, next up is tearalaments despia/branded, Oh man that's gonna be fun..., until then!

deck_name: Despia Darklord Deck ft. VFD - Master Duel (Updated)
deck_description: Despia Darklords for Master Duel, with a couple twists.  Firstly, this decklist has a lot less Darklords than usual as you might've seen. In place of those we're running pretty generic Fairies that can get us into cards other than Fusions and pretty easily swarm the field.  Getting VFD out is a 1-card combo using Diviner of the Herald. Summon Diviner, and send Trias Hierarchia with her effect. Use Hierarchia in the grave, and tribute Diviner to summon her. Diviner will proc, use her effect to summon Valkyrie Sechste. Sechste will proc, use her to summon Sigrun. Then just XYZ Sigrun and Hierarchia into VFD. You can use any other monsters you have after this too, such as an Aluber to grab Theater and use him and Sechste for Quaeritis, or using any other effect combination you have in hand. Archlord Kristya is a floodgate than can be summoned by First Darklords effect should you get the opportunity to, for example by sending it with Diviner or Foolish Burial.  Everything else is relatively the same as a normal Despia Darklord deck. Draglubion + Numeron Dragon OTK combo, Starving Venom as a generic fusion, Condemned in case you actually want to summon Morningstar, and Apollousa as a generic negate (who, fun fact, is protected by First Darklord as it's a Fairy monster).

deck_excerpt: The goal is to activate Huge Revolution, discarding your opponent's entire hand and destroying everything on their field.
deck_description: Released in 2005, Huge Revolution was mostly thought of as a joke card or an impossible card to resolve due to the insane activation requirements necessary to pull it off. Over the years however, several cards have been released which unintentionally make it slightly easier to activate.  Ideally, you'd like to succeed in this combo during your first or second turn before your opponent can set up their board of negates. I've included some options in the side deck to help with stalling or going second.  Ideally your turn goes something like this, summon Dark Doriado which you can alternatively achieve through Summoner Monk. Excavate your cards, then activate Enchanting Fitting room which will special summon each of your necessary monsters for Huge Revolution to be activated. Set trap trick or huge revolution. The main issue with Huge Revolution is that it must be activated during YOUR main phase. So all three of your monsters must survive your opponents turn in order for you to activate Huge Revolution on your next turn. In case they don't, Tri-Wight and Monster Reborn are key cards to bring your monsters back after they've been destroyed. If you manage to complete the combo in your first turn, Temple of the Kings will allow you to activate Huge Revolution immediately.     Another way to accomplish this combo is with Rescue Ferret and Saryuja Skull dread. If you have the furry emancipator in your hand and manage to get four monsters on the field to link summon Saryuja, you can special summon Rescue Ferret from your hand and activate its effect to special summon your three key monster cards from your deck. However they will be destroyed during your end phase so make sure you can activate Huge Revolution that turn if you take this route.  Overall, this deck is quite inconsistent and resolving Huge Revolution is still a difficult feat. However the feeling of accomplishment once you do is unlike any other.

deck_excerpt: Locks your opponent out of the extradeck, and has a board with 9 negates. Apollousa, Savage Dragon, Toadally Awesome, Dragite, Baronne De Fleur
deck_description: Uses the same Combo as the video below with some changes: 1) Oyster Meister is replaced with Left-Hand Shark 2) Rare Fish is replaced with Kragen and Zeus 3) I.P.Masq+Avramax is replaced with Apollousa.  -In the first Coelecanth loop, you will summon Left-Hand Shark, Royal Swamp Eel, and 2 fish of different names. Left-Hand Shark and Royal Swamp Eel will bring back Coelecanth, but this time you will also use Dagda, Monoceros, and 2 Fish to Link summon a 3200 atk Apollousa.  -In the second Coelecanth loop, you will summon 2 Royal Swamp Eels, 1 lvl 4 fish, and 1 Right-Hand Shark. Royal Swamp Eel+lvl 4 Fish will summon Savage Dragon Left-Hand Shark special summons from the GY and XYZ summons with Right-Hand Shark to make Bahamut Shark Use Bahamut to summon Toadally Awesome, then use Bahamut Shark and Royal Swamp Eel to make Crystron Halqifibrax(Needlefiber) Crystron Halqifibrax summons a lvl 1 tuner from the deck, then Synchro summon Dragite using Coelecanth+lvl 1 tuner.  End Board: Apollousa, Savage Dragon, Toadally Awesome, Dragite, Crystron Halqifibrax.  On your opponents turn use Crystron Halqifibrax to do the WonderMagician+Scythe Lock to Lock your opponent out of the extradeck, and then summon Baronne De Fleur.

Haven't seen any Blue-Eyes decks on duel links that are actually any good these days, so i made one myself. Only casual, or I would've Main-decked some Imperms and some Veilers. Otherwise, it's just standard Blue-Eyes.

This is an older Blue-Eyes deck, mainly building off of the structure deck.  This deck is designed more for casual play with the ability to get Blue-Eyes Shining Dragon on the field.  If you were to side in BLS, the ritual spell, a poly, and DMK you could get that out too.  This deck is not competitive.

deck_excerpt: Found a similar deck a few years ago, and I've upgraded and changed a few things around based on my IRL collection.
deck_description: This deck is a two-part deck.  Both parts can work independently of each other or together.  You want to start with either Venus or a combo of dragonfly+hornet/gigamantis/ladybug.  If you start with venus, get 3 shineballs on the field in Def and XYZ into gantatsu.  Ideally with the inzektors, you want gigamantis attatched to dragonfly to give it some beatstick protection.  Gorz, torrential tribute, mirror force, etc. are generic support/defensive cards to use.  If you're able to use Tualatin against an opponent, you can lock them down.  Same with archlord Krystia.  Hyperion and BLS both are good at clearing the field.  I've recently added Trishula as the inzectors are very good at level manipulation, combined with Venus's ability to get multiple low-level monsters on the field.  Wish I would have thought of this years ago.

deck_excerpt: The Tearalaments deck, using their initial reveal wave of support
deck_description: The goal of this deck is to establish several interruptions while recycling cards in your Graveyard to make powerful Fusion boss monsters. Thanks to Extra-Deck consistency tools like Tearalaments Kitkalos, the deck is quite consistent and capable of easily cycling through a variety of different Fusions to suit your needs. Ideally you will go first, summon Kitkalos, search out Tearalaments Salic and summon some number of Tearalaments and other Fusion monsters, but thanks to plentiful room for tech cards, handtraps and the archetypal handtrap of Tearalaments Haufenis, the deck is reasonably competent when going second. My ratios and reasoning are as follows: Main Deck: 3x Tearalaments Rainoheart - the main character of the deck and your most reliable starter. On summon he mills any Tearalaments monster to instantly make a fusion, usually Kitkalos, and he can be sent from the hand or deck off of a variety of cards to trigger his effect to special summon from the GY. Absolutely mandatory at 3, as he is the best normal summon and discard fodder in the deck, and most of the time you will either want to open him or search him out using Kitkalos or the Field Spell. 3x Tearalaments Shaylen - the archetypal extender. Shaylen is fantastic as she can be used to pitch any cloggy monsters in hand to trigger their effects while also milling 3 more cards from your deck, which will typically enable a fusion play. As this deck has a good amount of RNG involved in its plays, you want as many Tearalaments names as possible in the deck to ensure that Fusing is always available, so as of now I would argue every Tearalaments Monster should be played at 3. 3x Tearalaments Haufenis - an archetypal handtrap/extender. Haufenis relies on your opponent to trigger her hand effect, but in exchange enables some nasty Fusion combos on your opponents turn, including on turn 1 when you're going second. Depending on the cards you mill off of her, you can make a variety of powerful interruptions on your opponents turn such as Millennium-Eyes Restrict (if King of the Swamp is milled- more on this later), Predaplant Dragostapelia (after making Kitkalos and using her to mill a different Tearalaments monster), and even El Shaddoll Winda (if Shaddoll Beast is milled). 3x Tearalaments Mieru- arguably the worst of the bunch as she can clash with Rainoheart for your normal summon, Mieru gives you an additional option for milling cards to continue your combos and set up your GY. A common play is to summon her off of the effect of Kitkalos to mill 8 cards from your deck and almost always enable 1-2 Fusions. 3x King of the Swamp- King of the Swamp fulfills multiple roles in this deck, allowing you to search out Polymerization to allow for alternative methods of Fusing without relying on milling Tearalaments and also can serve as any specifically-named fusion material. King of the Swamp allows you to make far more than the otherwise limited pool of Fusions Tearalaments would be capable of making, most notably cards like Millennium-Eyes Restrict (who requires Relinquished as material) and Lubellion the Searing Dragon (who requires Fallen of Albaz as material). King of the Swamp is also an Aqua-type Monster, meaning it can serve as one of the generic materials for Kaleidoheart and Kitkalos, and it can also be used in place of Rainoheart in order to make Kaleidoheart. As you will be Fusing using materials in your GY, discarding it to search Polymerization essentially gives you free GY setup while searching you a potential extender. While you could theoretically play less than 3, the card gives you enough value and versatility that I currently max out on it. 2x Shaddoll Beast- a Shaddoll played to enable summons of El Shaddoll Winda. You could play any of the Shaddolls for this purpose, but I've found that Beast is generally the best as it gives you a Draw when sent off any of your card effects, such as any mill effect or if sent from the hand for Shaylen. I currently play 2 to ensure I see it frequently enough without bricking on them, but you could easily run more/less Shaddoll names by preference. 3x Gameciel, the Sea Turtle Kaiju / Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring / Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit / Infinite Impermanence- the going-second cards. These 12 flex spots could be anything you feel like playing to suit your particular meta, but I like these particular handtraps due to their versatility. I play 3x Gameciel as it is not only a powerful removal option (and this is somewhat lacking in non-targeting removal effects), but also because its Aqua typing allows it to be used as Fusion material for the Tearalaments Fusions if milled. 3x Perlayno, the Primal Parallel Ruined Realm / 1x Terraforming- the Field Spell(s). Perlayno searches for any Tearalaments Monster on activation, allowing more access to your combo pieces. Furthermore, Perlayno can pop a card on either field whenever you use one of your Tearalaments' Fusion effects (once per turn), allowing you to break boards, have an additional interaction when Fusing on your opponent's turn, and trigger your cards that activate upon being sent to the GY (such as Kitkalos' effect to mill 5). I max out on the Field Spell as it isn't currently searchable and can grab any Tearalaments Monster you want, but you could drop Terraforming if you find it cloggy. 2x Polymerization / 1x Instant Fusion- Polymerization is here as a free card off of King of the Swamp and to enable alternative routes for Fusion Summoning, while Instant Fusion can be used to instantly make Kitkalos, who in turn searches for any Tearalaments card in your deck. Instant Fusion can also be used to make Time Wizard of Tomorrow to break boards, or Millennium-Eyes Restrict to counter some common handtraps and interactions. You could cut these cards if you find yourself wanting more room, but I've found this to be a comfortable ratio. 3x Tearalaments Salic- Salic serves as a reliable interruption, a consistency enabler and a method of Fusing during your opponent's turn. If milled or sent by any effect it searches for any Tearalaments monster, and utilizing the on-field negation effect allows you to trigger any of your Tearalaments effects at will. I run 3 as you want to both have one copy in hand and at least one to mill for the searching effect. 1x Tearalaments Metanoise- Metanoise gives you a Book of Moon-like interruption while also milling a Tearalaments monster in the process, allowing you an additional method of Fusing as a quick-effect. However, the GY effect of Metanoise is surprisingly niche as you'll rarely end up in a position with monsters to add back from your GY to your hand as they all shuffle themselves back into your deck when Fusing. As a result, I only run the 1 copy as it is very searchable and you'd rather not hit this with your mills early-on, but you could easily play more copies. Extra Deck: 3x Tearalaments Kitkalos- the main fusion of the deck, Kitkalos allows you to have a high degree of consistency while enabling large chains of effects. She is easily summoned, giving you the ability to search or send any of your Tearalaments cards at will from almost any position. Most commonly, you'll use Kitkalos' effect on herself to summon a Tearalaments Monster from hand/GY while triggering her effect to mill 5. While she can technically be recycled infinitely, I run 3 copies to ensure that I always have access to Kitkalos even if one gets banished or if you play a bit fast and loose with your Fusing, but you could just as easily run 2 copies if you find yourself wanting more room. 2x Tearalaments Kaleidoheart- the main boss of the deck. Kaleidoheart is a quick-effect shuffle into deck on summon and whenever an Aqua Monster is sent to the GY by card effect, allowing you to easily spin cards on either player's turn. He also can special summon himself from the GY for free whenever he is sent there by a card effect, and mills a Tearalaments card in the process. This frequently comes in handy both for making him difficult to out and also allowing him to serve as an extender by milling a Tearalaments Monster for their Fusion effects, or by milling Salic/Metanoise for their GY effects. I run 2 copies as he is the biggest monster you can summon off of Tearalaments Monsters in order to push for damage, as well as to have one as a backup in case the first is banished, but you can technically recycle him off of the reborn effect of Kitkalos and could thus get away with only playing 1 if you so desire. 2x Predaplant Dragostapelia- one of your main forms of interaction, Dragostapelia can be made with surprising ease in this deck and gives you access to a simple negation effect on a soft once-per-turn. I play 2 as you can frequently make 2, and one can be recycled by fusing into a new copy using the one in your GY. Furthermore, the materials of Dragostapelia allow you to recycle any of your other Fusions, giving Tearalaments a strong grind game. 1x Lubellion the Searing Dragon- made using King of the Swamp as material, Lubellion allows you to put an additional body on the field while Fusing, or to recycle Monsters from your GY/Banished zone. Lubellion also satisfies the requirement to use the effect of Mirrorjade the Iceblade Dragon. 1x Mirrorjade the Iceblade Dragon- a strong non-targeting quick-effect banish that can be made using King of the Swamp and any Extra Deck monster, with an additional boardwipe effect if it gets removed. Mirrorjade can be a bit difficult to summon reliably due to its awkward material requirements, but its effects are certainly strong enough to make up for it. 1x El Shaddoll Winda- made using a milled Shaddoll Beast, Winda gives you a devastating floodgate that can be extremely difficult for some decks to play around/out. Tearalaments play quite nicely around her effect as well, as you rarely need more than one Special Summon per turn after establishing a field and you can easily get rid of her by using her for a Fusion if need be. 1x Time Wizard of Tomorrow- made using King of the Swamp in place of Time Wizard, Time Wizard of Tomorrow is a bit of a niche board clear typically used when trying to power through tough fields or as a last-ditch nuclear option. I don't often make it, and as such could easily be replaced by anything else should you desire to do so. 1x Millennium-Eyes Restrict- made using King of the Swamp in place of Relinquished, Millennium-Eyes Restrict allows you to counter all manner of handtraps and disruptions while removing cards from your opponent's field/GY. As Millennium-Eyes Restrict isn't a hard once-per-turn, you could easily play and potentially summon more than 1 should you choose to run more. 1x Number 39: Utopia / 1x Number S39: Utopia the Lightning- I run Utopia the Lightning as an Extra Deck out to get rid of things this deck otherwise has a hard time clearing. Untargetable/indestructible Monsters like Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon and unaffected Monsters like The Arrival Cyberse @Ignister can be a problem for this deck as nearly everything in this deck either targets or destroys, but luckily there are no restrictions anywhere on your effects that prevent you from running toolbox monsters in your Extra Deck to deal with said problems. While this is the option I currently run due to its low material investment, you could also play other removal options such as Borrelsword Dragon, Accesscode Talker (with a Link-3+ in your Extra Deck) or Underworld Goddess of the Closed World, though they can be difficult to summon under fire. 1x Time Thief Redoer- Redoer has an interesting place in this deck, as he is a relatively strong generic Xyz Monster that happens to detach his materials as part of his effect, rather than for cost. This means that Redoer can be used to trigger the effects of the Tearalaments Monsters you use to Summon him, those being the Fusion effect of Shaylen and the revive and subsequent mill effect of Rainoheart, and as a quick-effect no less. The Side Deck in this list is currently comprised of some other options you could run. -Mare of the Shore is a decent normal summon who fulfills the same role as Rainoheart while also being an Aqua Monster for your Tearalaments Fusions. -Invoked Caliga is a powerful floodgate Fusion you can make using King of the Swamp in place of Aleister the Invoker. -Mudragon of the Swamp can technically be made in this deck to recycle any non-Aqua Dark Monster and give your Monsters targeting protection. -Knightmare Phoenix, Cerberus and Unicorn are decent generic Link Monsters that can be somewhat easily made, though their roles are covered by various Tearalaments cards anyway. -Super Polymerization can be used to great effect in this deck as it naturally plays a myriad of generic and semi-generic Fusion Monsters, and King of the Swamp can be Set to allow you to Fuse away any monster using Super Polymerization for something like Millennium-Eyes Restrict (who can be made using any Effect Monster). -Tearalaments Crime is the archetypal omni-negate Counter Trap, and while it is indeed a powerful effect, I found it to be too costly to be set up reliably. The GY effect isn't particularly useful either, and with no current in-archetype way of recovering milled spells/traps, I feel it best to ignore Tearalaments Crime for now. -Foolish Burial Goods can be used to send Tearalaments Salic/Metanoise to trigger their GY effects, allowing you to search or recover a Tearalaments Monster at will. However, I found it to be somewhat redundant as the deck already has many ways of doing this, not to mention that Foolish Burial Goods can be bricky and does nothing for you if milled. I would play at most 1-2 copies if you do decide to play it. -Foolish Burial falls into the many of the same problems as Foolish Burial Goods. It can potentially allow you to extend and mill a Tearalaments Monster to trigger their effects, but it felt redundant and unncesessary to me. -Reinforcement of the Army can be used to search Rainoheart as he happens to be a Warrior Type Monster, but I generally felt that the deck has enough ways of getting to him without it.
A
YGO cube LOB 2

deck_excerpt: Stall, burn, attack, and remove. Progression series deck 11
deck_description: Ancient Sanctuary added several cards which improve the stalling and burn strategy, including the Wall of Revealing Light, Level Limit Area B, Draining Shield, and especially Solar Flare Dragon (not all of these are in this deck). This deck aimed at being something of a hybrid strategy where fast-paced powerful attacks could be used or long-term burn damage can win the game. This deck is unoptimized, so some unnecessary and useless cards are included which could provide a benefit with some tweaking or removed for increased consistency.  11th deck made in a progression series after drawing 48 of every set through Ancient Sanctuary, but using post-errata cards and the April 2004 ban list.

deck_excerpt: Evil Twins were moderately expensive, so let's change that.
deck_description: Ideally you want to open hand a twin/sunny snitch and home/secret password, That hand should happen like, summon twin, special the other twin. link into Dagda. Activate home, chain Dagda; set scythe, resolve home with any twin, red preferably. Link off the twin and dagda into trouble sunny trouble sunny can split back into the 2 evil twins and pop scythe on the opponent's turn. The twin+ extender play should look like summon twin+eff, summon extender, go into evil twin, ss the other from grave (should have an evil twin and live twin of the same color, and then ss the other color. Link them off + 1 opponent monster for goddess. Otherwise I would recommend just normaling a twin, linking into anaconda, and going into dpe and getting the draw 2 in quickly. The idea is to thin out the deck while at the very least, make a solid play. Also on your following turn, you can clear your monsters with dpe so you can get more twin plays through, I tried to fit the adventure token engine in here, but I feel the hand traps will be more useful. The hand trap line up is flexible, but I highly recommend gamma as it can be a really solid combo extender if you get ash'd early

So I created this deck to see the real potential of blue-eyes. This build is mostly about summon from the extra deck. This deck will be bricky as well. Main Ratio is 43 Monsters: 26   Spells: 17
    Combos: Sage & Melody | any stone & world legacy | any monster, One for one & World legacy | Sage, Melody & Nebula | Sage, Melody & world legacy | One for one, World legacy & dragon shrine| Alternative, Nebula, Spiral
  + OR + + + ++ ++ ++ ++       My card choices:
 
The reason why one for one is here is due to since we are playing lots brick we can discard them to summon out our lvl 1 tuners really easily to make needlefiber and also if you have any extenders like the legacy or reborn they can help you extend the combo even further. The reason why I only play 2 return of the dragons lord because the third one really never comes up for me during my play testing. The reason why I play dragon shrine is because of its secondary effect for example: sending blue-eyes+ stone of legend or either  blue-eyes+ wyvern. The reason why I play the eclipse wyvern and RedMD(Red-Eyes Darkness Metal Dragon) is because your able to to send it off with the dragon shrine and with the galaxy eyes dark matter dragon. The main banish dragon monster off of Wyvern is the RedMD(Red-Eyes Darkness Metal Dragon). If you have like an extender like pisty you uses its effect to sp the redmd from the banish pile or having chaos dragon levianner in hand you can be able to banish the wyvern and any kind monster like the guardragons. If your that type of person thats like a pure 40 deck. I would cut off RedMD,Wyvern,Dragon Shrine. And everything would be the same still.

deck_excerpt: A toolbox E. Heroes deck focused on generating hand advantage and summoning a variety of Extra Deck monsters to break through opposing boards for an O
deck_description: Mostly pure Elemental Heroes focused deck. Aim to go second, hopefully opening with a hand trap or two to disrupt the worst of your opponent's setup, then go for an OTK on your turn. The monster effects of the combination of Liquid Soldier, Shadow Mist, Blazeman, and Stratos let you summon a variety of fusion monsters while still maintaining hand advantage. The deck provides a solid toolbox for getting around most forms of protection. Captain Gold can be discarded by its own effect, providing material for Miracle Fusion, and Skyscraper is either an easy discard candidate itself (for something like Liquid Soldier's draw effect) or can allow you to win combat if you're locked out of the Extra Deck. The best choices for Shadow Mist's search are either Stratos, or Honest Neos. Stratos is best for when you fuse Shadow Mist and Liquid Soldier together, structure the chain so that you search Stratos first, then discard Stratos for Liquid Soldier's effect. Then, you can either use Stratos to summon E. Hero Tornado with Miracle Fusion, or special summon it with Liquid Soldier on a later turn to destroy at least one spell/trap on the opponent's field and then follow up with a Rank 4 Xyz or a Link-2 as an extending play. Remember that the hand traps like Ash Blossom, Ghost Mourner, and Effect Veiler can also be used as fusion materials in a pinch as well.  If you have to go first, or you're unable to OTK this turn, the deck has just a few options for closers. Masked Hero Dark Law shuts down many meta strategies by itself. A combination of Absolute Zero plus a set Mask Change allows you to activate a one-sided board wipe at any time, and is generally easier to setup than transforming Honor Ark into Zeus for a similar effect. Rivalry of Warlords is also a useful stun tool since a majority of the Deck are Warrior type monsters.  The Side Deck contains two alternative strategies. One is a Vision Hero package that allows for more swarming ability for maintaining card advantage on the field. You can substitute in the extra Rank 4 Xyz monsters for additional removal tools. The other strategy is a discount Kaiju strategy revolving around Super Polymerization to remove threats from your opponent's field when they are capable of putting up multiple layers of protection for their boss monsters. Adjust the Side Deck to fit your target meta. The Main Deck is already balanced around the Master Duel meta and performs well up into Gold Rank.  Consider substituting out Blazeman and the regular Polymerizations for the Vision Hero package (replace one Emergency Call with Reinforcement of the Army), and substitute out some of the fusion monsters in the Extra Deck for more generic Xyz and Link monsters. This will reduce the likelihood of bricking on a handful of fusion spells, and provide even more flexibility against other stun or control decks.

deck_name: Altergeist, How to say No by My brother
deck_excerpt: Altergeist, How to say No. This deck is only for your amusement.
deck_description:
This deck was the first attempt to play in the local near home with Altergeists, also known as “NO!!”. First off, my knowledge in this archetype is a lot lower than my knowledge of infernoid, so  feel free to give me any advice. The new “altergeist card” that won about one game by itself was Skill Drain. At first, I thought that card was convoluted to use alongside a deck that is highly dependent on the monster's effect. However with Altergeist Protocol, my boys…girls…. altergeists things cannot  have their effects negates. That's super neat to shut down my opponent’s board. Second thing to talk about is the use of three Altergeist Pookuery. Going First, I loved the fact that this card was glued on every opening hand, because I was guaranteed to make a good  board. However, going second this card just bricked me a lot. In the end, I can see that using three was beneficial because of siding these cards off for my techs on the side deck.  Now every other card is just the same strategy that everyone hates about altergeist: Say No to everything that the opponent does.  The Highlights that I am going to do is:
  • “The Warning Point”, This trap took a lot of my opponent off guard, because it shut down effects and cannot be used for anything until the next turn.
  • Using Pot of Extravagance instead of Pot of Prosperity, Card advantage is everything on this deck, even more than get a combo piece. This card helped me a lot.
  • More Solemn Strike than Solemn Judgment, a lot of monsters that summon themselves by effects. That 's the reason. 
  • Waking the dragon and the “ Trio Parada dura”, just a spice for the second game.
  • Dimensional Barrier is a beautiful card. 
  Finally, I can guarantee that (even though I did not do well in the local tournament), I did not make any friends. This deck is only for your amusement.
