deck_excerpt: Mathmech Tcg Format - Deck explanation before Ocg support
deck_description: Mathmech is a little explored deck but very competent in what it does. He makes the end board I respect most in current yugioh: distributed interactions whether field monster effect, spell/trap and hand traps. This type of combo is much better than decks that go to a table full of negates and lose to blind second cards. That's why I consider this a deck with immense potential for excellence in distributing interactions and this will be clear to everyone when Mathmech Circular support is released, which in my initial tests solves all of the deck's shortcomings. I tested Mathmech a lot in the current Tcg format and the deck performed very well, even with the powercreep of Token and DPE engines. This is due to a lot to understand that even with a lot of 1 Card Combo absurdities in the format the use of a lot of hand trap is still the best way to face everything unfair in the game, even if it doesn't completely stop the opponent it sure makes your end board breakable. With that in mind, I'll show you what I learned about the Mathmech archetype: - Like every Cyberse deck it has a tight Extra Deck but it makes one of the best end boards among Cyberse decks in terms of interactions since Primathmech Laplacian is an absurd card that is guaranteed at least -3 to the opponent since when it enters field it has an effect similar to Trishula, Dragon of the Ice Barrier sending a card from the hand, a monster and a spell/trap to the GY in addition to the Omni Negate that gains from the Mathmech Diameter to deal with another card. - And if the hand is very good, you will have the interaction of I:P Masquerena who turns Knightmare Unicorn to deal with another opponent's card, not to mention the interactions in the form of hand traps and the OTK facility of Mathmech. - The deck ceiling is not very high so you have to make the most of every interaction you do which requires a lot of training and knowledge of competitive matchups. //////////////////////////////////////////////// //////////////////////////Combos: So as you can see your turn 1 has the objective of setting up Superfactorial by making Primathmech Laplacian on the opponent's turn using Mathmech Diameter as material to have an Omni Negate as well. For this you use an engine that became popular recently in the so-called "Eldlich Cyberse" but which has always been used in Mathmech: Link Disciple + Link Devotee. Here you use this engine exclusively to access combos involving Cyberse Wicckid which is a card that is only missing by "Mathmech" in the name because it connects several parts of the engine by adding one of its 3 Tuners from the deck to the hand: Mathmech Diameter, Mathmech Nabla or Mathmech Sigma. And to complement the archetype we have two great generic Cyberse support options in the Main Deck: Balancer Lord and Parallel eXceed. These cards make the deck's consistency much better as they increase the amount of 2 combo cards possible and even help when you need to build a field going second while dealing with opponent interactions. Finally, I demonstrate this whole theory below: /////////////////////////////////////////////// Combo: Balancer Lord + Diameter NS Balancer Lord and eff pay1000LP and Link Disciple NS Diameter and eff Reborn Balancer Lord and RANK-4 Alembertian and eff Add Superfactorial *Alembertian eff tribute itself Reborn Diameter and Link Devotee and Mandatory eff *(if you have any extenders in your hand like Subtraction/Addition you don't need to tax the Alembertian and he stays on the field as a negate of Nibiru if the opponent has it) Disciple eff tribute Devotee filter Hand adn Devotee eff create 2 Tokens LINK-2 Wicckid and LINK-1 Linguriboh and Wicckid eff banish Balancer Lord Add Nabla Balancer Lord eff Special Nabla and Nabla eff tribute Linguriboh SS Sigma from Deck LINK-2 I:P Masquerena and Set Superfactorial Gamestate: Wickid + I:P Masquerena + Superfactorial /in GY: Diameter + Nabla + Sigma /////////////////////////////////////////////// Combo: Sigma + Subtraction/Addition Sigma eff SS from Hand and Subtraction/Addition eff SS from Hand Link Disciple and Link Devotee and Mandatory eff and Disciple eff tribute Devotee filter Hand adn Devotee eff create 2 Tokens LINK-2 Wicckid and LINK-1 Linguriboh and Wicckid eff banish Devotee Add Nabla NS Nabla and eff tribute Linguriboh SS Diameter from Deck RANK-4 Alembertian and eff Add Superfactorial Gamestate: Wicckid + Alembertian + Superfactorial /in GY: Diameter + Nabla + Subtraction/Addition /////////////////////////////////////////////// Combo: Subtraction + Parallel eXceed (basically any Normal Summon from the deck + eXceed) NS Subtraction and Link Disciple and eXceed eff Link Devotee and Mandatory eff and Disciple eff tribute Devotee filter hand and Devotee eff create 2 Tokens LINK-2 Splash Mage and eff Reborn Subtraction and LINK-2 Wicckid RANK-4 Alembertian and eff cl1 Add Superfactorial and Wicckid eff cl2 Add Nabla and Alembertian eff tribute itself SS Nabla and eff tribute SS Diameter from Deck and LINK-1 Linguriboh and Set Superfactorial Gamestate: Wicckid + Linguriboh + Superfactorial /in GY: Diameter + Nabla + Subtraction ///////////////////////////////////////////////// Combo: Balancer Lord + Sigma (basically any other Mathmech Monster other than Diameter + Balancer Lord) NS Balancer Lord and eff pay1000LP and NS Sigma Link Disciple and Link Devotee and Mandatory eff and Disciple eff tribute Devotee filter Hand adn Devotee eff create 2 Tokens LINK-2 Wicckid and LINK-1 Linguriboh and Wicckid eff banish Balancer Lord Add Nabla Balancer Lord eff Special Nabla and Nabla eff tribute Linguriboh SS Diameter from Deck RANK-4 Alembertian and eff Add Superfactorial Gamestate: Wicckid + Alembertian + Superfactorial /in GY: Diameter + Nabla + Sigma ///////////////////////////////////////////////// Put the continuation of the link on the duelingbook website after .com/ replay?id=813757-38220625 Test Hands Before Support Mathmech TCG Apr22 - In general you will always be able to setup Wicckid + Superfactorial but sometimes you won't have 3 Mathmech Monsters in the GY for Superfactorial because the hand didn't come out good, but otherwise the test hands presented help you a lot to understand how to use Mathmech. /////////////////////////////////////////////////Technoplay: Mathmech Diameter omni negate allows you to be guaranteed access to Superfactorial when using Alembertian eff because you negate the Hand Trap he chained to his effect. That's why you always try to make Alembertian on your 1st turn using Diameter as material. And on the opponent's turn the Diameter omni negate given to the Laplacian has to be used with caution given the hand traps you have in your hand, sometimes you can spare the hand trap like Ash Blossom if it is clear that negating with Laplacian the opponent already there will be no more ways to continue playing. In the case of starting with a Superfactorial draw, many of the combos can be done in order to guarantee having 3 Mathmech Monster in the GY including the Diameter over 5 summons, avoiding instantly finding yourself in a bad position in the game if you take Nibiru. For this Mathmech Nabla is essential to access the third name of Mathmech in the first summons. Even if you take Called By The Grave or any other card that takes one of the 3 targets from the GY's with Superfactorial eff, you can Summon the other 2 Mathmech Monsters and RANK-4 Alembertian in place of Laplacian. Nibiru, the Primal Being is one of the best hand traps against this deck because currently the hands played around it require 3-card combos. In other cases you are very dependent on the search effect of Cyberse Wicckid passing to continue your plays which makes the deck not very resilient to common hand traps of the format. But I say that for sure these shortcomings will put an end to Mathmech Circular in the game. Forbidden Droplet is your biggest blind second card nightmare when playing Mathmech so in cases of passing with Superfactorial and I:P Masquerena interaction always use I:P Masquerena interaction first even if you have to use Wicckid to make Knightmare Unicorn and miss its Follow Up. All Special Summoned Main Deck Mathmech Monsters have restrictions - Mathmech Addition, Mathmech Subtraction, Mathmech Sigma: - Everyone restricts you from Special Summoning Cyberse monsters from the Extra Deck. - Mathmech Sigma will be banned when leaving the field unless used as an Xyz Material. - Addition and Subtraction can't attack for the rest of the turn and that's why I always Special Summon them in Defense Position as they won't be able to attack anyway. - Mathmech Addition and Mathmech Subtraction are even better going second as they can target opponent's monsters without you having to spend your Normal Summon early. And there's still the detail that the monster they target doesn't need to lose or gain 1000atk for them to be Special Summoned. Additional Effects You Should Consider: Mathmech Nabla allows a monster made in the Extra Monster Zone to attack Monsters twice during the Battle Phase. Mathmech Multiplication doubles the atk of a monster you control in the Extra Monster Zone which synergizes very well with Geomathmech Final Sigma for inflicting double battle damage on the opponent so you pretty much OTK attack any opponent's monster that has 2k atk or less. which is easy since Subtraction can decrease ATK by 1000. And finally, we have the detail that Mathmech Sigma can be used as a non-tuner for a Synchro Summon of Mathmech monsters. Link Devotee has a Mandatory effect that is not once per turn when it is Link Summoned from you lock in doing only LINK-2 or less. I use two Link Devotees in this format because the Token engine made Ghost Ogre popular again which means if I'm facing a player who knows how to correctly use Ghost Ogre against Mathmech he will use the mandatory Link Devotee effect then the second copy is needed to allow you to combo Link Disciple if you take Ghost Ogre. Against trap decks, don't think twice about starting your turn by doing Linguriboh in scare to avoid losing to floodgates. Cyberse Wicckid is the only way to follow up on Mathmech's deck because even on the opponent's turn you can trigger search eff by Special Summoning a monster in the zone he points to using I:P Masquerena eff or Superfactorial. It protects your monsters from being destroyed by card effects so makes your end board even better against blind second cards like Raigeki. Many times you will make more Link Monsters which at first point of view are unnecessary summons but in the end give you more pops to Accesscode Talker. For example in Link Disciple + 2 Parallel eXceed you can do: Linguriboh then Splash Mage reborn from GY and do I:P Masquerena and do Transcode Talker bringing I:P Masquerena back and finally Accesscode. ///////////////////////////////////////////////Important interactions to know against metagame decks: When you have to take Mirrorjade out of the field with Accesscode without protection from I:P Masquerena or Wicckid then the best thing is to use Accesscode eff banish itself to destroy Mirrorjade just to prevent the opponent from being able to Reborn Accesscode with Dark Charmer. Speaking of Dark Charmer, this card is so good that I almost always banish I:P Masquerena as Wicckid's activation cost when I do Knightmare Unicorn to prevent him from giving Reborn. Chain Superfactorial not on Branded Fusion activation but on Lubellion effect because you take Mirrorjade off the field and already forces it to use the effect of banishing a monster from the field as soon as it enters. Superfactorial vs Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer Unlike cards like Tri-Brigade Revolt, even if you use Superfactorial as cl2 to the opponent's DPE effect, what will happen is to bring the Laplacian to the field and even if it's not in the zone that Wicckid points out, there's no problem because you protect him of destruction with its own continuous effect so you are always guaranteed that its effect when it is Xyz Summoned will activate and take up to two cards from the opponent in this case in addition to having the Diameter Omni Negate to negate the effect of the Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer on the GY. Final Sigma is absurd against Floowandereeze, it only has Continuous Spell Floowandereeze and the Unexplored Winds out or Tribute Summon Nibiru, the Primal Being and if you leave any of the small birds on the field like Floowandereeze & Robina it automatically increases the chance of losing the game with an ATK. Another cool thing about Mathmech versus Floowandereeze is that even with Floowandereeze & Empen on the field you have ways to clear his field thanks to Primathmech Laplacian so always try to see plays of making Laplacian to force his interactions. Make Final Sigma under Skill Drain = Always remember that on the field effects denied Parallel eXceed returns to 2000atk/def and is level 8 so you can for example make Link Disciple and Parallel eXceed eff and use eXceed and Mathmech Sigma/Mathmech Nabla/Mathmech Diameter to make Final Sigma and go to Beat Down and buy time until you have out for Skill Drain not to mention that if Final Sigma leaves the field you add a Mathmech card to your hand as Superfactorial. Another tip for dealing with Skill Drain is to use Subtraction and Addition effects to decrease the ATK of an opponent's monster or increase your monsters ATK and take it out in battle as Golden Lord etc since they are effects that activate in the hand and are not affected by Skill Drain. But of course the only out in monster form for Skill Drain after being activated is Accesscode Talker banishing itself from the field as a cost. Final Sigma vs Skill Drain: If Skill Drain was already activated before Final Sigma entered the field, it comes with the effects negated so it's no use doing it in the Extra Monster Zone, but if Final Sigma was on the field in the Extra Monster Zone before of Skill Drain is activated then it will continue to be Unaffected by Card Effects. ///////////////////////////////////////////////Missplays you must avitate to win games: Analyze if the Combo you are going to make loses to a hand trap because if so it is better to use Pot of Desires at the beginning of the combo to see if the hand becomes more resilient to interactions. Trying to keep Mathmech Sigma in the GY when his combo is weak for an interaction with Wicckid and couldn't do I:P Masquerena which made his end board much worse. You should analyze what to return to the deck after Link Disciple's draw because if it's any monster in the deck that can extend its plays after interactions when your combo is fragile to hand traps if you return the monster to the deck it could mean losing to an Effect Veiler/Ash Blossom in Cyberse Wicckid eff. Do not play around Super Polymerization on your Wicckid + I:P Masquerena End Board when you knew the opponent used that card in the Main Deck. It's better not to have Knightmare Unicorn interaction than to lose almost all of your field to a Starving Venom Fusion Dragon. You can Normal Summon a hand trap to make Transcode Talker. It just cannot Special Summon non-Cyberse on the turn you do it. So if you do Balancer Lord eff Special Summon Ash Blossom you won't be able to Transcode Talker.

deck_excerpt: Plant link combo deck that is capable of summoning Naturia Bamboo Shoot in first turn. Still has plant deck's weakness against hand traps, but is basi
deck_description: The deck has plenty of plant extenders as link/tribute material thanks to sunavalon one card combo and various plants who can special summon themselves. The deck can search plants a lot of times (4 Aromaseraphy Jasmine search + Mardel + Rikka Glamour), so use it to search Naturia Bamboo shoot, either search/summon Naturia Rosewhip, Cactus Bouncer, and other plant extenders.  With Card Advance, you don't even have to save your normal summon for bamboo while guaranteeing you can summon plant monsters from the deck with Pione. Aromage Laurel is an important combo card to trigger jasmine search, so prioritize searching it first if its not in your hand. Laurel and Unexpected Dai is a two-card combo to get you bamboo lock plus 3 monster interruptions (Benghalancer, Regulus, and Bloom). Most optimal endboard of the deck is shown here: https://streamable.com/3zr4iy

deck_excerpt: Hero OTK combo deck that revolves around graveyard effects to bring out fusion and link beat sticks to end your opponents careers (and mental health).
deck_description: If you're looking for a fun combo deck that can compete with top tiers and generate a high damage board of cool monsters in one turn look no further. This deck uses a combination of Stratos and Shadow mist's searching abilities in combination with the Vision HERO summoning engine to consistently build a board of monsters capable of OTKing. There is a bit of a learning curve however, the combos are situational and you need to adapt to your available cards. Expect to get pushed around a little as you learn the strategy and logic of this deck, but once mastered you'll be dunking on opponents in style.  Generally with this deck you want to go second. The deck doesn't have many options to defend itself aside from forbidden droplet and ash blossom, so going second allows you to generate your full field and immediately go for the kill instead of hoping your board survives the opponent's turn. Typically if you do go first the goal is to get Dark law or Plasma on the field as having those cards on the field can really disrupt your opponent, and almost guarantee a win if they can't clear them. This deck does not like extended duels and uses most of its resources in a large wombo combo. Generally speaking if after turn two you haven't done enough damage to cripple their game plan/win, most competent decks will out scale HEROs later into the duel.  Stratos/Shadow mist: Most of your searching power comes from these two cards, Getting their effects off successfully generally allows you to start your major combos. Shadow mist is an excellent target for effects like Vyon, Faris, Increase, and foolish burial, netting you a free hero search. Stratos can be used to clear spell/traps in a pinch.  Faris(Vision engine): Getting Faris to your hand allows you to kickstart your bnb, his discard effect can be used to get cards like malicious and shadow mist out of your hand(where they don't do much) into the graveyard. Then allows you to special summon  itself, and send Increase to your spell/trap zones. Tributing Faris(or a different monster) with Increase allows you to get an extra summon of Vyon who lets you discard from the deck. This one combo gets you two monsters on the field and allows you to discard from your hand and deck which is pretty nice.  Vyon: Has an effect that lets you send a card from the deck to the graveyard, and search for polymerization. Because of the amount of monsters the vision engine usually lets you summon, it's very easy to get Trinity on the field with Vyon.  Malicious: Malicious is another excellent target for cards you want to send to the grave, his effect allows you to special summon himself from the main deck by banishing himself from the grave. A free summon that can be used for links and combos very nicely with cards like fusion destiny, and Xtra HERO Cross Crusader. Worth noting that if you use Malicious to link summon Cross, you can bring him back using Cross' effect then link into Dread Decimator. Giving you a relatively cheap way to bring out one of your ideal OTK beat sticks.  Adusted Gold: Straightforward combo here. Discard Gold to get dark calling, use dark calling to fuse him from the grave with Dynatag or Malicious to get Malicious Edge, a board clearing 3k beat stick that generally ends most duels.  Liquid: Liquid soldier's effect allows you to draw 2 discard 1 if you use him in a fusion summon. Needless to say this is very helpful, and Absolute Zero (who is the typical target to fuse liquid into) can be mask changed into Acid for a full board wipe combo.  Mask Change: Mask change gives you access to some nice utility effects and is one of the more vital spells in the deck. Defensively you can use it to save a hero from being destroyed via card effect by using it to summon a masked hero before it's destroyed. Offensively it can be used during the battle phase on a monster that's already attacked to net you an extra attack thats between 2200-2800 dmg. In addition to that Blast and Acid have some helpful effects like clearing spells/traps and lowering attack points of opponent monsters. Not to mention Dark Law has one of the best effects in the game, neutering decks that rely on the graveyard and banishing cards from your opponents hand. Some decks will FF immediately once they see Dark law on the field, he's that good.

deck_excerpt: Unleash the beast with Gladiator Beasts on a budget! Forget expensive staples/techs and control the battlefield with powerful Gladiator Beast Fusions
deck_description: Unleash the beast with Gladiator Beasts on a budget! The aim of the game is summoning Gladiator Beast Tamer Editor, and there are multiple ways to do this.  [Before talking strategy, I'd like to get this out of the way first: This is by no means an optimal build, missing most pricey staples/techs currently available in the modern TCG. Funny enough, after not having played the TCG for maybe a decade, I had finally gotten around to selling my entire collection (except for my GBs and a few staples for nostalgia's sake) last year, but the successful marketing campaign that is Master Duel (and my success in Platinum Ranked using GBs with their new support) rekindled the heart of the cards in me. However, I was not looking to start throwing large sums of money at the TCG,  Therefore, no single card in the deck is valued above $6, and almost 80% of all cards used are below $2.]  Disclaimer now out of the way, let's talk about Tamer Editor. This fantastic fusion monster, requiring 2 LV5+ GBs, has a *soft* 1/turn effect to summon any GB fusion monster from the ED, allowing you to quickly stack your field with big bodies that can either pop or negate your opponent's cards. The particularly helpful part of this effect is being able to summon Dominitianus and Heraklinos without the need for 3 GBs. In fact, the deck doesn't even run Vespasius or Laquari, the GBs normally needed to summon them, freeing up space in the deck for more cards that add support or consistency to achieving our main goal of summoning Tamer Editor.  You'll normally summon Tamer Editor with Augustus (field) + Augustus/Noxious/Attorix, but Augustus + Attorix is by far the easiest way, Attorix being searchable with Test Panther (2), Tenki (1), Proving Ground (3), and Rejection (3). The Tamer Editor flowchart normally starts with a field consisting of Test Panther and any GB (except for Augustus), and x1 Augustus/Noxious/Attorix in hand, though it can be done without Panther if you draw into Test Tiger.  STEP 1 The many ways to summon Test Panther + 1 GB: - Rescue Cat/Rabbit: Summon Samnite+TestTiger or x2 Andal, link into Test Panther, Panther searches GB Comeback to summon any non-Beast GB from hand or GY (non-Beast because Comeback can only summon a GB of a type not already face-up on your field, and Panther is a Beast, so make sure if you use Samnite that you have a different GB in hand). - Rescue Cat + Rescue Rabbit: SUMMON CAT FIRST, summon Ferrijit with Samnite+TT, Ferrijit summons Rabbit into Andal x2, 1st Andal+Ferrijit summons Test Panther alongside the 2nd Andal. - Andal x2 (inhand): 1st Andal links into Link Spider, Spider summons 2nd Andal from hand, link to Test Panther, search Comeback to revive Andal. - Unexpected Dai + Andal (in hand): Achieves the previous option before even normal summoning, allowing you to normal summon a GB alongside your Panther and save Comeback for a follow-up play, or search GB Charge/WarChariot/United for defense, or search Augustus/Noxious/Attorix if you don't have a LV5+ GB in hand (normally you'll want either Noxious/Attorix, but Augustus in hand can extend plays even further if you have Darius/Equeste/Bestiari in hand). - Mind Control + 1 GB: Steals an opponent's monster to use alongside 1 GB to summon Test Panther, since Panther is a Link2 requiring min. 1 GB. Panther searches Comeback, revives your GB. - Gladiator Rejection + RescueCat/RescueRabbit/UnexpectedDai/TestTiger+1GB: Free summon of an additional GB from deck whose type isn't face-up on your field when resolving when a GB is summoned from deck, and the main deck contains 11 cards that facilitate this alongside Rejection, in additional to GB tag-in/out effects (but the aim is to be able to summon Tamer Editor BEFORE the battle phase whenever possible). - Any 2 GB + Comeback: Summon 1st GB, Comeback summons 2nd GB, link into Panther, searches 2nd Comeback to revive either GB.  STEP 2 Use Panther + 1 GB on field and Augustus/Noxious/Attorix in hand to summon Tamer Editor: - Attorix/Tenki/ProvingGround: Draw or search Atttorix, Panther tags out the GB on field to summon Augustus from deck, summoning Attorix from hand, Attorix sends Augustus/Noxious from deck to GY to gain their LV, fuse Augustus+Attorix into Tamer Editor. - Noxious: Panther tags out the GB on field to summon Augustus from deck, summoning Noxious from hand, Noxious sends Bestiari from deck to GY (for follow-up Gyzarus plays using Darius/GBUnited), fuse Augustus+Noxious into Tamer Editor. - Augustus: Panther tags out the GB on field to summon Augustus from deck, summoning a 2nd Augustus from hand, fuse Augustus+Augustus into Tamer Editor. If you have another GB in hand, you can use the 2nd Augustus to summon it, potentially extending your combo (Darius to revive a GB, Equeste to recover Comeback, Bestiari to pop a S/T and/or fuse into Gyzarus for more pops). - Test Panther: Searches Augustus/Noxious/Attorix if you don't have it in hand by drawing or other means and already have Panther + 1 GB on field without the need to search Comeback.  STEP 3 Use Tamer Editor's effect: - Summon Domitianus: This is almost always your #1 pick. Soft 1/turn monster effect negate+destroy, PLUS you choose your opponent's attack targets on their Battle Phase, a useful effect used to protect your weaker cards like Panther. So many players DON'T READ this part of Domi's effects, leading them to accidentally attacking into your heavy hitters instead. #imagineduelistsactuallyreadingcardeffects - Summon Heraklinos: Can discard 1 to negate+destroy any S/T. Only summon with min. 1 card in hand. Remember that Darius/Equeste can help recycle your discarded GB cards (Remember that Equeste CANNOT recover Proving Ground or Rejection). Great for protecting your monsters from stuff like Raigeki / Lightning Storm or backrow-heavy decks in general. - Summon Gyzarus: A free pop 2 anywhere on the field. Great for dealing with high ATK targets, or pesky backrow.  Congrats! You now likely have a field of Test Panther, Tamer Editor and Domitianus. But why stop there? If you managed to conserve your GB Comeback, Link Tamer Editor and Test Panther into any Link 2 or 3, revive Tamer Editor with Comeback and activate its effect again, summoning either a 2nd Domi for more effect negation, Heraklinos to also gain protection from S/T, or Gyzarus to pop and clear the way to victory. Domitianus (3500) + Tamer Editor (2400) + Gyzarus (2400) = 8300 damage. That's lethal without even taking into account the ATK power of the Link Monster.  STEP 4 (optional) Link summon using Tamer Editor + Test Panther, revive Tamer Editor with Comeback to use its effect a 2nd time on the same turn: - Knightmare Unicorn: Your only way of non-destruction removal in the deck besides Tri-Brigade Shuraig. Alongside Gyzarus summoned by your revived Tamer Editor, you can remove up to 3 obstacles in your way before the Battle Phase. Up to 4, technically, since you can further Link Summon with Tamer Editor + Unicorn into Shuraig for a 1/turn non-targetting banish. Borrelsword Dragon is also a viable candidate for running over opposing heavy hitters. - Cross-Sheep/Ferrijit: These let you summon an extra monster from hand (Ferrijit) or GY (Cross-Sheep). If using Cross-Sheep, make sure you can summon Tamer Editor from GY to a zone Cross-Sheep points to to get its effect off. From here, you can further Link Summon with Tamer Editor + CrossSheep/Ferrijit + the extra monster into either Tri-Brigade Shuraig or Borrelsword Dragon. Borrelsword is usually for Turn 1 plays, to add an additional layer of defense to your field. Summoning Shuraig Turn 1 is not recommended, as you may lose it before ever getting to use its removal effect.  Notes on other main deck cards: - Gladiator Beast United: This searchable quickplay spell requires a bit of set-up, but is a great way to disrupt your opponent's plays on their turn. With Bestiari in hand, field or GY (usually put in GY by Noxious) and any other 1 GB in hand, field or GY, you can summon Gyzarus and pop 2. If you already have Bestiari + 1 GB + United on Turn 2 going 2nd, you can simply enter BP and summon Gyzarus to clear your opponent's field and attack, tagging out into setting up your Tamer Editor combo in MP2. - Gladiator Beast Charge: Effectively Gyzarus in searchable trap form. Lets you pop up to 1/GB with different names face-up on your field. - Gladiator Beast War Chariot: Searchable monster effect negation, for when Domitianus isn't enough. - Effect Veiler: Probably one of the best cheap hand traps. Interchangeable with Kaijus or other available had traps like Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit. However, Veiler (and other monster HTs like Ghost Ogre) has the added bonus of being able to normal summon it alongside a special summoned GB to go into Test Panther if necessary.  Side Deck: - Skull Meister and GB Retiari: For GY-heavy decks. - Gameciel: The Kaiju of choice, being the only one Tamer Editor and Gyzarus can run over. - Dimensional Barrier: For shutting down decks that focus heavily on ED monsters, especially those that use mostly a single type. - Royal Decree: For those nasty trap-heavy decks and Skill Drain. The deck doesn't really suffer by removing its 2 GB traps. - GB Charge: For decks that use a lot of continuous S/T, and an alternative out to Skill Drain. Looking at you, Eldlich players.  Other decent+cheap side deck options: - Twister / Twin Twister: For more S/T removal. Twister only works for face-up S/T but doesn't require a discard. You want your hand for Heraklinos and Unicorn, but remember you can recycle with Equeste. - Ghost Belle & Snow Rabbit: Generic hand-trap destruction effect. Potential alternative to Veiler. - Dark Ruler No More: Another out to problematic monsters that are indestructible or have negation effects. Potential alternative to Gameciel.  Fun fact about GBs and Skill Drain interractions: - You can still tag in/out a GB under Skill Drain, because returning to deck is the cost, but the summoned GB will obviously not get its effect.  Main deck card options for those with a bigger budget or who already have some modern staples/techs: - Evenly Matched:  I love using this card in Master Duel with GBs. Summon a GB, attack, tag out (returns GB to deck as cost), chain link 2 Evenly Match, wipe your opponent's field, tag in to new GB. Fun fact about GB Comeback, the monster summoned by it is indestructible by battle, which is helpful if you have EM and a GB that can't attack over anything on your opponent's field. - Accesscode Talker: Another great finisher with high attack and a removal effect. Would probably replace Shuraig or Borrelsword (should probably keep for Turn 1 plays) with it. - Obviously stuff like Ash Blossom, Nibiru, Crossout, Droplets, Impermanence, etc.  Final Notes: This deck is a lot of fun and surprisingly consistent. Great for casual play with friends, or catching players off-guard at locals, but likely not big-tournament viable. Still, a great option for nostalgic players returning to the game on a budget.

deck_description: Checkout H3ro Of L3gend's youtube channel on how to play the combos for this deck  This deck is based on his, except for Scythe Lock, Small World and a few other cards  Endboard turn 1 + standby phase turn 2: DPE + Darklaw + Scythe lock. Sometimes with also Masquerena for an Avramax or another link summon  Turn 2: wipe the board with Accesscode + Knightmare Unicorn using Isolde for link climbing, or do a Zeus Play  You can destroy hand cards on your first turn with Aqua Dolphin, Small World can search for him or any hand trap, special summon Aqua Dolphin with Fire Flint's effect  Also works for Master Duel but it is a bit weaker (Dystopia + Dynatag instead of DPE and Dasher)     Main Deck: Nibiru, the Primal Being x1 Destiny HERO - Dasher x1 Artifact Scythe x1 Elemental HERO Stratos x2 Destiny HERO - Drawhand x1 Elemental HERO Liquid Soldier x1 Elemental HERO Solid Soldier x3 Elemental HERO Shadow Mist x3 Neo Space Connector x1 Neo-Spacian Aqua Dolphin x1 Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring x3 Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit x3 Infernoble Knight - Renaud x1 Fire Flint Lady x3 Droll & Lock Bird x1 Effect Veiler x1 E - Emergency Call x3 A Hero Lives x2 Reinforcement of the Army x1 Fusion Destiny x2 Small World x3 Mask Change x3 Called by the Grave x1 Living Fossil x1 "Infernoble Arms - Durendal" x1  Extra Deck: Masked HERO Dian x1 Masked HERO Acid x1 Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer x1 Masked HERO Dark Law x2 Masked HERO Blast x1 Divine Arsenal AA-ZEUS - Sky Thunder x1 Number 41: Bagooska the Terribly Tired Tapir x1 Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax x1 Accesscode Talker x1 Knightmare Unicorn x1 Isolde, Two Tales of the Noble Knights x1 Artifact Dagda x1 I:P Masquerena x1 Predaplant Verte Anaconda x1  Side Deck: Droll & Lock Bird x1 Tornado Dragon x1 Lyrilusc - Assembled Nightingale x1 Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess x1 Lightning Storm x2 Harpie's Feather Duster x1 Dark Ruler No More x2 Forbidden Droplet x2 Red Reboot x1

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_m9MnjH7U04 Un mazo prehistórico, no es tan conocido por que no posee un soporte de negación o de destierro, el mazo es totalmente ofensivo al momento del combate, el extra-deck que tiene es mayormente un pequeño soporte si el deck está en grandes aprietos, puede usarse algunas de las cartas del extra-deck, pero aun así el deck es bastante funcional como para enfrentarse a algunos decks del meta. A prehistoric deck, it is not so well known because it does not have a denial or banishing support, the deck is totally offensive at the time of combat the extra-deck it has is mostly a small support if the deck is in big trouble, it can use some of the cards from the extra-deck but still the deck is functional enough to take on some meta decks.

deck_description:

deck_name: Casual Budget Melffy Post Power of the Elements
deck_excerpt: Casual Budget-Friendly Melffy Deck, Post Power of the Duelist
deck_description: This is a casual riff on the pure Melffy deck post-Power of the Elements. Starters are Rescue Cat, Nimble Beaver, and Obedience Schooled. Ideally you end on a Naturia Beast + Joyous Melffys with a Kalantosa under it, giving you unlimited spell negates and a pop + another card, ideally Puppy or Wallaby, and you also then have the potential to go Sealy + 2* into Cheerful or Herald, or Sealy + 4* into Desert Locusts, ripping a card, then Locusts +4* into Leo for a big dude to sit on. Joyous Melffys is here if you don't have anything else turn 1, Mommy can do some fun stuff with 5 materials but really is cope, Crumble Logos can get something annoying out of the way, Barkion and Landoise for specific matchups where trap or monster negates are more useful, Dawn Dragster for a negate to summon on your opponent's turn with Sealy, since Naturia Beast requires an Earth tuner, Cross-Sheep to play around Knightmare Gryphon, although that's really just my casual environment talking, and Saryuja for additional summons and to make use of a swarmed board.  In the side I just threw a bunch of random stuff without much thought, but there's the other two Alphas for going second, 3 Lost Wind for more negates, 1 Obelisk because it's hilarious, a Knightmare package just for fun, 3 Drowning just because, and a little Fabled package because Unicore is kinda nice, and Cerburrel isn't terrible.
Dark Worlds for Fun
Galaxy Eyes for Fun
Go to - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1627G1TF20I - for the full deck profile and combo tutorial.

deck_excerpt: Any tuner + Chaos Space = Baronne + Draw 4
deck_description: The main combo of this deck consists of using any tuner plus an extender to go into Crystron Halqifibrax, summoning The White Stone of Ancients from the deck and using it's GY effect to summon a level 8 Blue-Eyes monster in the end phase. During your opponent's turn Halq's effect synchro summons Formula Synchron, which is used to quickly go into a Baronne de Fleur using itselft and the level 8 summoned off of the White Stone. The Chaos engine in the deck is used to extend further in the same combo I just described, Chaos Space searches Black Dragon Collapserpent which special summons itself, use it as the extender needed for Halq, then use the White Dragon Wyverburster that you add with Collapserpent's GY effect and the White Stone to synchro summon T.G. Hyper Librarian. All of this still gives you Baronne on the next turn, but Hyper Librarian gives you 2 extra draws making a total of 4 draws: 1 with Chaos Space's GY effect, 1 with Formula's on summon effect and 2 with Hyper Librarian's effect when both Formula and Baronne are summoned; these draws are very important to get to your handtraps since in many cases just having Baronne's negates isn't enought to stop the opponent. This combo can many times also get you follow up in the form of Chaos Dragon Levianeer or Nebula Dragon thanks to Blue-Eyes Abyss Dragon's effect which is the optimal target to summon with White Stone's effect. If your starting hand has The Melody of Awakening Dragon in addition to a tuner and Chaos Space your end board can also include Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy for extra interruption. All of this is showcased in game 1 of the video below.

deck_excerpt: Any tuner + Chaos Space = Baronne + Draw 4
deck_description: The main combo of this deck consists of using any tuner plus an extender to go into Crystron Halqifibrax, summoning The White Stone of Ancients from the deck and using it's GY effect to summon a level 8 Blue-Eyes monster in the end phase. During your opponent's turn Halq's effect synchro summons Formula Synchron, which is used to quickly go into a Baronne de Fleur using itselft and the level 8 summoned off of the White Stone. This deck also includes the Chaos engine that makes said combo more powerfull, I went into detail about this in my Master Duel version guide for Blue-Eyes which you can see by clicking here; the main difference between the Master Duel and the TCG versions is Dictator of D., which Master Duel doesn't have yet, it makes the Halq combo more consistent and helps in making rank 8 and even rank 4 XYZ plays. Oh and fun fact of the day: as seen in the replay below, Blue-Eyes Jet Dragon, another one of the Blue-Eyes cards that Master Duel doesn't have yet, is apparently a certified insta-win against Thunder Dragon.
Just a thought I had and will try in the upcoming days...

deck_excerpt: This is a OTK Gaia deck. This can get you to Plat in master duel, but can't compete with Meta decks.
deck_description:
This is a very strong turn 2 deck to try and OTK. Most cases you can't, but for the most part you'll have a huge advantage in turn 2 since you'll be able to attack with a 5.2k beater that only grows stronger if it kills a monster. You can
  • Normal summon Gaia the Magical Knight
    • Special summon Curse of Dragon from hand or GY,
      • Pick up Spiral Fusion (this can get Ash blossomed) and fusion summon Gaia Magical Knight of Dragons
      • Or pick up Galloping Gaia (usually if you already have Spiral fusion in your hand)
  • Normal summon Artillery Catapult Turtle
    • Special summon Gaia the Magical Knight from the deck (this can get Ash blossomed)
      • Then follow through first steps.
    • Special summon Curse of Dragon
      • Then pick up either Spiral Fusion if you can use it, or get Galloping Gaia
With Spiral Fusion, your fusion Gaia gains 2600 ATK, and is allowed to attack twice on monsters. Gaia Magical Knight of Dragons is the safest, and strongest card you can play on turn one as it can decrease its ATK by 2600 to destroy one card on the field once per any turn, but NOT negate. This card is the go to for fusion summoning cause of its effect to gain 2600 ATK after killing a monster in battle, once per battle phase. Becomes "Gaia the Dragon Champion" on the field. Sky Galloping Gaia the Dragon Champion is situational as he can force the monster he's attacking to attack or defense position. His summon searches Spiral Spear Strike from the deck or GY, which allows "Gaia the Dragon Champion" pierce dmg on defense position monsters. It allows you to draw 2, discard 1, if you are able to destroy the monster. Becomes "Gaia the Dragon Champion" on the field. (You can Fusion summon this card using Keeper of Dragon Magic as material) Curse of Dragon, the Magical Knight Dragon, is a super situational card. Once fusion summoned, you can fusion summon a level 7 dragon fusion monster using materials in the GY, and pull out Spiral Fusion out of your GY to fusion summon any of the fusion Gaia's above. Soldier Gaia the Fierce Knight quick effect is to tribute a fusion dragon monster to summon this dude. This effect can be used in battle phase and can attack as well when summoned, so attack after the monster has attacked. When Fusion summoning with Curse of Dragon, it can activate another effect by targeting your "Gaia the Dragon Champion" and negating all your opponents face up monsters effects with ATK less than or equal to that Gaia. IF an open board, no cards on opponent side, 8k LP
  1. Fusion summon Curse of Dragon, the Magical Knight Dragon
  2. Fusion summon any "Gaia the Dragon Champion" cards
  3. Go to "Battle Phase"
  4. Attack on each monster, then use Soldier Gaia the Fierce Knight quick effect to summon himself using Curse of Dragon, the Magical Knight Dragon
  5. DON'T use his effect once summoned.
  6. The DMG should come out to 2k + 5.2k + 2.6k = 9.2k
You usually don't have to worry about traps in the battle phase because of Galloping Gaia's effect, if you have any "Gaia the Dragon Champion" fusion cards on the field. When using Galloping Gaia, you want to pick up Curse of Dragon, or Gaia the Magical Knight. These two cards are the engine of this deck. You can fusion summon with any of the Gaia the Fierce Knight, and ANY level 5 dragon monster. Mahaama dragon is in this deck incase you have absolutely nothing and can help stall a bit. IF Gaia the Fierce Knight Origins is in the GY, you can change one monster's ATK to the original value. You DON'T use this on your Gaia's unless you happen to have your Gaia Magical Knight of Dragons ATK to be at Zero for some reason. Spiral Spear Strike. This is a dead card in most cases on your starting hand. You only want this if the enemy has a defense monster. *It's okay to throw this card away since Sky Galloping Gaia the Dragon Champion can pick it up from the GY or deck.   Feel free to add more to the extra deck. This was just basically a pure Gaia fusion deck and it's fun seeing a 5.2k beater on the board destroying monsters on the field.
I just decided to make an awful deck for a little game with some friends

deck_excerpt: Even I admit, Block Dragon shouldn't come back. But that doesn't mean we don't want it-
deck_description: Bread and Butter Combos: Delta The Magnet Warrior + Magnetic Field + Magnet Induction Activate Magnetic Field, leave your opponent in a state of chronic shock as they realize they're playing against Magnet Warriors, then Normal Summon Delta. Use Delta The Magnet Warrior's effect to send Beta The Electromagnet Warrior from Deck to Grave, then activate Magnet Induction to Special Summon Epsilon The Magnet Warrior from Deck. Use Epsilon's effect to trade out the Beta The Electromagnet Warrior in grave by milling a Gamma The Electromagnet Warrior from Deck, then add Alpha The Electromagnet Warrior from Deck to hand with Beta. Use Magnetic Field to bring back Gamma The Electromagnet Warrior from grave to Special Summon Alpha from hand, and add a Level 8 Magna Warrior (preferably Berserkion since you can summon Valkyrion from Deck). If going first, make Gallant Granite and Gorgonic Guardian. Use Gallant Granite to search Adamancipator Researcher to get another body on board, then use Adamanciaptor Researcher and the remaining Level 3 to make a Naturia Beast. If going second, make Gallant Granite (or Number 101: Silent Honor ARK) and The Phantom Knights of Break Sword and use Gallant to add an Adamancipator Researcher OR another Magna Warrior. It doesn't take much thought to go on from there. (You can tell from this upcoming combo that I play this Deck more than I should.) Beta The Electromagnet Warrior + Magnetic Field + Magnet Induction Activate Magnetic Field, panic because you really hope your opponent doesn't have a hand trap, then Normal Summon Beta The Electromagnet Warrior. Use Beta The Electromagnet Warrior's effect to add Delta The Magnet Warrior from Deck to hand, then activate Magnet Induction to Special Summon Gamma The Electromagnet Warrior from Deck.  Use Gamma The Electromagnet Warrior's effect to summon the Delta from hand, and mill an Epsilon. Now your first instinct, especially when playing on a simulator (because let's be real, who would spend $95+ on a Magnet Warrior Deck?) is to immediately activate Magnetic Field to Special Summon Epsilon and mill an Alpha, then immediately forfeit because you realized how stupid that was. Instead, hold back from using field for a bit, and make Cherubini, Ebon Angel of the Burning Abyss (SYNERGYYYYY). Use its effect to mill and Alpha The Electromagnet Warrior and get an insignificant 2200 ATK. NOW you use Magnetic Field to Special Summon Epsilon The Magnet Warrior from grave, which then mills any Magnet Warrior except an Alpha The Electromagnet Warrior, to Special Summon the milled Alpha The Electromagnet Warrior. Use its effect to add a Level 8 Magna Warrior, and well, you know the procedure when you've got 2 Level 4s out. Overview of the Deck: Magnet Warriors are an interesting bunch. Lots of people complain that they don't do much by themselves and need lots of support to even be playable (not that new support is unwelcome, please give us the rest of the Magnets, Konami), and while that's true, this has always been the design of Magnet Warriors. From day 1, Valkyrion's design implicates that the main function of Magnets was for being a Tribute engine to turbo out high level monsters like the god cards (which wasn't practical, but hey it's something). Their continued support has simply allowed them to adapt, and enhanced their ability to support other strategies even more. Now, whether or not this design choice was a good one is up for a debate that I could honestly care less about. What is a fact though, is that Magnet Warriors have a degree of splashability and weird field interactions that give them a variety of play styles, and always leaves them open for experimentation. More credit than what people give them. Either that or I'm just mad that Block Dragon's still banned, and am resorting to a 3 card combo to search Researcher.

deck_excerpt: Competitive-ish turbo Assault Mode Deck that focuses on interruption and control. For full combos, watch: https://youtu.be/pttLC3YfmLo
deck_description: In the original build, I missed adding Called By The Grave, so I added it here.  Things you should know about the deck: Stardust Dragon/Assault Mode's effect to negate and comeback to the field is not hard once per turn, so you can still chain Torrential Tribute at the end of the turn when it comes back, your opponent will chain some negate or effect to protect his monsters not knowing that you can negate again taking your Stardust Dragon/Assault Mode out of the field safe from destruction, then it will comeback again, and all of this during the end phase and this can be done over and over again. Assault Sentinel when tributed to special summon 1 monster from your hand or deck that specifically lists "Assault Mode Activate" in its text, locks you from special summoning monsters from the extra deck for the rest of the turn, except for synchro monsters. When you use Assault Sentinel's effect and it leaves the field, PSY-Framegear Gamma becomes live to negate any hand trap since there are no monsters on your side. If you have Plaguespreader Zombie & Emergency Teleport/One For One, you can bait hand traps using the Halqifibrax & Auroradon combo, then use Emergency Teleport to summon Psi-Reflector and do your main combo. If Assault Sentinel gets negated and you have Emergency Teleport/One For One, you can special summon Psi-Reflector and continue combo. You can use Emergency Teleport to summon Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit on you opponent's turn for an interruption since its effect activates on the field as well.  https://youtu.be/pttLC3YfmLo

deck_excerpt: Its a Mystic Mine deck, so y'know...
deck_description: Will probably update this further as i figure out the extra deck.     EDIT 1: Decided to take a few pages out of Dzeef's book after seeing his performance at Hartford. I've added anti-spell fragrance and Night Beam to the side deck, along with D.D. Crow.     EDIT 2: I decided to just forego the Krawler and just play Mine. Works better for what I need it for, and I'm not using it for some burn deck or what have you, so i don't have much guilt in using Mine in this context. I also tried to cut it down to a 40 card deck. Figuring out what to add, what to remove, what to reduce or increase, etc. was a little tricky, but I think what I have is fairly consistent (well, as consistent as a deck with Generaiders, 3 Parallel eXceed, and a main deck Evil Twin boss monster can be).     EDIT 3: I've been tweaking around my Mystic Mine searchers, as well as I've added 2 Pot of Dualities to support my secondary stall-strategy. I would run a strategy other than Mine if other strategies were more affordable considering this is going to be my IRL deck. Lightning Storm, Forbidden Droplet and Pot of Prosperity really need lower rarity prints at some point.     EDIT 4: I tried to prioritize making the deck more budget friendly since I feel like the main reason someone would even be playing a Mine deck is if money is an issue (given that its still stupidly cheap compared to cards like Droplet).

deck_name: Magistus, a guide to the spellcaster order
deck_excerpt: This is the first guide I written in a while. But I’m glad to be back at it!
deck_description:
Hi guys! Welcome back to a magistus list!

I haven’t made a guide in a while, but I decided to make one today for some reason, I don’t know why.

This isn’t a Complete Breakdown guide, this is just a list of card reasonings and other stuff.

But overall this particular deck is what I like to call magistus calamity turbo, it’s a moderately successful form of deck that’s very control oriented.

But for now, the cards!

1 Fairy Tail Snow

Snow was recently released from its long stay on the banlist, it got banned because it had no once per turn clause on it meaning it provided additional interruption in some decks. But as a level 4 spellcaster I can also use it to make plays in addition to other things. Pretty helpful if you ask me.

3 Crowley, the Magistus of Grimoires

Crowley is simple enough, you can discard a spellcaster and summon him then you can flip his attribute (this effect is virtually useless) and reequip a magistus if he’s in the graveyard. Solid extender and played at three.

3 Incredible Esscaila the Virtuous

The Esscaila from the short lived rein of swordsouls serves a purpose in magistus for being capable of behaving as a tuner for the synchro summon of the Calamity or risen. Sadly though she hits your wallet pretty hard because of how she was abused by other decks.

3 Zoroa, the Magistus of Flame

Zoroa is the most valuable of the Magistus. He allows you to equip summon search and more! Even though there is only two effects on him he’s worth playing three of in magistus alone.

3 Endymion the Magistus of Mastery

Endymion is a magistus with a unique position in the deck, it plus ones your hand and draws are always welcome, but at the same time it kinda lacks something. I opted three though because I love my advantage and it’s water so I can play dragite.

1 Performage Hat Tricker

If two or more monsters are on the field you can just summon it from your hand, that’s all I need from it ngl so I play a copy. Other players can opt for more of this card and it’s pretty solid in Magistus but I personally slip by with one.

3 Rilliona the Magician of Verre

Rilliona will soon grow to become the founder of the witchcrafters but for now she is one of Magistus’s most valuable cards as she is a searcher for spells and traps with a helpful grave effect to equip another Magistus.

3 Ash Blossom and Joyous Spring

Need I say why?

2 Spellbook Magician of Prophecy

Even though it takes up the normal summon this card is definitely an option to consider when playing Magistus, I play the full blown knowledge package.

3 Magician’s Souls

Souls currently holds a unique place in the metagame for being able to refresh your hand, but what Magistus has over others when it comes to souls is that I can use it to pitch my used-up equips for draws and it doesn’t even take a normal summon to do so! If you’re to play Magistus and can afford it PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE play the magicians souls package, I promise it’ll make your life so much easier.

1 Illusion of Chaos

Illusion of Chaos searches magicians souls and packs itself into the deck making it pretty valuable on that front. I recommend playing it.

3 Trismagistus

The continuous spell for Magistus is a very solid card for them, in other decks this wouldn’t be the same way but Magistus has a severe lack of ways to summon over certain amount of monsters from your hand each turn. Plus this card provides a continuous protection effect!

1 Foolish Burial

Being able to send snow to the graveyard is a good enough reason alone to play this. And even if you can’t send snow (AKA you opened it) you can still set up Crowley or Rilliona and get their grave effects ready

1 Magistus Invocation

Rilliona’s main search invocation is a fusion spell that can fuse away your equips and the fusion monster it can summon is also a very solid boss so I recommend playing this card, you can get it easily enough by draws or Rilliona so please don’t play more than one.

3 Magistus Virtra

A revival spell with a built in protection effect is valuable to a deck that wants to keep one monster out and you can also pitch it with souls if it is clogging.

3 Spellbook of Knowledge

Part of the Knowledge engine this card lets you plus pretty easily, 10/10 would recommend.

3 Spellbook of Secrets

The last part of the Knowledge engine Secrets is three extra copies of the plus 1 this engine provides.

2 Aiwass, the Magistus Spell Spirit

One to summon and one to equip, Aiwass is an interruption who also makes it harder to beat over your boss monsters, playing three is a mistake and one is fine but I prefer two.

1 Adamacipator Risen-Dragite

Dragite can gain its interruption from Endymion or the Spellbook magician, that’s the only reasoning I’ll give you on this front, the rest you can infer for yourself. (For the record this is a pretty flexible slot so if you want you can try some other cards go right ahead, I went with what I thought I could get the most mileage out of)

2 Zoroa the Magistus Conflagrant Calamity

The boos of the whole deck. Level 8 synchro, equips for the extra on synchro summon and locks the effects of fusions links xyzs and synchros when properly set up. It also helps that it can revive on a whim for the grind game.

1 Vahram the Magistus Divinity Dragon

Like always, a dragon. Vahram, has a solid equipped effect as far as protection goes and moreover has a hilarious secondary effect that people overlook, if it’s on the field by a synchro summon ant it is popped the opponents entire field actually just goes BOOM, if you know your opponent doesn’t read summon it as a bait, I personally have just summoned it and rammed it into something to dismantle boards before as well.

1 Peformage Trampanzee Magician

This card allows you to push for game or pop stuff your opponents have so don’t be scared to use it, it has come clutch for me before.

1 Ninaru the Magistus Glass Goddess

Ninaru recycles and rids opponents of some pretty pesky spells so I like to play it at one because I don’t need more than that.

1 Rilliona the Magistus Glass Witch Wardrobe

Summoning a Magistus from deck is helpful if you need certain ones in a pinch but playing one is probably the best choice like Ninaru

1 Accesscode

Because I can make it off of selene and push for game

1 Selene, Queen of the Master Magicians

Selene’s job is simple enough, make Accesscode and help push for game, but you can also use her to extend other plays as well. You should only need to use one.

1 Crowley, the First Propheteer

One of the Magistus’s grown up version, Crowley grew to be the leader of the Spellbook archetype and the forever meme: NS Alister, search Invocation. But as a dark for accesscode, a solid link 2 stepping stone on your way to selene, and able to search a part of the Knowledge package this Crowley is a pretty helpful assist to this build, I would recommend running him if you’re using the Spellbook package.

3 Artemis, the Magistus Moon Maiden

The reason why this card is pricy is because it’s simply put: solid invocation food. Playing three helps a lot because it searches, it lets Zoroa lock links, and it’s probably just the best Magistus card in the game, but for the wrong reason.

Magistus is a pretty low laying archetype in the current format but it’s very fun and even better, easy to build! It feels great to play it.

You may notice that the list I have finished writing a guide for is heavy on card advantage, and your right, that’s what this build does, it tries to lock your opponents down and amasses resources until it can go for the kill. Despite this looking underwhelming it is actually pretty efficient at times.

What this deck lacks the most is definitely kill power, but generating advantage on a whim is definitely very helpful.

Overall I would classify this particular list as a midrange deck as it pumps out something and preps your hand for the next turn until it can kill. I can see people calling this control and I understand why but my experience is that I’m doing too many combo based plays that I don’t feel like it’s actually control.

Questions will be answered and I’m more than happy to respond to comments!

deck_excerpt: Sometimes sinners can be the ones who do good things. Other times, saints may sin against man.
deck_description:
*Attention: Video has been uploaded and will be linked in the description as soon as possible. Link below:

( https://youtube.com/watch?v=btLm4BQf2ew&feature=youtu.be ) -Exo   So our Dragon fren has been getting quite the reception recently, and it was about time I got into making a non-Despia related Branded list myself. The reason of choosing an Orcust - Shaddoll hybrid list was simple: both have quite an oddly unique synergy to each other. Not because they're both Dark; but the GY synergy they both work upon to me interest me for some reason. It's a little rare for some people to appreciate the love oddball synergy between two unexpected things; but it does happen in this game from time to time. The Branded pieces (while not the biggest player in this deck) still does what it needs to do best, and here it was truly matters. Now for the most part, you just have two copies of Fallen of Albaz and one copy of Albion the Shrouded Dragon (with the usual three copies of Branded Fusion), because obviously this is the norm thanks to the "Heathenry" caused by the Despia archetype, and the lackluster exploitation of Super Polymerization. Speaking of which, didn't I forget to mention that a Shaddoll package was in here? Yep, it's pretty basic (with just 2 copies of Shaddoll Squatma and Shaddoll Dragon, and a copy each of Shaddoll Hedgehog and Shaddoll Beast); but because of this, I also opted to run a copy of Trickstar Corobane and Fairy Tail - Snow (to be used to Fusion summon either Albion the Branded Dragon or El Shaddoll Construct). Now as for our favourite devastator to all DARK-attribute monsters Super Polymerization, I have two Extra Deck targets that can help clear away some issues; but both could also be used with the effect of Fallen of Albaz: Predaplant Dragostapelia (used to rid of hard to handle monsters like Despia Quaeritis)  and Predaplant Triphyoverutum (as a board wipe, better than Guardian Chimera IMO). Finally comes the discussing point here: The Orcust engine and why I added it in. Truth is that I find the GY consistency of Orcust to always come in handy in decks like Shaddolls in times of need (with or without Orcust Harp Horror). With that being said (knowing that Predaplant Verte Anaconda is on its way out), I have added the only engine that truly matters to the Orcust engine as we speak: three copies of Girsu, the Orcust Mekk-Knight, two copies of Orcust Knightmare, and one copy of both World Legacy-"World Wand" and Orcust Cymbal Skeleton. All of them which allowed me to not only get the usual Link monsters that Orcust requires (such as Galatea, the Orcust Automation), but also be apart in the process of the fusion summoning requirements for both the Branded and Shaddoll monsters as "backup payment" (especially for El Shaddoll Winda).

deck_name: Superheavy Samurai Scythe Lock - MASTER DUEL
deck_excerpt: Imagine people attacking with attack points in attack position.
deck_description:
This deck isn't very meta and can be stopped with any sort of disruption, but this is my attempt to make the SHS as viable as possible. This setup probably isn't very fun to play against, but it's effective and it works in most cases.

--Scythe Lock--

Ideally, you want to go first with this deck to set up the Scythe lock. While there are many full combo hands that you can draw to facilitate this play, your main goal in the first step of the Scythe lock is to get Scales, Soulpiercer, and an SHS tuner on the field. In order to do this, you need to activate the effect of Scarecrow and then tribute it to activate the effect of Soulpeacemaker. From here, use Scales and Soulpiercer to Link Summon Dagda. Activate Soulpiercer once again to add Soulclaw to your hand. Then, equip Soulclaw to the SHS tuner you left on your field in order to activate its on-field effect and trigger Dagda. After you Summon Soulclaw and set Scythe, use Dagda and the SHS tuner to Link Summon Halquifibrax. Proceed to activate Halquifibrax's effect to Summon Ghost Belle from your deck. Finally, using Soulclaw and Ghost Belle, Synchro Summon Naturia Beast. At this point, the Scythe lock is set and you can end your turn.

During your opponent's turn, use Halquifibrax's effect to Summon Wonder Magician as quickly as possible. I personally wait to use this when my opponent controls a monster in order to stop Gamma. After Wonder Magician is Summoned, use its effect to destroy Scythe. After you Summon Scythe to your field, activate Wonder Magician's effect to Synchro Summon Baronne de Fleur using Scythe as material. And there you have it. One omni-negate, one Imperial Order on legs, and one Extra Deck lock on your opponent. If your opponent is playing a standard combo deck, this is probably where they are going to scoop.

--Auroradon-Borreload-Musashi-Follow-Up--

As a follow-up, you can get three SHS monsters on the field to Link Summon Auroradon. Use Auroradon's effect to Summon O'Lion from the deck by making it tribute itself and a token. Using your present materials, Synchro Summon Borreload Savage Dragon and equip it with Auroradon from the grave. You can also activate O'Lion's effect to Summon a token. If you also managed to add Trumpeter to your hand earlier, you can use it and the O'Lion token to Summon Musashi and recycle a machine monster for later use.

--General Tips--

Soulpeacemaker, Soulpiercer, and Wagon are the three critical pieces of this deck. Soulpeacemaker Special Summons from the deck, Soulpiercer has a non-once-per-turn search effect, and Wagon is the searcher that searches out these two searchers. Another very integral part of this deck is Scarecrow, which you will usually use to trigger Soulpiercer's effect and to recycle resources for more combos and plays. Another less crucial but still important card is Flutist, which can save you from Effect Veiler and Infinite Impermanence. Outside of these necessary cards, I also packed in cards for different situations. Lithosagym can be a mini Scythe in case you brick. Jizukiru is good for removal and Gandarla is good for getting rid of the Barrier Statue of the Stormwinds in a Floowandereeze deck. Tunneler is good for recycling your SHS monsters, especially for the Scarecrows and Musashi.

For the cards in the Extra Deck, you use Musashi to recycle important machine monsters and to maybe even recycle Jizukiru. If you're in need of a Harpie's Feather Duster, Synchro Summon Ogre Shutendoji to clear your opponent's backrow. If you need to use your opponent's Spell and Trap cards to keep surviving, you can Summon out Warlord Susanowo. For a quick finisher, you can Summon out Steam Train King by either Synchro Summoning it normally or using Battleball's effect on a Jizukiru you gave to your opponent. If you ever get stuck with bad hand, Xyz Summoning out Bagooska and hope for the best. Bagooska is also good going second if you have Scales and a Level 4 monster. By Special Summoning Scales and Normal Summoning a Level 4 monster, you can create Bagooska and shut down your opponent's negate board without activating any effects.

YAGED

(Yet Another Galaxy-Eyes Deck) 1. Summon Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon(s) using Xyz monsters 2. Summon stronger Xyz monsters 3. Hold the line until you accomplish steps 1-2

deck_excerpt: N/R Format Ritual Deck. Isn't Meta but surprisingly is consistent and fun to play. Gadget players: "No you can't just take my monsters for free". Re
deck_description: Ok so this Deck, the second one from N/R Format. This Deck wasn't built by me I received a lot of help by some Discord users named Domnostein [Megalith Best Deck!] and Monk, The Local Ballpark Player (Yes this was in a N/R Format Discord Server). This is a really budget Relinquished deck it's extremely cheap.  The objective is summoning Relinquished. For that you can use the Impcantation engine to speed up the strategy and making it more consistent, I completly forgot this engine so at first I was thinking of Djinn of Rituals Archetype and Sphere Kuriboh to try to have more options for the Deck.  The main weakness for this deck it's the fact that you NEED enemy monsters to kill your opponent, being Sonic Bird, Manju, and Senju your "Beaters" with 1400 ATK; so in the case you have your 3 copies of Relinquished in the GY and no way to recover it, that's GG; it's like an Pure Eldlitch having it's 3 copies of Eldlitch banished face down or absorbed by a Thousand Eyes Restricted.  After testing it out the best option it's going second. 'Cause your best combos ends with Relinquished and when you do that going first you hav in the best of cases 1 maybe 2 Relinquished with 1 or 2 Impcantation monster.  If you feel very brave you could try it out in Rankeds, you'll regret it very quickly.  Have fun. :3

deck_excerpt: A fun, fishy combo deck for under $200.
deck_description: This deck was built for my locals Classic+ Format which features decks under $185 for Main, Side, and Extra Deck. Goal: Summon Big Boi Coelacanth, go TurboTastic, end board with multiple "no's". Generally by dumping Coelacanth with Lifeless Leafish, stacking into Dugares, and then going full Turbo. General Turn 1 examples: Special Tenyi-Shthana, Normal Lifeless Leafish, dump Fish Boi, make Dugares, special Fish Boi, turbo Summoner Monk, discard spell, special Leafish, dump Fish boi, make Dugares, special Fish Boi, TURBO One for One into Beutunaful Princess, special Leafish, dump Fish boi. Summon another level 4 fish                                                                                                                             (White Stingray, Silent Angler, etc.), make Dugares, TURBO Once you go Turbo, make sure you grab Oyster Meister and Royal Swamp Eel as a baseline and summon 2 other fish situationally. You can generally make a Link-2 out of Dugares and Coelacanth, then make either Abyss Dweller or Bahamut into Toadally Awesome. Once you've made some space, synchro into Monoceros, special Coelacanth back and then discard a card to summon Fishborg or another Swamp Eel out. Then you can easily go into Dragite, turn the token into a Linkuriboh and then use the Link-2, Linkuriboh, and Big Fish Boi to make Apollousa. Important card explanations: Deep Sea Dive/Guitar Gurnards: One card combo to make Dragite or Monoceros. Diva can also summon Minstrel to fill graveyard and stack an extender on top of the deck. Eria: My choice for a generic Link-2. Has some functionality against decks that run Water Monsters and is a Water monster itself (works with Abyss Dweller). Deep Sea Minstrel: Crucial to pick out Ash Blossom or Impermanence out of your opponent's hand before going Turbo. Also provides synergy with Diva. Linkuriboh: Generic Link-1, ideally turns your Oyster Token into something that can make Apollousa. Can also be summoned from the grave with Beautunaful Princess to deal with big boss monsters during battle phase. Other Possible Budget Card Choices (not included): Knightmare Phoenix: Pops Macro Cosmos or Dimensional Fissure. Having access to the grave is critical for the deck. Glacial Beast Iceberg Narwhal: Great finisher card, helps insure lethal. (this is a WIP and will be updated as I prepare to enter tournaments in the future. Feedback welcome. Enjoy!)

deck_excerpt: A deck that combines the control of Eldlich with the power of Uria. Makes uses of Curious thanks to the Sacred Beast side of the deck, making the Eldl
deck_description: The Deck's pretty simple, you get out Eldlich and make uses of the Golden Land traps to keep your opponent form getting their combos off to the point they can kill yeah. And if you're lucky you can bring out Uria for the big numbers!  More seriously this deck is making use of the fact that Sacred Beasts have an easy line to Curious that allows them to dump Eldlich to get him into rotation. From there it's slandered eldlich stuff while sometimes getting out Uria to remove set cards and deal massive damage thanks to the boatload of continuous traps and the grave, pumped up even further if you manage to get Hyper Blaze on the field. The extra deck is mostly just a toolbox of stuff to help deal with cards and deal enough damage for game. The exceptions to this are the trifecta of cards that are central to this deck, Linkuriboh, Relinquished Anima, and Curious. By utilizing the fact that Chaos Summoning Beast is a level 1 that can be summoned by Dark Beckoning Beast and brought back by Opening of The Spirt Gates you can easily make Linkuriboh and Relinquished Anima. Along with the Dark Beckoning on field that's enough material for Curious.

deck_excerpt: Sunavalon/Rikka/Aroma/Bouncer. Consistent 5 negates and a floodgate.
deck_description: Simple plant Link, will change with DIFO coming out next month.  The idea is to try to end as often as possible with Benghalancer, Cactus, and some other negates or protection on the field when going first. This will require special summoning the Loci, however, so may not always be possible.  Get Loci on the field either by using Unexpected Dai, or White Roise Cloister if you have it or a Lonefire blossom to tribute to summon it from deck, if you have the cloister but no Lonefire nor Loci hopefully you have a Painful Decisions, and if not, let's hope you at least have a rescue rabbit.  Once you have a loci on the board, link it for a Dryas, activate Dryas to search Sowing, use Sowing to summon Twins from deck, then Chain Link 1 Dryas to heal the damage of the Sowing and summon a Sunvine Healer from Extra Deck, and Chain Link 2 the Twin to get the Loci back from grave. Use the effect of Healer to gain 300 health (don't forget this, it is needed to summon Laurel in a few effects).  Link off the Dryas and Healer for Jasmine, then use Jasmine's effect to tribute the Twin and summon Mardel from Deck (hoping she's not in your hand, else you'll have to get creative). Mardel effect on summon to search Laurel (if not in your hand), then Laurel effect to special summon itself.  Link Laurel and Mardel Loci into a second Jasmine. Activate Laurel's effect in grave to heal 500, and trigger the effects to search of both Jasmines.  This is where it becomes situational, and depends on what you have in your hand. If you have one of the Rikkas, and you haven't normal summoned yet, search the other Rikka and a Cactus Bouncer. If you have either Carrotweight or Spore in hand, and you haven't normal summoned yet, search the other and the Cactus Bouncer. If you have neither but you haven't normal summoned yet, but you have any other plant monster in hand, get Snowdrop and the Bouncer. If you have used your normal summon, either search a full package, or, if you have part of one in hand, get what you're missing and either Teardrop or Carrotweight. You may also opt to get the bouncer regardless since you'll most likely be able to normal summon it next turn after still making big bodies on the field if you can't OTK your opponent.  Once you've done your searches, the rest of the Sunavalon part is Jasmine and Mardel link into Melias, Melias effect to summon Loci from grave, Jasmine and Loci for Melias, Melias effect to summon Loci from grave again, then Loci link into the second Dryas, which searches for Shrine. Careful to summon the first Melias with the Jasmine in the main monster zone to a zone pointed by the one in the Extra monster zone, and the second in a zone next to that one, since Melias does not have a downward arrow, so if it is in the Extra zone, it will prevent you from link summoning without using it.  You can use Shrine now, or once you have the Dryantrentiay out, doesn't really matter, but remember that you need a Sunavalon Link Monster on the field to activate it. Once you do, if you have Carrotweight and Spore in hand, activate it by sending Carrotweight to grave, then use its effct by sending Spore to the grave to summon itself, then use Spore's effect in grave to banish Laurel and summon itself gaining 1 level from Laurel, which then lets you synchro the two of them off for Marjoram, which lets you search Blessed Winds. If you have a Rikka in Hand, you can tribute the Loci for their effect, and if Mudan comes out you can sarch Rikka Sheet. If you summon Snowdrop and another plant, use Snowdrop's effect to make them both level 8, then overlay them for Teardrop.  Link the Dryas and a Melias into Benghalancer, then link the Benghalancer and the other Melias into Dryantrentiay. Drientrentiay will search you Bloom from deck. Then use the effect of Benghalancer in grave to banish the Jasmines and summon itself back in a zone pointed by Dryantrentiay (preferably not the same one in case a column negation occurs).  Use Pot of Avarice now, if you have it, mainly resetting your extra deck so you don't throw too much back into the main deck, that way you have more odds of drawing some hand traps off it.  If you don't draw any extenders, normal summon the Cactus Bouncer, set whichever traps you got through the combos, and pass.  There is an alternate route for the Rikkas on which you end up with Strenna on the board, you can use her effect to add back a plant from grave to hand, do that before your turn, it's free real estate, as she will most likely be tributed next turn by Rikka Sheet to negate and steal a monster, and summon out Hyperyton with her as material attached to it.  Beware of the synergy between Blessed Winds and Marjoram: when you gain health, you can use Marjoram to pop a card.  Benghalancer bounces back to the hand in exchange for Life Points equal to the bounced monster's attack. If you have Cactus Bouncer up on the field with it, you can negate the card with one of your negates on summon, then bounce it back with Benghalancer, and they can't normal summon anymore, nor special summon unless they deal with the bouncer.  If your opponent tries to pop your plant link monsters, you can banish Sowing from grave to protect them.  While your LP are higher than your opponents and you have Marjoram on the field, your plant monsters cannot be targeted with card effects.  If you plan on putting out a Bouncer, do not try to go down the Strenna into Hyperyton line, as that is a special summon, which you cannot conduct while Bouncer is on your field.  Don't forget Benghalancer's recursion if it's taken off the field. It will be a target since Dryantrentiay cannot be target by effects nor attacks.  Dryantrentiay's effect is not a quick effect, but on your turn you can pop a link monster it points to (wink wink to Benghalancer who can come back), and pop as many cards your opponent controls as it had Link rating (so most likely 4).  Every turn after activating Shrine, it gives you a free Loci from grave, which can be turned into a thrasher, that can get 4k attack thanks to Dryantrentiay being on the field, but beware it will be destroyed if Dryantrentiay is destroyed by a non-targeting effect.  Bloom, beyond negating all face up monsters on your opponent's field when activated if you have a link 4 plant (Benghalancer counts) also lets you make a plant link monster gain attack equal to that of all the cards it points to. So if you first use Thrasher to kill a monster, then use its effect to summon it back to a zone pointed by the big tree, you can increase the attack of Dryantrentiay by that much more when it attacks. If you can get a second thrasher out, try to put the Benghalancer in a zone not pointed by Dryantrentiay when you summon it back, that way you can have 2 4k Thrashers and a big monster from your opponent's grave fueling the big tree's attack through Bloom.  If you run into a lot of Nibirus, you can play Sales Ban, or you can try other variants of the deck that run the Brave package, but that would triple the cost of the deck. Also feel free to adapt hand traps and Side deck to your scene's habits.
