deck_excerpt: Branded Dark Magicians sounds way too long, Branded Magicians sounds cooler anyway. It's actually a pretty fun control deck to play.
deck_description:
Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back after two or more days without internet so I was stuck trying to build this list that is actually pretty confusing to make (either that or the other half of this deck just gave me a choice paralysis due to how many one of cards it runs originally), which is Branded Dark Magicians... Branded Magicians sounds cooler. "Why play this deck?" Are you a Yugiboomer? Do you love Fusion Summoning, like me? Or do you just... want to have a valid excuse to use Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon over DPE? Well this deck (I think) is for you, kind of. Also a bit of a disclaimer, as per usual, my lists are tinkered based off of my preferences, so if you feel like changing something about the deck, feel free to do so, so long as it doesn't mean using the Brave Tokens in a deck that needs its Normal Summon, especially this one. Anyway, the list. The Main Deck: Monsters • My standard Branded engine ratio, with a few changes - x2 Aluber the Jester of Despia, x1 Fallen of Albaz, Incredible Ecclesia, & Dramaturge for the monsters. x3 Branded Fusion & Branded Opening with/without x1 Branded In Red for the Spells, depending on whether you want to use Guardian Chimera or not. x1 Branded Exile with/without x2 Branded Retribution for the Traps. Only one Fallen of Albaz this time mainly only to make room. I really tried my hardest to make this as compact as possible without cutting Branded Fusion to 1. • The Dark Magician cards
  1. The Dark Magicians, not the Fusion but the Yugi's ace monster (kind of) - We only play 2 because it's a brick and it's a target for both Magicians' Souls and Branded Fusion. The other one is a The LIGHT - Hex-Sealed Fusion, hence the "kind of".
  2. Apprentice Illusion Magician - Dark Magician searcher. Only a 2 of because that's really the standard ratio for it and I don't want to play just one copy of any searcher, like playing only one copy of Despian Tragedy in Branded Despia, for example. I'm just saying that it doesn't make sense.
  3. Magician's Rod - Normal Summon Rod, add Illusion Magic, Dark Magical Circle, or Eternal Soul, or anything else you wanna do instead.
  4. Magicians' Souls - Probably the most broken (and expensive) card in this deck, aside from Branded Fusion. It can either set up your GY or Special Summon a Dark Magician from your GY (and technically from your Deck), and it draws you cards.
  5. Illusion of Chaos - Reveal this card, add Magicians' Souls or Magician's Rod. Also a Fusion Material for Master of Chaos.
  6. Eye of Timaeus - A searchable Dark Magician Fusion monster because that's what it practically is, usually Dark Magician/Dark Magician Girl the Dragon Knight or The Dark Magicians.
  7. Dark Magic Attack - A searchable back row removal. This could also be Dark Burning Magic if you just want to wipe your opponent's entire board instead.
  8. Bond Between Teacher and Student - A free Dark Magician Girl and Dark Magic Attack/Dark Burning Magic.
  9. Secrets of Dark Magic - The original Magikey Maftea, it's both a Fusion Spell and a Ritual Spell, except it's also a Quick-Play Spell.
  10. Illusion Magic - Another searchable one of searcher.
  11. Dark Magical Circle - Your most important card. It's a search (sort of) upon activation, and it's an interruption in the form of a targeting (boo) banishing effect (yay) triggered when a "Dark Magician" (that counts your Fusion Monsters that are treated as such as well) is Summoned to your field. Searchers should always be played at maximum quantities, especially this one, though you could get away with playing 2 since it itself is also searchable, I guess.
  12. Magician Navigation - This one feels weird, because in Pure Dark Magicians, you gotta play at least 2-3 copies of this but in this version, it feels weak and strangely enough it feels stronger with its interruption effect when in the GY. I'll leave this one up to you but just one of this, I feel I can get by.
  13. Eternal Soul - Your second most important card. The reason why your Dark Magical Circle can spam banish effects. Also, protect this card at all costs, because it's gonna blow up your entire board when your opponent gets rid of it.
  14. Magicians' Combination - It's a negate, except it's actually pretty fun to use, since it lets you tag in and out of your Dark Magician and Dark Magician Girl. Also, it negates the effect, not the activation so... keep that in mind because it's relevant.
The Extra Deck: • Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon - The big boss monster towers negate, but this time it can actually pop monsters and burn. • Dark Magician the Dragon Knight - Your second boss monster, mainly because it protects your back row from targeting and destruction. I like to play 2 for insurance but you can probably get away with just playing 1. • Master of Chaos - This one's purely experimental, I never actually see this come up to be honest, but because I'm playing Illusion of Chaos, might as well use it. • The Dark Magicians - A neat one of monster that draws you a card whenever a Spell/Trap is activated, be it by you or your opponent. It also floats into both Dark Magician and Dark Magician Girl so, that's cool I guess. • Dark Magician Girl the Dragon Knight - Quick-Play pop on a face-up card at a cost of a discard might sound hefty at times, but better have it than not. Final Thoughts: It's a fun deck to play. I mean, that's what both Dark Magician and Blue-Eyes are, really, they don't strike me as the most competitive decks there are but, you know... it still has the Dark Magician bricking issue though despite already cutting it down to just 2 copies. It also has the same problems with the other deck that I've been testing and working on lately - Branded Tearalaments - that sometimes the deck feels too slow and sometimes it just ramps up out of nowhere swiftly, though I think that only says much about the pilot and not necessarily about the deck itself, which makes sense since I love fast-paced decks, and speed is one of the most important criteria for me when it comes to testing decks, I'm still not sure. Regardless, the deck worked better than expected, definitely. It's still basically just two control decks that share incidental synergies being both Fusion strategies merged into one. Also, it's great that most if not all of the Dark Magician Fusion monsters are all Level 8, which is just the perfect Level for the Branded so, yeah. That's pretty much it. Also if you wanna do the Guardian Chimera thing, feel free to do so in this list only because the Extra Deck is actually pretty loose and you can afford to cut down some cards. As per usual, if you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.
Just tightening things up by trading in some flexibility

Swap Frog + any other Frog combo: + normal summon Swap Frog, then send one Frog from your Deck to the GY, which is very likely to bait an Ash. + Activate Swap Frog effect to return it to the hand, then continue to special summon it by discarding the other Frog monster, then send another Frog from your Deck to the GY, just pick anyhow so that there are at least one Ronintoadin and one other Frog in your GY. + special summon Ronintoadin from the GY by banishing one other Frog. + special summon Marincess Coral Anemone, then use its effect to special summon Swap Frog from your GY and send another Frog (that is not Ronintoadin) to the GY. + special summon Ronintoadin. + XYZ summon Toadally Awesome. (you should speacial summon Dupe Frog during your opponent's SP, and Swap Frog in yours. during your Main Phase the turn you special summoned Swap Frog, return it to the hand to normal summon it again to maximize the resource in the GY).

deck_excerpt: I finally finished it, my take on the Branded Tearalaments.
deck_description:
Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, and I think I have finally figured out how I wanna build this deck after weeks of testing. Presenting, Branded Tearalaments. "Why play this deck?" Well... I love Fusion Summoning, and I love Fusion Summoning more than once. What's actually funny about this list is that since I've decided to cut the DPE engine, I can now play Visas Starfrost, which means there's a line in this list that can bring out Baronne De Fleur before your fifth summon, though it kills your Branded Fusion but you know what, that's fine, because after months of endless testing Branded lists, the archetypal Field Spell Despia, Theater of the Branded is pretty underrated. That also means you could search for any "Branded" Spell/Trap instead of rushing into Branded Fusion, you still have your Tearalaments cards that can do your Fusion Summoning for you by recycling the materials from your hand, field, and/or GY back into the Deck, and that Fusion Summon is not Level restricted, that means that if you have a bunch of DARK Fairies in your GY, you can actually still bring The First Darklord this way. As fast as the Branded engine is in terms of spending all your resources from the deck, the Tearalaments cards bring that ever so needed recycling power at a cost of sacrificing some of your GY set up. Anyway, the list. The Main Deck: I've already explained my standard ratio for the Branded engine before, but as a refresher, here it is: • x2 Aluber & Fallen of Albaz, & x1 Incredible Ecclesia, Ad Libitum, & Dramaturge for monsters. • x3 Branded Fusion & Branded Opening, & x2 Despia, Theater of the Branded with/without x1 Branded In Red for the Spells, depending on whether you want to use Guardian Chimera or not for the spells. • x1 Branded Exile with/without x2-3 Branded Retribution for traps. Monsters • The Tearalaments cards - The only cards that I feel like needs to be discussed, especially in terms of ratio.
  1. Tearalaments Rainoheart - This is your other Normal Summon, just following the standard rule of 5 per deck. He sends any copy of "Tearalaments" monster from your deck, except a copy of himself. He also has an effect to summon himself when sent to the GY by a card effect but banishes when removed from the field.
  2. Tearalaments Shaylen - The main extender of the Tearalaments, has an effect to Special Summon herself from your hand and allows you to send a monster from your hand to the GY and mill 3 cards off the top of your deck. This is all a part of the effect, which means it can trigger your Despian Tragedy's search effect. She also has the archetypal effect that she shares with the following other 2 Tearalaments monsters, to Fusion Summon ANY Fusion Monster when sent to the GY by a card effect, by shuffling the Fusion Materials from your hand, field, and/or GY into the deck. We only play 2 of her because she can easily be milled anyway.
  3. Tearalaments Haufenis - The obligatory pseudo-hand trap of the archetype, has an effect that can be activated in response to an opponent's monster effect activated on the field that allows herself to be Special Summoned from your hand and mills 3 cards off the top of your deck, alongside her GY effect to Fusion Summon. We only play 1 of her for the same reason as Shaylen's.
  4. Tearalaments Meiru - The other archetypal Normal Summon, except we're playing less copies of her and just more of Rainoheart instead because he's a name for the purposes of Fusion Summoning despite both being very much searchable. Has the effect to also mill 3 cards off the top of your deck when she's either Normal or Special Summoned, alongside her GY effect to Fusion Summon. We also only play 1 of her for the same reason as her sisters'.
No Tearalaments Spell(s) because they don't have anything so far that helps with this particular version of the build. Traps • x3 Tearalaments Crime - The obligatory archetypal omni-negate Counter Trap that can be activated if you control either a "Tearalaments" monster or a "Visas Starfrost". It negates the activation, but it shuffles the card back to the deck instead, then allows you to send a card from your hand to the GY (potentially a "Tearalaments" monster, Despian Tragedy, or any one of brick that needs to be in the GY.) The Extra Deck: • x1 Tearalaments Kaleido Heart & x2 Tearalaments Kitkalos
  1. Kitkalos is a Level 5 Fusion Monster that requires only 1 "Tearalaments" monster and an Aqua monster, and has three effects. The first is her being a pseudo-searcher upon getting Special Summoned (not just Fusion Summoned). Second is the effect that allows you to Special Summon a "Tearalaments" monster from your hand or GY by sending a monster you control to the GY (which can include herself). Lastly, if she's sent to the GY by a card effect, you can mill 5 cards off the top of your deck. Each of these three are hard once per turn effects.
  2. Kaleidoheart is the current boss monster of the Tearalaments, that requires 2 Aqua monsters and Tearalaments Rainoheart in particular, in which we only play 1 of because he's extremely recyclable due to us also playing the Branded engine. He cannot be used as Fusion Material, so that's neat against Mirror Matches. He has the effect that allows you to, upon him or another Aqua-type monster getting Special Summoned while he's on the field, target a card your opponent controls and shuffle it to the deck. If he's sent to the GY by a card effect, he can also Special Summon himself back and lets you send a "Tearalaments" card from your Deck to the GY. Both of his effects are all hard once per turns.
Final Thoughts: The first time I've read the Tearalaments cards I've immediately told myself, "If these cards' effects for a Fusion based archetype don't scream "we're definitely eventually going to receive a Shaddoll Fusion of our own", I don't know what does". Like, it's crazy that compared to the former lore-based archetype, Despias weren't as good initially, but Tearalaments... they only need an extremely good pay off and a consistent enabler, possibly in a form of a Fusion Spell, and trust that I will always be keeping an eye on this archetype with consistent and careful watch because I am extremely excited for this, so much so that it reminds me of the day Despias were initially released. As per usual, if you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.
Casual fun

deck_name: Splight - Frogs / Post Power of the Elements
deck_description: Since it's release, Splights take the OCG meta like a raging storm. Despite OCG and TCG being different formats, this particular archetype should be really successful in our format too.  The deck should be consistent, since Splight monsters special summon themselves when you control another level 2 monster card, thus easily allowing the start of your combo. The usual endboard is Toadally Awesome and Splight Elf for two Spell/Trap negates. You should use the Toad first and then revive him (providing that your opponent summons a monster) with Splight Elf's effect. Other notable cards for your endboard are Splight Red and Splight Carrot who provide monster and spell/trap negation respectively.  I should also note that the effect of Gigantic Splight effectively blocks your opponent from using Nibiru thanks to it's second effect

deck_excerpt: If you didn't like deep waters before, you sure won't now.
deck_description: If you didn't like deep waters before, you sure won't now.
Albaz Strike upgrade.

For combo tutorial, check out my previous build. I removed my second Chaos Ruler for a Samsara, because sometimes you need a level 5 Synchro Dark Dragon Monster to combo off and also I am playing currently 3x Resonator Command which pairs well with 11 Resonators, so you always get Crimson Resonator. Also I am playing 2x Red Reign, this card plus a level 8 or higher Dark Dragon Synchro Monster is almost an instant win against most decks.  For the spicy tech I am playing 1x Armageddon Knight, because this card plus Red Resonator is still access to Crimson Resonator. And I am playing 1x Stygian Street Patrol as a target for Armageddon Knight and also Ascator.
Fun/Casual Mathmech deck
Quickly getting out the various numbers
Pure go second dinos

deck_excerpt: Competitive version by @Ignister explaining some choices.
deck_description: My theory about some cards of this archetype has changed and now I see that this decklist is more competitive to use @Ignister. The deck strategy remains focused on its win condition through the "Towers" called The Arrival Cyberse @Ignister and for that the main deck and extra deck have an excellent synergy to do it with a 1 card combo engine. /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////The changes I made to the main deck were: Two Doyon @Ignister makes a lot of sense in the deck as it is the fundamental piece that allows you to make 1 Card Combo while maintaining good follow ups in the process. It is a good card to have in your starting hand and increases the consistency of the deck overall. The use of Hiyari @Ignister and Gatchiri @Ignister makes you able to play around Nibiru, the Primal Being, the only detail is that this is only possible in 2 Card Combo because the only way to add Hiyari to the hand is through Achichi @Ignister or a Cynet Mining and for that we should previously have a way to add the main combo pieces to the hand. I also think it's very important to have as many copies of Field Spell Ignister A.I.Land as possible because without it your plays are limited depending on having extenders like Gathiri or Hiyari to get somewhere and if your opponent is smart against @Ignister he will keep hand traps like Ash Blossom and Infinite Impermanence for the Dark Infant and Pikari preventing you from accessing the field. And the higher the stat of having 2 field Spells in your hand, the easier it is to use A.I. Contact which is an excellent consistency card. As for the Extra Deck I chose to use Update Jammer instead of Linguriboh but many players like to keep Linguriboh to have better chances against Floodgates and end up taking Light Dragon @Ignister from the decklist. I prefer to keep XYZ in the extra deck because it gives you the option to have one more target for the A.I. Meet You and it's a great card for the deck grind game because it doesn't matter how fast matches are in modern yugioh because there are decks competent enough to get you into a resource trading game and Light Dragon @Ignister will help you out a lot in these moments for being interaction with the opponent, protection of your monsters against destruction by effects and still helps to give OTK for giving Reborn of a LINK monster in the Battle Phase. About Fire Phoenix @Ignister my view on the card has changed a lot because before I thought Decode Talker Heatsoul was a much better card to use as a target for A.I. Meet You for having an excellent field effect that serves as a contingency plan in case your plays are stopped if you draw 1 card every turn. But Fire Phoenix @Ignister has very interesting applications in the deck: synergy with Achichi @Ignister in the Battle Phase to destroy an opponent's monster, it also inflicts 2300 effect damage to the opponent, has floating effect to return to the field if destroyed by effect of cards or battle. So in many situations it will be this card that will force interactions of the opponent's boss monsters like AA-ZEUS and in the near future the Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer than a Heatsoul. /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Combos: Differences between each Starter is basically in the first half of the combo which I say is how you arrive at the following gamestate: Splash Mage + Wind Pegasus + Doyon/Pikari = Achichi/Pikari/A. I. Meet You always end up arriving at this part of the combo and from then on it will be the same for everyone what to do next to get to TOWERS. Place the URL continuation on the duelingbook site after .com/ ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Combo 1: Achichi/Pikari 1 Card Combo (Towers 4k ATK) If you do Splash Mage first after Wicckid you can get Wind Pegasus very early in the combo which is better in most cases than waiting for the Dark Templar effect to wear off to do Wind Pegasus. Example with Achichi @Ignister: replay?id=621416-35878853 Gamestate: Towers (4k ATK) + Field /in Hand: A. I. Meet You /in GY: Wind Pegasus + Danmari (Don't Forget End Phase -2300damage if have used A. I. Meet You and not summoned the revealed card) //////////////////////////////////////////////// /////// Combo 2: How to make TOWERS without going through the Dark Templar? (Towers 3k ATK - SAFE ROTA) Example starting with A.I. Meet You from: replay?id=621416-35879497 Gamestate: Towers (3k ATK) + A.I. Reborn + Field /in Hand: Fire /in GY: Wind Pegasus (Don't Forget End Phase -2300damage if have used A. I. Meet You and not summoned the revealed card) Opponent's Turn: A. I. Reborn summon Bururu @Ignister and eff send Danmari @Ignister //////////////////////////////////////////////// /////// Combo 3: Bururu + A.I. Reborn (Towers 4k ATK) replay?id=621416-35882425 Gamestate: TOWERS (4k) + Dark + A.I. Reborn + Field /in Hand: Fire /in GY: Wind Pegasus + 2 Dark Infant (Don't Forget End Phase -2300damage if have used A. I. Meet You and not summoned the revealed card) Opponent's Turn: Reborn Bururu and eff Foolish Danmari (Negate) //////////////////////////////////////////////// /////// Combo 4: Achichi + Pikari (Play Around Nibiru) https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=621416-37613974 Gamestate: Arrival Cyberse (3k) + Field + Token /in Hand: A.I. Meet You /in GY: Wind Pegasus + Danmari (Don't Forget End Phase -2300damage if have used A.I. Meet You and not summoned the revealed card) //////////////////////////////////////////////// /////// Combo 5: Doyon + (any @Ignister monster that its not Pikari) (Example with Hiyari) https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=621416-37614279 Gamestate: Arrival Cyberse (4k) + Field /in Hand: Pikari(Follow Up) /in GY: Wind Pegasus (Don't Forget End Phase -2300damage if have used A.I. Meet You and not summoned the revealed card) (you could have added A.I.dle Reborn with Pikari @Ignister to reborn Doyon @Ignister and make Dark Templar @Ignister and add A.I.dle Reborn back to the hand with Doyon and make Dark Infant @Ignister using Wind Pegasus @Ignister to trigger the Dark Templar and the Dark Infant itself to reborn 3 monsters and make Arrival Cyberse with 5k Atk. The detail of this combo is that on the opponent's turn you use A.I.dle Reborn to bring Bururu @Ignister back to the field and send Danmari @Ignister to the GY, that is, you exchange Follow Up for interaction) (It depends on your Normal Summon to decide what to add with Pikari @Ignister to the hand, whether it's A.I. Meet You or A.I.dle Reborn for the combo to come out right, something you learn with practice) //////////////////////////////////////////////// /////// Combo 6: 1 Card Combo (Bomber Dragon Double Raigeki) replay?id=621416-35838685 Gamestate: Bomber Dragon + Light Dragon + Dark Infant + Field + A. I. Reborn /in Hand: Nothing /in GY: Linguriboh + Wind Pegasus (Don't Forget End Phase -2300damage if not summoned the revealed card) (Remember that Bomber Dragon doesn't let you attack with other monsters on the turn it uses its Raigeki effect) Bomber Dragon Combo is very good and your deck can practically do the same interaction as Double Raigeki's Prank-Kids Battle Butler. I'm just showing you that it's possible to make other end boards in turn 1 if you want to test it. /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Many games are decided on the details of some archetype cards that have very useful side effects and that the opponent doesn't pay enough attention to: Achichi @Ignister has the GY effect of banishing and destroying a Cyberse monster that is battling during the Damage Step, with this you avoid taking Battle Damage and survive a possible OTK from the opponent surprising him by winning another turn. In Master Duel this has happened to me twice: The first against a Numeron that summoned 4 monsters and thought it would OTK but couldn't. The second against a Zoodiac Tri-Brigade that did Accesscode + Shuraig in just 4 summons and left the LINK-1 Dark Infant on the field because it already had lethal and wanted to play around Infinite Impermanence but in the Battle Phase I used Achichi eff avoiding the OTK surviving the turn. Pikari @Ignister and Hiyari @Ignister manipulate levels to 4 until the end of the turn, with Piraki from any other @Ignister Monster like Wind Pegasus and Hiyari being his own level allowing you to make RANK-4 plays. Gatchiri has a continuous effect on the field to protect Cyberse monsters from being destroyed by card effects the first time each turn. It doesn't exist in Master Duel, but in the near future Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer (DPE) will come to the game so much that in the game banlist they already put Fusion Destiny at 2 thinking about this boss monster. This means you'll see much better with the in-game DPE how useful it is to take advantage of this Gatchiri protection while playing @Ignister which is another detail people forget about in the deck. Dark Infant can be made using any @Ignister other than LINK Monster. So you can use a Wind Pegasus or Light Dragon as material which is useful when you want to clear the Main Monster Zone and use the Ignister A.I.Land eff or to trigger Dark Templar eff from Soul Charge. Speaking of Dark Templar @Ignister you can use your Soul Charge effect during the Damage Step so a peculiar way to play around Nibiru is you Summon 3 Monsters to the field, make the Dark Templar and go to Battle Phase to attack and destroy an opponent's monster and trigger eff of Monster Reborn from the Dark Templar and then when you summon an arrow he points you bring 2 more @Ignister to start your Main Phase 2 making The Arrival Cyberse @Ignister. Nibiru, the Primal Being counts the summons made in all phases of the turn: Draw Phase, Standby Phase, Main Phase and Battle Phase but it can only use its effect during the Main Phase and as you have Turn Player Priority you start your Main Phase 2 making Towers playing around Nibiru. Sometimes the Danmari @Ignister hand effect can help you deal with floodgates. Once I was playing against Eldlich and my opponent flip Gozen Match on Dark Infant @Ignister summon, as I already had Doyon @Ignister in hand I used A.I. Meet You to add Danmari to the hand and then I LINK summon ladder to Cyberse Wicckid and bring Doyon back to the field with A.I.dle Reborn and in the Battle Phase I attacked Eldlich the Golden Lord and negated the attack with the Danmari effect just for him to enter the field and in Main Phase 2 to Accesscode Talker and destroy the Gozen Match. Gatchiri @Ignister only enters the field when targeting a Cyberse Monster and negating its effects, if the Cyberse monster's effects are already negated you won't even be able to activate Gatchiri's effect to enter the field, so in case you have for example the Achichi @Ignister on the field and would use it to make the Dark Infant @Ignister to add the Field Spell and the opponent has a set Infinite Impermanence saved to use in the Dark Infant effect because he knows it's much more important to prevent adding the Field Spell than a monster for the hand, thinking about this possibility of the Dark Infant being denied the best thing for you to do is use the effect of Gatchiri on Achichi to enter the field because if the Dark Infant has the effects negated you will lose the chance to bring in Gatchiri and continue to have plays on the turn. Achichi @Ignister only adds Level 4 or lower @Ignister monsters to the hand just like Dark Templar only Soul Charges Level 4 or lower GY monsters. The only ways to add Level 5 or higher @Ignister to the hand is when using Hiyari @Ignister eff or A.I. Meet You. /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Cards that have GY effects important to remember: As previously emphasized we have the effect of Achichi @Ignister on Damage Step and Fire Phoenix Floating eff on the next Standby Phase, we also have the most obvious effects that are the ones that no one forgets Wind Pegasus @Ignister and Danmari @Ignister that interact with the opponent and the Ignister A.I.Land to set back on the field. But the effects that are most overlooked are those of the deck's Reborn Spells - A.I.dle Reborn and FA.I.ghting Spirit. The quick play spell A.I.dle Reborn allows you when an attack is declared involving 2 monsters you banish it and a card from your hand to add an "A.I." Spell/Trap in the GY or banished to the hand. This is very important to remember with regards to adding an A.I. Land that was banned with Cosmic Cyclone back in hand or an A.I. Meet You who is in the GY during your opponent's turn and you don't have Follow Ups for your next turn, so it's another unexpected way to take advantage of these details of the various cards of @Ignister's archetype while your opponent doesn't even realize that when attacking your monsters is giving you a Follow Up. The FA.I.ghting Spirit banishes itself to protect its @Ignister of 23atk+ ATK from destruction by effects. And on top of that when being banned she activates her other effect of protecting your @Ignister from 23atk or more ATK from destruction per battle so there are several details that make the difference between winning and losing games with @Ignister. //////////////////////////////////////////////// /////// Disregard the Side Deck because it doesn't exist in Master Duel, I'm just showing other examples of tech cards that can be used in the main deck in place of some of the 15 spaces available in the main deck.

This deck was made with the upcoming Archetype: Labrynth. The Lab monsters search for traps and each other so during your opponents turn, and during the BP you can break a board with interruption.   Boss Monster - Labrynth Archfiend   Drawing Power - Pot of Prosp Extra deck consists of Fusions that you don't want to banish off of Pot of Prosp. They have GY effects for Dog Punish to escalate with. Your targets can literally be anything you want to sub in, but I chose Access Code and a random lol.   The idea is to set up to 4 back-row and work your way through the opponents board whilst getting out the Lab monsters. The Lab monsters then gain you advantage on summon by searching for added back-row, or Lab monsters. The field spell is amazing. Allowing you to pop a card if you use a specific Lab Trap card. Lab Archfiend is def the monster to get on board, it gains attack for each named trap in your GY. Easily becomes a wall, with a sizable booty to boot. Pairing this with the Lord of the Heavenly Prisoncard allows you to successfully accomplish the whole deck.

deck_name: My Dangerous! DAD from Dark World
deck_excerpt: Excited for the DAD ghost rare? Come look at some cool engines to splash it with!
deck_description:
Mostly a going second OTK deck that is super customizable and probably able to be played with 60 cards (Might post that later). The goal is summon DAD or Dark Armed Dragon. If you don't know this card it is an older meta staple being one of the only Teir 0 decks in the game (not being played with Armed Dragons). This is a fun card that sort of murders your opponent if they have no negates with an accesscode type effect for DARK monsters. If you don't like Danger! Dark world I suggest you play some of these engines or even all of them:
  • Phantom Knights
  • Burning Abyss
  • Destiny Hero &/or the DPE engine
  • Shaddolls
  • Bamboo Sword (a drawing engine using Equip Spells)
  • Raidraptor
  • Maybe even blackwings
  • Brave/Adventurer (note: it doesn't use DARK monsters)
  • Chaos
  • Zombies
  • Lair of Darkness
  • Resonators (Maybe even use the Red Dragon Archfiend Ghost Rare as well)
  • Gren Maju type deck with cards like Gizmek Orochi and Eater of Millions.
  • Red-Eyes
  • Dark Magician (Maybe Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon)
  • Thunder Dragon
Of course you can make the deck your own by making it  mix between the engines or some not mentioned too. I chose Danger!s because they are a great monster draw engine consiting of DARK monsters and Dark Worlds for even more draws, PLUS they totally break boards using Grapha and Bigfoot then lastly you can summon DAD to clean up the rest of the board! And lastly for Side deck I suggest running Danger! Thunderbird not included in the deck list because I wanted to keep it at 40. Run kaijus probably so you can out the negates to stop your DAD board wipe and probably Lightning Storm and Feather Duster. For the rest run whatever you want! Some other recommended cards are: Apollousa, Black Luster Soldier Link, Voloferniges, the Darkest Dragon Doomrider, either of the borrel link monsters (even possibly savage). Have fun and good luck pulling the DAD ghost rare!

deck_excerpt: halq combo I made that ends on borreload savage dragon + baronne de fleur
deck_description: halq -> deskbot 001 -> auroradon (summon 3 tokens) -> deskbot -> quandax -> tribute 2 tokens to summon coltwing, 2 tokens summoned, deskbot comes back  board is now auroradon, quandax (level 4), 2 level 3 tokens, coltwing (level 10), deskbot 001 (level 1)  synch quandax and a token to get power tool (grab living fossil), now you have auroradon, coltwing (level 7), deskbot 001 (level 1), 1 level 3 token, and power tool dragon (level 7)  xyz dracossack with power tool and coltwing, synch into cupid pitch using token + deskbot, increase level by 1 with its effect  now the board is auroradon, dracossack, cupid pitch (lv 5)  proc dracossack effect, detaching coltwing to summon 2 tokens, deskbot comes back  board is auroradon, dracossack, 2 level 3 tokens, deskbot, pitch (level 5)  synch pitch and a token to get savage, targeting halq in grave to equip to savage, and grabbing caligo claw crow off of pitch  now you have auroradon, dracossack, 1 level 3 token, deskbot, and savage dragon  living fossil back mecha phantom beast coltwing, synch deskbot and a token into another quandax, special claw crow from hand, synch claw crow, quandax, and coltwing into baronne  end on board with Mecha Phantom Beast Auroradon and Dracossack, Borreload Savage Dragon, and Baronne De Fleur. if you started combo with e tele then you still have your normal summon for whatever you want.

deck_excerpt: A Banish Deck with Gigarays Gandora as an extra way to win.
deck_description:
This is basically a banish deck but I also threw Gandora in there, and in order for Gandora to work as well as possible I also threw in a few Lightsworn. If you know how a banish deck works, you know how this deck works. Just read over the effects of cards you're not sure of. Also keep in mind that you want to go second with this deck since it's an OTK deck and not a negate deck. The only First Turn Play that's super useful is summoning Draglubion and than using Draglubion's effect to summon Hope Harbinger, since that negates one spell card. A few notes to keep it easier if you are not familiar with some of these cards ( I sure as hell wasn't) Gigarays Gandora: You want one of this card in the Graveyard and one other Gandora in the graveyard when you summon this card, you than banish literally everything on the field and can directly attack your opponent with like 10,000 atk. Gizmek Makami: When this monster is normal or special summoned, you can discard one card and search for any of your boss monsters (Gizmek Orochi, Gigarays Gandora and Gren Maju). You can also normal summon this card if you have at least 10 cards banished. This is probably your best deck search and draw power, though the utility of Allure of Darkness and Pot of Desires is not lost on me. At the end of the day this deck has 3 win conditions
  1. Gigarays Gandora banishing everything but itself on both fields and hitting ridiculously hard
  2. Gren Maju hitting ridiculously hard
  3. Getting two 8 star monsters on the field, summoning Draglubion and using its effect to summoning Numeron Dragon to hit... ridiculously hard
This is probably how I would build a springans deck with the current format.

deck_excerpt: Fossil Adamancipator deck profile April 2022 feat. Aussa the Earth Channeler
deck_description: Do you like tomboys? Do you like girls with glasses? If you said "yes" to either question, you're a man of culture, and you're gonna love this Fossil Adamancipator deck's tech option, Aussa the Earth Channeler! You can discard her and another EARTH monster to search an EARTH Rock or Spellcaster monster with 1850 or less ATK. In most cases, you're gonna want to use her to search Mathemetician, and then normal summon him to dump Weathering Soldier, and finally use Weathering Soldier's effect to search either Fossil Fusion or a card that mentions it.     Strategy-wise, this is a go-second deck, so you would prefer to do that. But thanks to the Adamancipator engine, you can potentially sit on a 4-negate Apollousa. If you're going second, not only do you have 9 hand traps, but also 2 Cosmic Cyclones and Harpie's Feather Duster.     I decided to name this deck "Iwaki Fossil Park" after the Iwaki Coal Mine and Fossil Museum, located in Iwaki, Japan. This facility features a replica of a coal mine and educates tourists on Iwaki's history of coal mining, and has a beautiful and extensive array of dinosaur skeletons and fossils! So if you're interested in the mining industry, or you're a bit of a dino nerd, then you're really gonna get a kick out of the place. Currently, Japan has not yet opened its borders to tourists, but hopefully that will change soon.

This Normal/Rare Cyberse deck for the Master Duels event is centered around summoning Link Monsters by playing special summon monsters such as Parallel eXceed and Backup Secretary, with some fusion monsters splashed in for versatility's sake with Diplexer Chimera in case you know your opponent will be using Spells/Traps and Earth Golem @Ignister to deal with beefier monsters in the opponents Extra Monster Zone, both having good value when being eventually destroyed in battle refunding creatures you spent to summon them. The typical win condition is trying to summon  Encode Talker, Powercode Talker, and/or Shootingcode Talker depending on who may be best to summon, with Agave Dragon acting simply as a large beatstick in case you need raw power.

deck_excerpt: Use Clear World to subdue your opponent then use your Ace monsters to win the duel.
deck_description: The Clear archetype (from the Anime, used by Yusuke Fujiwara) Deck concept is about crippling the opponent with “Clear World” depending on which Attributed monster they control on the field, also having cards to change the monsters attributes. Clear monsters on the other hand let you bypass all the detrimental effects leaving the opponent to suffer all the negative effects. Although only 2 cards were ever printed on the archetype in the TCG/OCG, I was able to build this deck revolving around its concept about Attributes with another archetype which is.. Shaddolls! They work surprisingly well with each other maybe not top tier, but it is usable and fun. It's probably the closest thing that you'll ever get to be playing the Anime version of this deck until support cards come out. Your main focus is to have your Field Spell Clear World & go into your Aces, using "Shaddoll Fusion" summoning "El Shaddoll Winda" (sending a Shaddoll monster and "Clear Vice Dragon" to the GY since it is a DARK monster) which will restrict Special Summons and either Special or Tribute Summon CVD while Clear World is keeping you and your monsters safe by battle. Winda provides a great field presence with its own immunity to destruction effects, but not without its low stats keeping it in check. So it may have a hard time attacking, being attacked or doing a lot of dmg, that is why you have CVD, they make a great duo partner with each other, Clear Vice Dragon may look weak, but here's the thing, all of its effect are continous & do not start a chain, it has its own Unique protection effect of destruction (which is not a cost by the way) and it does all the battling for Winda beating over your opponent's Beefy High ATK Boss monsters, when You Attack it gains Double the ATK of that monster (During Dmg Calculation Only). It can beat almost any monster by battling such as; "Number S39: Utopia the Lightning", "Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon", "Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax", "Raidraptor Ultimate Falcon", "Black Wing Full Armored Master", and etc.. A pretty neet monster althought, it's not OP and is still vulnarble, but it gets the job done when needed. Using the Trap card DNA Transplant with your Field Spell or Super Poly are great going for the DARK Attribute since it has more of a field presence than the other attributes, although yes you won't be able to Attack, that is why it is important to bring out CVD as SOON as possible since You as the player are "Unnaffected by the effects of Clear World" OR you can just set another Clear World to avoid the detrimental effects in your turn then activate it once again when you're done battling (A alternative win condition could also be done with the Trap card DNA Transplant by declaring the FIRE Attribute, If it comes down to finishing off your opponent when you can't Attack for game just simply burn them for 1000 Dmg, only activate it During you opponent's End Phase for Clear World to trigger the element of surprise on them). Using the Spell card "Super Polymerization", can also help remove almost any of your opponents problematic monsters along the way. For duels going up against a pure DARK Attributed monsters, you may side deck DNA for more useful cards that you may need for the duel, they'll be bricks because you'll be going for the DARK Attribute 99% of the time anyways for those non DARK decks. If you liked the Deck Profile, Please leave a Like & Comment. Also check out my Youtube video that I posted of this deck down below! You may also feel free to add me on Discord if you have any questions, NEXUS#6644
Link

Wetlands beatdown is most certainly an interesting deck to say the least. As the name suggests, the deck focuses around the field spell Wetlands, a card that is rather specific as conditions are concerned, but the attack boost it provides is extremely substantial. The ability to turn any 0/0 into a 1200/0 is a big game changer. there aren't many ways to search it out so terraforming and metaverse will just have to do. 5 copies of a card is good, don't get me wrong, but it's not as consistent as something like Umi Goodstuff. (i'm working on a list for that so keep an eye out) This deck also centers around a few other cards. The aquarium spells are important as they do multiple different things, 1: they provide an additional stat boost. 2: they provide some protection for your monsters. and 3: they provide a little recursion when destroyed. along with those cards, Cryomancer and Dewdark of the ice barrier are both pretty strong cards for the deck, Cryomancer being a walking gravity bind, and Dewdark just attacking directly for big damage if you have wetlands on board. all of the other cards in the deck aren't as important but they do serve a purpose, most of them are pretty obvious. Now go on out there and beat people to death with the fabled M I S T A R  B O Y

deck_excerpt: Dragon Waifus are officially the best Dragon deck, because God decided this earth was not strange and terrible enough ;)
deck_description: So, this is where we are at right now - the most competitive versions of Dragons is Dragon Waifus. When I first started playing, this would have seemed ridiculous. Part of it is that the archetype got a new sweet boss monster, the Omni-Negate value-engine that tags out - part of it is the broken trap and the new broken starter - but mostly, this deck was waiting for the metagame to shift, and for players who believed in the deck to develop it.  I'm not an amazing Dragonmaid player, but I love me some Dragon decks, and I genuinely think Dragon Waifus is not just the best Dragon deck, but the best home for the Rokket package right now in the Master Duel meta. I have been working on this for a little bit, and I think I have this engine humming right now, so I wanted to share it.  The interruptions in the format are pretty standard. Maxx "C" is kinda nutso, and Ash answers Maxx "C" - Called By is also nutso even in the absence of Maxx "C" and if one of the few great answers to the sneaky insect. I don't love Ash tbh, but so long as it is a Maxx "C" meta these cards seem pretty standard and essential. After that all I'm doing is leaning on in-engine interaction and extra-deck utility monsters.  So, for Maid form Dragonmaids I'm on 7 - 3 Chamber, 3 Parlor, and 1 Nurse. Chamber and Parlor are kind of your Aleister - they both have good setups into Hieratic Seal, they both search the Fusion spell for Fusion set-ups, which is important since Sheou is the deck's main game plan. In this deck, they also can help set up Romulus plays, which is pretty rad. Chamber is mostly better than Parlor, but they're at their best when you activate both in the same turn, so the deck is built to do that. It would be nice if Kitchen also worked as a decent starter, but in practice I'd rather cut it - it doesn't have a lot of great setups, and isn't a 1-card boss monster like these other starters. Nurse, on the other hand, is kind of awesome - it'll help make the god plays possible with Foolish effects, and is summonable off of Seal for incredible value. The main value in Parlor over Chamber is sending the Dragon Form high-level monsters from the deck to the GY, but it does enable a bunch of weird set-ups. I'd love more starts into these cards, since they are my main engine, but for now that means reliance on other 2 card combo engines.  I also knew I needed high-level Dragon monsters to make Sheou with, and I wanted a good solid package of 5. 1 Absorouter makes so much sense - getting to start plays by summoning Sheou, then searching Tracer is kinda cray, and this card being in the deck also makes Tracer searchable using the Extra Deck. You also do need high-level Dragonmaids to tag out into - I like 2 Lorpar, because going second the card is extremely good, but 1 Ernus seems fine. You could put whatever you wanted in the last slot really, but I like using Chaos Dragon Levianeer going second to break board, and it'll occasionally get a snipe going first. It also is just fine as Fusion material from the hand if you can't summon it. I shifted out a Lorpar into Nurdyle, which seems good so far.  I'm running 5 Fusion Spells, but you have a lot of access to the main one with the 6 other Dragonmaids - you want to see exactly one copy of these so you don't have to search is, so again, you run 5. Dragonmaid Changeover is the best generic poly available in Dragonmaids, and in addition to its Fusion effect not being once per turn, it also can enable loopy nonsense that is both value and interruptive when you see it, so the risk of running multiples is low while the payoff of seeing a copy is huge. if you wanted to you could run Verte and 1 copy of Poly, which will mostly just be Changeover for all intents and purposes, but in testing it never came up because it was always a bad value play. You could also run Despia, Theatre of the Branded, as all of your Fusion Monsters meet the criteria for summoning, but this build runs 2 other Fields and is trying to grind with either/or. Dragon's Mirror is busted, and when things are going well the card is insane, but it is bad in multiples and the low-end Mirror makes very sad Sheous with no friends. Changeover is just the best Dragon Fusion support card in general, anyways.  So, for Rokkets, we have 2 Tracer, 1 Silverr, and 1 Magna. You can actually trigger the Magna and Silverr with Hieratic Seal or Borrelsword, which is nice, but the real reason for 2 searchable Rokkets off of Tracer is that they come up in the grind game, and that doing so enables more turn 1 Rokket combos. I'm also on 1 Quick Launch, and 1 Boot Sector Launch. This might seem weird, but remember, we only need access to 1 Tracer, and we're trying to get some more consistency in another way. I like this engine a lot, even if it isn't entirely necessary. One thing to note is that, while you can, and occasionally should, pop your own field spell with Tracer, it is often better just to leave it up for the threat of the grind game, whichever one you've ended on.  So, the main consistency for all of these combos comes with the weird little thing we're doing with the rest of the deck. Foolish Burial and Dragon Shrine are effectively copies of the same card you can activate on the same turn in this deck, and Ravine gives us a searchable third copy, with the downside/occasional upside of coming with a discard, and being easily searchable. Meanwhile, Nurse Dragonmaid revives Dragonmaids sent to the GY for value, Hospitality does the same but with a free send often attached, and Monster Reborn is a hyper generic card that also allows access to the dragons sent off the sending package, as does World Legacy Guardragon, at least for the purposes of summoning Rokkets and low-level Maids.  Lastly, we have 3 Tidying. We're really leaning on these and on the weird activation cost of Hieratic Seal to out floodgates and give us game against dump floodgate decks - we also need a lot of this card, since it'll be sent to the GY to enable the extension of plays, and since it is a stupid busted trap and a big part of the decks viability. It's the dumb trap you search out, but since often enough you'll have to search out a Fusion spell, you want to see this anyways.  This deck can put up pretty insane boards - Sheou + Seal is still your bread and butter, but you'll add a Savage to that often enough. Many hands get to choose between Sheou + Savage and Sheou + Seal. Some get to choose between Sheou or Savage + Seal. You'll also sometimes make God boards. You can also Otk, break boards fine, and grind like a mofo, and going for the Ravine / Reanimate route has opened up some truly insanely broken opening plays that may be better than Dragon Links best god boards in a world with Pisty but not Elpy. Also, Tidying is nuts.

deck_excerpt: If only the Adventure Package didnt cost as much as my student loans...
deck_description:
The aim of the game is simple... get out Sunseed Genius Loci (the Normal Monster) out on the field as fast as possible. From there, your plays should be able to quickly blossom into a sticky board consisting of a bounce, a one-sided blanket negate, and an easy OTK on the follow-up. With the Adventure package, this deck becomes more resilient to those pesty handtraps that once stopped this deck in its tracks and allows for a better endboard as well.   Here is a basic one-card combo (All you need is Sunseed Genius Loci):
  1. Summon the seed
  2. Go into Sunavalon Dryas (Link 1)
    1. Search "Sunvine Sowing" from Deck
      1. If you have one in hand just search "Sunvine Shrine"
  3. Activate Sunvine Sowing and Special Summon Sunseed Shadow from Deck
    1. When you take 1000 damage, use Dryas to summon Sunvine Healer from Extra Deck
  4. Go into Sunavalon Daphne with Sunseed Shadow and Sunvine Healer
  5. Use Shadow's GY effect to Special Summon your second copy of Sunavalon Daphne from the Extra Deck
  6. Use the newly summoned Sunavalon Daphne and the Dryas to summon Sunavalon Melias (in middle column)
    1. Use Melias to revive Sunseed Genius Loci from GY
  7. Use the Genius Loci to summon another Dryas
    1. Search out "Sunvine Shrine" (not a once per turn)
  8. Activate Shrine to revive Genius Loci
  9. Use Melias (Link 3) and Dryas (Link 1) to go into Sunavalon Dryatrentiay (Link 4) in EMZ
    1. Search "Sunavalon Bloom" from Deck (this is your main negation piece)
  10. Use the Genius Loci and the Daphne to Link Summon another Melias
    1. Use Melias to revive Genius Loci (again)
  11. Use Genius Loci and Melias to bring out Benghalancer the Resurgent (this is your bounce)
On the follow-up, you should be able to use Dryatreniay to tribute Benghalancer and pop 4. Use Benghalancer's GY effect to summon itself back (make sure it is under Dryatreniay). Then use your Shrine to revive your seed to then go into Sunvine Thrasher (Link 1) and OTK.

deck_excerpt: The format warping super-threat in a cheap format!
deck_description: Kaijus and summoning Ablaz fusions, fun! You go second. Also feel free to change whatever,  I'm no expert deck builder and have barely tested this Card Choices Jizukiru and Thunderking: Kaijus are core part to this deck's functionality.  Kaijus are not only great board breakers for this tower-building format, but they can also be used as material for Fallen of Albaz to Summon any Albaz Fusion Monster.  They can even be used with Monster Reborn to get easier OTKs.  Jizukiru and Thunderking as specifically good because they are LIGHT Monsters so they can be used as material for Albion the Branded Dragon, a Fusion Monster that just let's you summon another Fusion Monster! Radian: Similar to Jizukiru and Thunderking but you can beat over this one and use it for material for Dragostapelia. Albion the Shrouded Dragon: It both dumps a Albaz to the GY for your reborn spells and acts as an upstart goblin! He's also not a bad discard for albaz and can even be Summoned with Branded Bond, and used as material for Branded in White. Pankratops: Excellent going 2nd tool for removal, can be either used as removal or extra damage for an OTK. Thunder Dragon:  Deck thins, Provides discards for Albaz and Twin Twister, and can be used as a LIGHT material for Summoning Albion the Branded Dragon with Branded in White Fallen of Albaz:  THE MASCOT HIMSELF ALBAZ!.  The reason for why this Deck even works is because Albaz outs large threats easily and turns them into powerful Fusion Monsters that you can use to beat your opponent to death!  Albaz is usually best paired with a kaiju so that you can guarantee a Fusion Monster. Summoner Monk: The deck runs a fair amount of spells, especially ones that are prone to bricking so this is a great way of getting an Albaz. Branded Bond: Great follow-up after dumping and albaz, extends/opens your OTK.  It's second effect even comes up sometimes, but it's rare.  You can float into it with Albion the Branded Dragon Branded In White: Fantastic Extender for if you cannot Summon an Albion the Branded Dragon, and can be used to even open up situations where you cannot make a play. A good card to float into with Albion the Branded Dragon Pot of Desires: Great consistency.  Pray that you don't banish all of your Albazes though. Pot of Extravagance: Great consistency because Albaz targets are the only thing worth playing in this Deck's Extra Deck.  It does have some negative synergy with desires and Albion the Shrouded Dragon but you can always discard bricks. Foolish Burial: Dumps Albaz, and sometimes maybe a big kaiju Monster Reborn: Excellent extender, especially with all of your cards that dump Albaz in the Deck. Harpie's Feather Duster: This Deck inherently has little answers to backrow so you want to run a good amount of backrow removal, and harpie's feather duster was the best Twin Twister: 2nd best backrow removal, this deck has a lot of discard fuel as well Cosmic Cyclone: 3rd best backrow removal. Called by Grave: Negates handtraps and is very versitile, great card in almost every deck. Extra Deck Card Choices Predaplant Dragostapelia: He's not an Albaz Fusion but you can summon him with a Branded Albion or Branded in White.  He's great because he's basically a monster negate every turn. Sprind the Irondash Dragon: He has some tricky materials if you don't use a kaiju specifically, but he does move and destroy cards every turn so he is pretty good if you can summon him. He floats into Albaz like most of the other Albaz Dragons. Brigrand the Glory Dragon: Probably the least useful Fusion but he is still an Albaz Fusion.  His battle protection is pretty good but his targeting protection is pretty mid (as the kids say). He floats into Albaz like most of the other Albaz Dragons. Titaniklad the Ash Dragon:  It's the best beater you got so you'll probably go into him often. He floats into Albaz like most of the other Albaz Dragons. Albion the Branded Dragon: Hard to just summon with Albaz alone but he's definitely worth it.  He just allows you Summon another Fusion Monster upon being Summoned so you can get some pretty good beats going on.  He also has a unique and fantastic float effect where he adds/sets a "Branded" Spell/Trap from your deck (Which can be Branded in White for yet another Fusion Summon)
A Dragon Link deck I'm working on, its nothing particularly special yet. Still toying around with the extra deck and side deck, witch is why it looks awful.

deck_excerpt: Ever wanted to destroy meta decks with dragoon? how about Destroy your opponents with a deck that took 10 years to fully come out? Well this is the de
deck_description: G'day everyone! I am back with a new deck list for everyone wanting to play a mostly pure ice barrier deck! Ice barrier since starting the game has been phenomenal to play, and i love to see people get dominated by it. Making it all the way to platinum using this deck beating out even the strongest of decks.  First off, we are going to start off with the basic strategies of this deck and move into the more complex ones.  Revealer is good. Revealer is great infact. if you get revealer on the board and it isn't negated, you have the whole deck as your oyster(pun intended(i like water decks)) Or atleast the tuners, as discarding for cost can be tricky, most of the time the best thing to do is to get the winds over the ice barrier into the graveyard to prepare for the next turn, bringing revealer back into your hand for round 2 Frost bite boogaloo. Sometimes you want to get one of your other ice barrier monsters in the grave so you can use Freezing chains of the monster reborn to quickly get it up for a combo, getting either zero dragon, White aura whale, White aura bihamut, crystal wing synchro dragon or just a plain ol' Stealth kragen.  basic two card combo is Revealer normal summoned, special summon either silent sea nettle, speaker for the ice barrier or general wayne if playing turn two and your opponent has a monster out. From there have two monsters on the field with possible outcomes being 2 level 4s or 1 level 4 and 1 level 5, you can decide what card you want to bring out with good ol' revealer's effect. Let me show you my thinking Going second and 2 or more cards on the field? and you have general wayne out? Hexa spirit of the ice barrier, use it's effect for level 2, synchro Trishula, Zero Dragon of the Ice Barrier out and banish those cards!  Going first? with 2 level 4s you have 3 options to go, You can use the effect of revealer bring out hexa spirit, make it level 2 using it's own effect, then summon coral dragon, with coral dragon out and a level 4 you are just one special summon away from big boy Bihumat himself! With 3300 Attack and 3000 defence, even if your opponent summons out dragoon, you can take it down with a brute force swing to it's head! Another option is to go for a Number 4: Stealth Kragen, this sets you up for a really early interrupt of your opponents plans by destroying any normal summon or pretty much anything really, non target, quick effect destroy with damage of half the attack ontop? sign me the fudgesickle up!  Now, are you going second, your revealer's effect has been interrupted, and you have a speaker for the ice barrier out, and not being locked to only summoning water monsters? Then here is the scary combo that got a lyrilusc card limited to 1. Ram your kragen into the enemy monster, summon out two spawns, with those two spawns, use them to XYZ summon into a utopic Future, then XYZ summon into Utopic Draco Future. i know right, Utopic Draco future in an Ice barrier deck?! You heard it here first! this is an amazing card and super easy to get out on your first turn!  We run the Mistar boy for a couple of reasons, when we get crackdown, and you have a stealth kragen up, you have only water monsters on the field. so link it away with a token generated by the effects of a speaker in the graveyard!  To get the crystal wing synchro dragon out is tricky. You need to be able to do it without locking yourself into water. the way to do that is to have speaker for the ice barrier and a hexa spirit. You start off by summoning the hexa spirit, then special summon the speaker, use effect of hexa spirit and send a level 3 to the grave, then synchro into gungnir, you may use the effect of gungnir if you have cards to spare, then use the freezing chains of the monster reborn, get that little hexa back out to then slap him to the grave with a fresh summon of the Crystal wing Synchro dragon!  If you are going second, and you want to mess your opponent up big time, you can! You need 3 cards with one more to discard. Revealer, Speaker and Wayne. if your oppoonent has a monster out, you can summon wayne, so Normal summon revealer, Special summon the speaker and wayne, search any spell you want from wayne, then you use the effects of Revealer. Get ou the little defender of the ice barrier or hexa spirit and discard warlock. XYZ summon Stealth Kragen with revealer and speaker. Synchro summon White aura whale with level 3 tuner and wayne, destroy their monsters in attack position and pierce the rest! You have 2 extra lives on the whale, so don't worry about him getting destroyed. Then turn after, if they haven't destroyed or they have destroyed the stealth kragen but you have 2 spawns, well guess what, you have a combo for the utpoic Draco future!  Silent sea nettle is a massive card, being able to return our defender for special summon for revealer, return the stealth kragen and spawns for a second sticky minion, and you have the ability to return any of the synchros except for crystal wing synchro dragon.  Here is the kicker. This deck sucks against a negate, not really if it stays on the field, like imperm, but if it is negated and destroyed, you have going to have a hard time getting everything back out without having a freezing chains in hand. Even then, it can be rough. I know it isn't easy, but i know you can do it, i know you can all power through!  Play around with the deck, i have tried to look at many different ways to improve it, and if you find any be sure to tell me, either message me on here, or jump into my stream Twitch.tv/Merlin_the  Thank you all for coming to my Yugi Talk
