deck_excerpt: A fun deck for Casual Play. Summon the Omni-Negate, Stardust Dragon/Assault Mode. Figure out the best strategy to play the deck. Hardcore vibes, let's
deck_description:
Welcome to the first set of my structure deck series. The series was inspired by my evaluation of certain archetypes I had played for quite some time in order to at least understand the basic mechanism in a specific period of time.This is, of course, not an official structure deck, I'm just unable to think of a better name.

Let's just head right into the deck. The first set, "Structure Deck: Assault Emergency" is an Assault Mode-based deck. Some people probably say that Assault Mode is inherently bad, and I myself admit that it lacks what it takes to be a top deck, at least for now (although Konami seems to have abandoned this archetype, not giving any helpful support since 2019). The best buff they ever gave so far was probably making Emergency Teleport turn to Unlimited (3) status.

GENERAL STRATEGY

So, you see, there's actually no particular innate strategy available in the archetype itself, except by continuously relying on the combo of Psi-Reflector to Special Summon our Boss Monsters. The best we could do (without brainstorming with deckbuilding and further advancement and also wasting even more time) is to create our own strategy and spend most of the time relying on decisions and field analysis. It's pretty important for Assault Mode users, as the only factor I could find to make Assault Mode stand a chance is an experienced and wise duelist.

If you do not like to read card effects (at least for the cards you are not familiar with), you better start playing other archetypes instead of this one. It's going to be rough for you otherwise. Decision-making is very crucial. In this deck, you can say that the Extra Deck is our main arsenal, and the Main Deck is a tool to access it. I've been watching countless videos and brainstorming for quite a while (credit to DarkArmedDuelist's video), and I think I have found a decent arrangement for the deck. So let's just head to the explanation section about why I chose each of 'em.

Oh wait, one more thing. This is also important, yet a minor warning. First, this deck description section of mine might take a decent amount of time to read and even somewhat will possibly make you disappointed in the end (both because of the deck or my explanation, which may be proved to be a waste of time). Second, for dueling tips while using this deck of mine, please stop being a subjective duelist who wants to win climaxly if you do, because it's not going to work with this deck. You better finish your opponent as fast as possible and quietly, while you still have a chance. My gameplay so far has taught me that Assault Mode doesn't really stand a chance against most of the meta or top tier rogue decks in general, because of the fact that you can normally only summon 1 Boss Monster per turn via Psi-Reflector. But hey, my friend said that this deck of mine would make it to a mid-tier rogue deck. It's quite fun to play, too. Anyway, to the explanation section!

DECK MEMBERS

MAIN DECK

A. Monsters

1) Stardust Dragon/Assault Mode

First off, our Boss Monster. If you've been playing the game for quite a while or intend on using the AM deck, I'm pretty sure you have at least heard of this card. Right, SDAM is one of the better Assault Mode monsters. I mean, look. It's an Omni-Negate, you can also get a free SD when this card is destroyed. SDAM is probably the best AM monster (at least in pure Assault-Engine-based decks) due to its powerful effect and ease of summoning. You just need to bring up Stardust Dragon, which is already one of the easiest AM materials to summon and Assault Mode Activate it. This powered-up version of SD is indeed powerful, but not without any weaknesses. One, the main weakness will be the fact that the AM Engine is fragile and can easily be destroyed by a single disruptive force. Two, this card is very vulnerable during its effect activation. Although you can use this card to negate, your opponent can also continue the chain and destroy this card easily. Three, cards like Called By The Grave are simply the natural enemy of SD and its AM counterpart. They not only prevented this card from returning after activating its effect, you also simply lost that free SD I mentioned. Five, this card is USELESS if you draw it from your deck. It's as if you literally skip 1 Draw Phase if you draw this card. The only way to fix this is to simply discard it for effect activation or use it via Assault Mode Zero.

Lastly, SDAM is very easy to bait. You need to use the effect very wisely. The card is a gun with only 1 bullet. Choose the cards to negate wisely.

2) Psi-Reflector

Here comes our star. You definitely can't run an AM deck without this little Tuner fellow. This card carries the whole Assault Engine and the AM Engine itself revolves around this card. When this card is summoned, you can add 1 AM Activate or any monster that lists it in their card texts. Then, you can reveal AM Activate from your hand to trigger this card's ultimate effect. You can Special Summon 1 monster that has "AM Activate" in its card text, and increase its level up to 4. With this effect, you can definitely access most of the level 6 to 9 Synchro Monsters. This card is also easily searchable via other deck members. Too bad, this card can only activate its effect once per turn, leading the deck to only be able to summon 1 Boss Monster consistently per turn if it was not negated (this is also very negatable). Make sure you use your resources efficiently to create a straight path (remove all possible threats on the field) for this card to shine.

3) Assault Sentinel

The 2nd best assault monster after the Psi-Reflector. This card can be used to search for Psi-Reflectors and even prepare a target for its effect (since this card will go straight to the GY). Another effect of this card can change a monster's attribute via an Extra Deck monster's attribute. This effect is a great addition to Psi-Reflector, allowing you to access even more Synchro Monsters with more restricting material lists. The backlash, is that you can't Special Summon any monster this turn except Synchro Monsters (a few other cards also have a similar restriction). Not really a problem for this deck.

4) Assault Beast

A searcher for AM Activate. You only need one in your deck. Since you can easily search for this card via Psi-Reflector, and even Assault Sentinel gives more beneficial effects than this card. Still pretty useful, though, in certain situations.

5) Ascator, Dawnwalker & Fire Ant Ascator

For time-sake, I will make things shorter. Maybe you should read the card effects to understand what I will say. Both cards are a pair. Have a similar restriction as Assault Sentinel. These pairs are the alternatives to the Psi-Reflector. With only the Psi Reflector, you can only summon 2 Boss Monsters at the very best. With this pair, you get the 3rd. I recommend either discarding useless SDAM or AM Zero, or any less useful card for your situation.

6) PSY-Framegear Gamma (w/PSY-Frame Driver) & Ash Blossom and Joyous Spring

Our main handtrap force on the deck. The PSY-Frame Driver is recycleable, so you only need 1. Just make sure you won't make it banished unless you're forced to, since it's no longer recycleable in that situation. And yeah.. some classic Ash Blossom. I believe I don't need any further exposition. The PSY-Frame pair can even be an alternative to summoning another Boss Monster, if you manage to activate it in your own turn, or chain it with the Synchron Formula available in your Side Deck (A pretty rare case).

7) Nibiru, The Primal Being & Gameciel, The Sea Turtle Kaiju

Uh huh. Other classic cards. These two cards are useful for getting rid of some monsters your opponent controls by tributing them. Use them wisely, and make sure you have something in your sleeve to destroy them later, since you definitely don't want your cards to be used against you. Pay special attention to Nibiru, since its stats are determined by the monsters it tributed.

B. Spells

1) Assault Mode Zero

Finally, we're done with the monsters. Next, our spells. Start with AM Zero. It's a card you don't want to run more than 1 copy in your deck. You only need one in this deck, really. You can use this card to get rid of those annoying SDAMs in your hand, so that they can finally get some use. You can also get this card in your GY banished, so you can set AM Activate and immediately activate it this turn. This card is a perfect target for Ascator pairs or any cards that require discarding. The starthand combo is to discard this card by the Ascator effect and then Synchro Summon SD, and use this effect to immediately summon our SDAM on your very first turn.

2) Emergency Teleport

A very useful searcher card. Use this card to search for either Psi-Reflector or Psy-Framegear (most of the time, the first one), and Bam. You get yourself into the engine's core that easily. The effect is simple, but believe me. You need to run 3 copies of this card, to ensure the highest consistency of the Psi-Reflector combo. Getting this in your starting hand can also mean 1 card combo to Synchro Boss Monsters.

3) Fire Formation - Tenki

Thanks to Tri-Brigade, this card made it to limited status. But eh, 1 is fine. Still, increase the consistency of Psi-Reflector via searching for Assault Sentinel and calling out our main star. This card can also be considered a 1-card combo. It really is a lifesaver, especially if you start with none of the combo starters.

4) One For One

Another card to increase consistency. I think I need no further explanation for its use.

5) Monster Reborn

It may be useful in certain situations (e.g. to summon Synchro Monsters with tighter summoning difficulties such as Crystal Wing, to get extra materials, or revive any useful card in the GY, and many more).

6) Twin Twisters & Called By The Grave

Cards for extra disruptive force. You can also use them to ensure Psi Reflector's combo succession.

C. Traps

1) Assault Mode Activate

AM Activate is needed to summon Stardust Dragon AM and Red Dragon Archfiend AM. You won't need more than 2 copies. Too bad it's a trap card. Anyway.......

2) Back To The Front

It's basically a trap version with a similar role as Monster Reborn. Use it to extend your capability of summoning stronger Boss Monsters. The combo that I can think of is using this card after the effect of Psy-Framegear is resolved, to Special Summon Formula Synchron, and give some elements of surprise. I believe you guys have better creativity than mine. Feel free to replace this card with any better card you know.

3) Solemn Judgement & Infinite Impermanence

Handtrap disruptive force and Omni-Negate. Although Solemn Judgement comes with a painful cost, it's still worth it as long as you use it wisely. Pay attention to the placement of Infinite Impermanence. You can also use it for the 2nd bullet after SDAM activation, if it's the only monster you control.

EXTRA DECK

1) Stardust Dragon

Vanilla Stardust Dragon. You need this to summon SDAM. Can be Synchro Summoned by using either Psi-Reflector, Ascator, or Psy-Framegear. I only put 1 in the Extra Deck, and the other one is available in the Side Deck, in case you want to go for a consistent 2nd SDAM. Why? Because you can Special Summon this one SD from your GY using Monster Reborn or Back To The Front and get a 2nd SDAM that way. But eh, most of the time, you simply do not use or discard that 2nd SDAM. But, feel free to re-organize the Extra Deck, and probably tell me some better alternatives.. Make yourself comfortable.

2) Satellite Warrrior

A level 10 Synchro Monster. This card is pretty decent, potentially clears the board, and is a beatstick. You only need the extra Tuner and synchro monster at a suitable level.

3) Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon

Another decent card, although a bit harder to summon.

4) Level 6-9 Synchro Monsters

You can replace any of these monsters with any better card you can think of. Just keep in mind that you should avoid choosing Synchro Monster with overly restrictive material requirements. However, Assault Sentinel really has you extending your range of choices. The Extra Deck is your powerful arsenal, so choose the right monster for the right condition. I will give a short description of each of my Extra Deck monsters, just in case you want to know why I picked them.

Vermillion D. M.: A decent card destroyer.

Ravenous Crocodragon: Draw power, as well as a strong beatstick. is a decent card destroyer.

Beelze: I use it to play defensive. It is this deck's strongest defense wall (although I think there's a better alternative, I hope you don't mind telling me a card or two). I also usually play this card with Red Dragon AM in the Side Deck, since Beelze isn't affected by its double-edged effect.

Kitedrake: A good board clearer. You will need Assault Sentinel to summon this card. Even after clearing the board, you still get this beatstick as a great bonus.

Accel Synchro Stardust Dragon: Didn't really use it.. Although this card somewhat will make it easier for you to Synchro Summon higher level Synchros.

Scarlight Red Dragon: I think this version of Red Dragon is better since most of the cards are Special Summoned in the current meta. Also serves as a material for its AM counterpart.

Draco Berserker: Its banish effect is really good, and it annoys my opponent a lot most of time.

Framelord Omega: A recycleable Lightforce Sword. "We will definitely win it, Yugi. As long as we have Lightforce Sword in our hand" - Atem. Hmm, can't see how this line is relatable since LS is a trap card, but anyway..

Cyberse Quantum: To fight undestroyable cards.

Baronne De Fleur: Not always worth it to summon, but is a useful card depends on the situation.

Wind Pegasus: A backrow destroyer with decent card bouncing effect when it leaves the field.

Coral Dragon: It has an extra draw advantage and is also a tuner, so it will most likely be used. I hope.

SIDE DECK

The side deck is filled with my alternative strategy, and any cards I want to be there. Again, you can search for a better replacement. Tell me your opinions in the comment section.

In the end, Assault Mode is indeed not a really good archetype. I don't recommend it for you to use it at all in competitive play. However, this deck is not without the slightest benefit. As for me, I think this is a really challenging deck to use. This deck requires more understanding and knowledge of the game than most decks. It really gives that vibe of a hardcore gamer's deck. It's still pretty fun to use, though.

I do hope that you guys that have more knowledge than me can help me improve this deck further. Feel free to give all of your honest opinions in the chat. That's all from me. Thanks for reading till the end. This article sure took some time to create.. And I really appreciate any attention. Thank you!

Now that Dimension Force is coming to the TCG, Predaplants are finally getting their new support. And thanks to the Alba Strike structure decks, Predaplants are better than they have been in a long time! And the name for this deck is pretty obvious, especially if you watched Dateline back in the early 2000s. Chris Hansen was the GOAT!     Anyway, this deck is good going first or second, put personally, I prefer going first to set up as many disruptions as I can.

The main idea going first is to end with mirrorjade and branded in red face down so that you can go into guardian chimera on your opponents turn as a form of disruption.  You accomplish this by getting to mirror jade with 1 extra body on the board as a target for mirrorjade to banish by sending an extra deck monster to the graveyard. You will send albion the branded dragon so that you will be able to set your branded in red at the end phase and have it live on your opponents turn. When you use branded fusion going first you're always going to want to send despian tragedy to search the ad libitum of despia because using him as material from your hand when making the chimera allows you to Immediately special summon the mirrorjade back to your side of the field with its banish effect live again.  The frighfur package helps you get materials in your hand for guardian chimera as well as possibly being bait for an ash blossom.  The light hex sealed fusion allows access to dragoon and can also be used as a third copy of Fallen of albaz in a pinch.  The hand traps that hurt the deck the most are played as crossout designator targets at 2x.  The side deck mostly consists of blowout cards for going second with the inclusion of a small zombie world package. You can send Necroworld banshee off of branded fusion to access your zombie world and you can then use super polymerization to make dragonecro nethersoul dragon using your opponents monsters as material.

deck_excerpt: The best XYZ toolbox in Master Duel
deck_description:
Sharks work well as an XYZ toolbox in the face of current top decks. With MD being a best of 1, having answers to multiple strategies is key. That is why the deck is filled with ways to deal with your opponent's field, whether its hand traps, DRNM, or even Evenly Matched.   your main starter is [Buzzsaw Shark]! you want to see this card as soon as possible so we are running 7 cards that can get to it. 3x Buzzsaw Shark 3x Beautunaful Princess 1x One for one With Buzzsaw Shark, you can start your combo going into Bahamut Shark -> Toadally Awesome -> Utopic Draco Future (if you open White mirror too) Even if you dont see Buzzsaw, you can still play with extenders like Lantern and Angler to make a similar board but with more resources.   Outside of the main combo, you have plenty of Toolbox oriented extra deck monsters to deal with your opponent's field.
  • N4: Stealth Kragen can lock your opponent into Water attribute along with Gozen Match (Great against Invoked Shaddoll and Tri-B strategies).
  • Abyss Dweller is an answer to GY focused decks.
  • Silent Honor Ark can steal your opponent's largest threat and then build a Zeus over it.
I have piloted this deck to Platinum 1 for multiple seasons so far and plan to go for Diamond 1 this season. With Swordsoul and DPE being out at the point of submitting this deck (MAy 10), I might have to revise my hand trap options to suit the new meta

deck_excerpt: Swordsoul Tenyi deck for Master Duel
deck_description: Swordsoul Tenyi deck. The goal is to be a midrange deck that consistently puts Chengying on the table with multiple ways to trigger him, and hopefully tools to protect him. I'm still on DPE, but I also don't think you can pass up the consistency granted by Halq - Auroradon. That combo is also super flexible here, ending on either Yazi to set up Swordsoul plays with Auroradon and Yazi, or Denglong + Draco Berserker, in addition to the option of just making Verte when you need it. I think DPE is too important to cut in a Chengying based version, since it can trigger Chengying in a pinch and works neatly with Torrential Tribute as well, but I also think in a lot of situations you're either hoping to draw Fusion Destiny and make Halq plays, or else you're negated into infinity and make DPE in desperation - these are both still good plays I think the deck needs access to. It also offers a line that plays under Nib, although I'm not hyper impressed by that or scared by Nib. Still nice.  This version of the deck is a midrange trap(ish) version focusing on the grind game, and on making Wyrm monsters. There simply wasn't enough space for the actual essentials and all of the tech choices I wanted to run, so instead it is greedy as all hell, and hoping to go first. Having said that, Solemns are still good going second, and Swordsoul can sure break boards, you bet your bippy.  This deck is good, not terrifying, but very strong, and forms of it (Wrym piles basically) are probably going to be good for quite a while. It is also the kind of deck that will likely continue to randomly top events even when it is not good, and will also likely have more than one heyday, if I had to guess, just on the basis of Wyrm synchro piles having such good support already. Denglong is probably not essential, but I like the idea of running it as an alternative in the Auroradon combo. But you could do as well or better with Herald of the Arc Light, which also has a floodgate effect - still, this is a counter trap, so that's pretty good. Or you could just not have that line of play and instead focus on diversity and tech calls - there is space. But for the way I like to play Swordsoul, I need a 16 card extra deck, and whatever I cut will hurt. So we're pretty pure, at least in terms of how we end babeee.  Still doing some tuning. Denglong setups exist, but don't come up, and O-Lion is less of a brick than Nine Pillars, so Denglong is out, and Herald is in. I think it is time to unban this card in the TCG if it exists and Wyrm Synchro doesn't want to play it. You could run 3 Ecclesia and 1 Mo-ye for the same number of "starters", and you'd see Ecclesia more often going second, but it seems brickier, not as good at grinding, and especially bricky going first. I like these ratios a lot. You could run 2 Tour Guide for more 1 card starts, but I'm okay with most of my openings requiring 2 cards to start, and 1 Tour Guide seems totally fine, especially since the Rota is also a less restrictive 1 card start.

A Salamangreat focus deck. The ideal play would be to get out of Salamangreat Sanctuary as quickly as possible by link summoning Balelynx as quickly as possible to get started on the link plays. Then work on getting out Pyro Phoenix to be able to board wipe your opponent once or twice, then equipping Salamangreat Claw them gives them some protection. The main portions of the deck are designed around reusing a lot of the same materials as you link summon up to Pyro Phoenix. The cards in the side deck are designed to be swapped with the third copy of monsters that exist in the main deck only, otherwise, the consistency tends to break down.

deck_excerpt: A very run off the mill deck for some very FUN of the mill people :---) (sorry)
deck_description:
I know in my last deckprofile I talked crap about pile lists but hear me out. I'm just playing 48 cards so it doesn't count! Okay so maybe it counts a little but I think there's a big difference in the deck that played all the best engines together to abuse only the strongest of cards and, yknow, Lightsworns. I appreciate a good chaos pile deck as much as the next guy! So with Dimension Force on it's way we need to talk about the newest addition to the P.U.N.K. team: Noh-P.U.N.K. Dia Note. Dia Note does something very important: Not being a level 8 monster. It can be searched and added by Noh-P.U.N.K. Ogre Dance and most importantly Special Summoned by Noh-P.U.N.K. Foxy Tune. This means that one Noh-P.U.N.K. Ze Amin can mill 9 cards. People used to play engines just to summon Chaos Ruler, the Chaotic Magical Dragon and now we have an engine (a consistent one at that!) that summons Chaos Ruler and The Zombie Vampire. With Fairy Tail - Snow and Destrudo the Lost Dragon's Frisson (anyone else keep calling it fissure?) no longer being forbidden I'd be a shame NOT to play a chaos pile deck!   Put on your overalls and grab a wrench, we're talking engines now!
  • P.U.N.K.
    • Combo Line:
      1. Summon Ze Amin, effect to add Foxy Tune.
      2. Foxy Tune effect to SS Dia Note.
      3. Synchro Summon Chaos Ruler, C1 Chaos Ruler C2 Dia Note to SS Foxy Tune // Mill 5
      4. Overlay both for Zombie Vampire // Mill 4
        • Keep in mind that chaos pile decks are non-linear so you might do other stuff in between this.
        • P.U.N.K.s are also the reason I'm not playing 60 cards. I want to see this engine consistently while still having enough cards to a) not brick on Wulf and Felis and b) not ever mill Snow/Destrudo. So I ended up at 48.
    • Ze Amin: You're starter
    • Ogre Dance: Searches Ze Amin (and Dia Note)
    • Foxy Tune: SS Dia Note from Deck and enables Engine without a NS if you open Foxy Tune + a P.U.N.K. monster
      • Alternative Combo Line: Foxy Tune effect to SS Ze Amin. Ze Amin effect searches Dia Note. Dia Note effect sends the other P.U.N.K. and summons herself --> Setup as seen in step 2.
    • Ukiyoe-P.U.N.K. Sharakusa: Another level 3 psychic for Ukiyoe-P.U.N.K. Amazing Dragon and used for alternative endboards to Synchro Summon on your opponent's turn.
    • Amazing Dragon: Bounces 1-2 cards from your opponent.
    • Emergency Teleport: SS Ze Amin to perform the combo without commiting to a NS
  • Lightsworn:
    • Charge of the Lightbrigade: Searches Raiden, Hand of the Lightsworn and mills 3
    • Raiden: Mills 2 and is a tuner.
    • Wulf, Lightsworn Beast: Extender if milled.
    • Felis, Lightsworn Archer: Extender if milled and is also a tuner.
  • Danger!:
      • Danger! Nessie!: Body on the field and a draw or searches Mothman!
      • Danger! Mothman!: Level 4 body for Synchro, XYZ and Link plays and a draw.
      • Danger!? Jackalope?: Body and draw or Special Summons Mothman!
  • Chaos:
    • Chaos Space: Searches either of the Chaos Dragons, returns a banished card (has multiple niche uses like recycling a card that you want in deck like Dia Note if she's milled, Fusion Material if you play a DPE package for example).
    • Black Dragon Collapserpent: Level 4 body that searches Wyverbuster.
    • White Dragon Wyverburster: Level 4 body that searches Collapserpent.
  • Snow: Flips your opponent's monsters face-down. NOT once per turn. If you have a stacked GY you can use her as a body on your turn, too.
  • Destrudo: Body and tuner. Can summon Shooting Riser Dragon or F.A. Dawn Dragster with ease.
  • Called By The Grave: Called by the Grave is good going first and even going second against Branded.
  • Handtraps:
    • Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring: Generally one of the stronger handtraps. Does wonders against Branded.
    • DD Crow: Like Ghost Belle it manipulates the GY. Since it's a DARK it's better here than Belle.
    • Effect Veiler: Albeit technically a worse Imperm when it comes to it's function as a handtrap, it is also a tuner and a LIGHT making it better here than Imperm.
  The all-generic Extra Deck Think of a number between 1 and 1652. Picked one? Great. I guarantee you whatever number you picked, it would still not be enough to fit all Extra Deck cards that Pile decks would like to play. (A higher number and I'd have to account for custom cards. No thank you) So these are the 15 I decided to play and here's why. Welcome to my TED Talk:
  • Link Monsters:
    • Striker Dragon: Used to link climb with the Chaos Dragons.
    • I:P Masquerena: Used to summon Knightmare Phoenix on your opponent's turn and puts Snow back into the GY.
    • Crystron Halqifibrax: Used to link climb or to summon Sharakusai to Synchro Summon on your opponent's turn. It's other effect can be used for Desert Locust (I'll refer to the card later).
    • Knightmare Unicorn: Spins a card from your opponent.
    • Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess: Multiple monster effect negates. It never hurts to use your first badge of resources for her. If you can, use Chaos Ruler before going into Zombie Vampire and summon it back with its effect, then it won't get banished if you overlay it for Zombie Vampire later.
    • Accesscode Talker: Used to secure game.
    • Closing Thoughts: Each of them is very important. I really cut it down to the necessities. If I could I'd play more. Dharc the Dark Charmer, Gloomy for example is great, especially after Vampire Zombie milled cards for your opponent.
  • XYZ Monsters:
    • Minerva, the Exalted Lightsworn: Used to flex your price card to let everyone know your either crazy good or crazy rich. Oh it also mills 3 and might draw you some cards, too.
    • The Zombie Vampire: Mills 4 cards and summons you another body. Depending on your opponent's deck this can either really mess them up or help them greatly. But we're all Dopamine addicts so don't even pretend you'd hesitate for even a second to use it's effect even against the worst matchup possible.
    • Closing Thoughts: Again I kept it at minimum to overcompensate with Synchro Monsters. Definitely play both. Abyss Dweller or Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy are fantastic additions to your lineup. 
  • Synchro Monsters:
    • Desert Locust: Loops a card out of your opponent's hand and can then summon Fleur with Snow or Amazing Dragon with Dawn Dragster after it's used its effect.
    • FA Dawn Dragster: It's a Spell/Trap negate that can be made with Destrudo and almost any monster.
    • Shooting Riser Dragon: Can mill Snow and then also used for another Synchro Summon, etc.
    • Chaos Ruler, the Chaotic Magical Dragon: Used to mill cards and adds a card to hand.
    • Borreload Savage Dragon: You have plenty of tuners, non-tuners, level 4 monsters and links in the GY so this is an easy omni negate. // Adamancipator Risen - Dragite is a great budget option as long as you get Halq into the GY (and then not banish it with Snow..obviously).
    • Baronne de Fleur: There're surprisingly many ways to make a level 10 Synchro and this one is simply the strongest one. // For a budget option I'd choose Swordsoul Supreme Sovereign - Chengying. It has near infinite attack after using Snow once or twice, protection and has great removal. There's plenty of removal already that's why I'd prefer Fleur.
    • Ukiyoe-P.U.N.K. Amazing Dragon: It can bounce 1-2 cards or extend when going for lethal.
    • Closing Thoughts: As you can see I'm playing a whole lot of Synchro monsters for a whole lot of different board states. Chaos pile decks are very non-linear but you could technically remove Desert Locust, Fleur and Amazing Dragon for more Link or XYZ monsters. I recommend keeping the other ones!
  Once again I have to mess with the Side Deck to get the right tags. Can we please bring choosing tags back? :')
Roll dice and mash synchros. That is it.

deck_excerpt: Dinomorphia deck post-Dimension Force, May 2022! Inspired by Power Rangers!
deck_description: Despite the name, this is not a Dino Thunder Dragons deck. This is a Dinomorphia deck featuring two of their newest cards from Dimension Force: Dinomorphia Rexturm and Dinomorphia Frenzy! The name was inspired by Dinomorphia Frenzy's artwork, which is inspired by a scene from Power Rangers: Dino Thunder. The card was trending on Twitter at the end of 2021 because of the comparison.     Twitter link: https://twitter.com/YuGiOhNewsTCG/status/1476587455637819395     This deck sticks to the archetype's "go first or burst" strategy, but with two good tech choices for Dinomorphia. It contains two copies of Hope For Escape for some draw power, and Ferret Flames for monster removal. In fact, if your LP is low enough, Ferret Flames can be a board wipe for your opponent. The best part is that it doesn't shuffle their monsters into the deck--it forces your opponent to do that to their monsters, so this can get rid of unaffected beaters like Raidraptor - Ultimate Falcon, Ancient Gear Chaos Giant, and even UCT under Misc.

Super consistent OTK/combo deck  mostly focuses on discarding Grapha, Bigfoot, and Dogman to break opponents board before OTKing your opponent  Possible combo end boards include Apollusa/Saruya/Accesscode, Number 38/Dingirsu/Number 68, Arc Rebellion/Number S39  This deck is super consistent and able to play through up to 3 negates  Feel free to change anything you like and recommend possible changes

deck_excerpt: Don't worry about this deck, it's purely for fun. I wouldn't recommend using it in a real duel since it's my first attempt at a deck.
deck_description:
So I decided that I wanted to try and build decks based on my personal OCs, but the main gimmick for this deck is of course the same as in the Structure Deck for the archetype with a few added bonuses.

  • Extra traps for if your Shaddolls are negated
  • Extra ways to summon your Shaddolls from the GY
  • Extra protection from Attacks
  • Extra protection from Fusion Monsters.
  • Banishment effects
Thunder stun. That's it.

deck_excerpt: An incredible anti-meta deck that targets Extra Deck monsters and practically makes them invalid. For full combos, watch: https://youtu.be/4OViMFSer0
deck_description: In the current meta, add 1 copy of Nekroz of Areadbhair instead of Nekroz of Gungnir.  I hope you like this one ^^  https://youtu.be/4OViMFSer0k

Just a fun Blue-Eyes deck. I just like to use Sage or Stone of Ancients to get Abyss dragon ASAP, then use its effect to summon Chaos MAX on the next turn. Use True Light to search out Ultimate Fusion and wreck everything with Blue-eyes Alternative Ultimate Dragon. You can use Spirit of White or Solid Dragon to banish spells or permanently negate a monster's effect. Piercing the Darkness is fun - you can effectively get an extra draw every turn, especially if you have Azure-Eyes out. Extra deck left mostly empty

deck_excerpt: Fun means no Dragoon, only Flare Metal!
deck_description: You can usually get 1-2 Flare Metal Dragons on turn 1, 3 if you're lucky. Lots of draw power for getting lots of level 7s on the field (and in the graveyard). Red-eyes Fusion stops special summons, so I use it as a back-up or just for that last bit of burn damage with Black Comet Dragon.

deck_excerpt: Just a cool deck with cool cards.
deck_description: You can consistently get all three synchros. They have no built-in protection, so use the Koa'ki Meiru crew. The crystals give the synchros powerful effects if they are in the graveyard and give nice recyclability. Adamancipator Friends can help you reach into the deck for more tuners. The field spell lets you choose what you want to excavate, when paired with Dragite, you can bounce 5 cards! A Feather of the Pheonix is an interesting one; allowing you to excavate a card that was in the grave. The Extra deck was left mostly empty.

deck_excerpt: A brand new 2022 version of my Old Antimeta.
deck_description:
This deck is a renewed and reworked version of my old Antimeta which I used to play in 2019, which was in turn based on my golden age Antimeta from 2012 and were both clearly a bit outdated. Interestingly, the old version still managed to beat some decks at a local tournament in May 2019 probably thanks to the surprise effect of a deck composition that hadn't been used for a very long time and for which the meta wasn't prepared. This year I tried to use it again, but it was a complete disaster, the game has now a completely new rhythm and the old deck couldn't keep up without hand traps and newer and more powerful versions of some cards. The core idea is still to play in an unexpected manner w.r.t. the current meta and surprise the opponents who could not have a proper side deck to counter our strategy.

Strategy:

Ideally, you want on the field the Inspector  Boarder, the Fossil Dyna Pachycephalo and/or Thunder King Rai-Oh. They need to be defended, but it's also important to use your hand traps to stop your opponents immediately before they manage to bring big monsters on the field. A lot of drawing cards are present to allow for a constant hand refill. I am seriously considering adding one or more Maxx C in case the deck runs out of cards too quickly (of course only if it gets unbanned). Some testing is needed to understand whether the deck is balanced or it needs more defending or drawing cards. The Extra Deck is not essential for the moment, therefore can be improved for strategic use in case of emergencies and the only useful card is the Stardust Dragon. It is important to have a full 15 cards in order to exploit the Pot of Extravagance. The Side Deck has counters that could be needed against specific decks. It allows focusing on removing, destroying small monsters, countering decks with a lot of summoning, countering decks using the graveyard and more.

Possible edits:

  • Among the following cards: - 1x Pot of Duality - 3x Raigeki Increase PoD if you need more drawings, or remove if you need more defensive traps. Consider substituting with Maxx C. If 3x Reigeki are too many they can be reduced to make room for other cards (such as Maxx C)
 
  • Among the following cards: - 1x Magic Cylinder - 2x Storming Mirror Force - 2x Evenly Matched - 2x Bottomless Trap Hole Can be rearranged into a new composition of other defensive/offensive traps (look at the list at the end of the deck description). Torrential Tribute, Lost Wind or Witch's Strike could be a valid substitute for the Magic Cylinder (which is just present for fun and hit opponents who do not expect it). Evenly Matched could be reduced to 1 and all the other cards on this list can be completely removed (not all at the same time, still need some defences) in case of better alternatives.
 
  • The Ritual monster in the Main Deck can be substituted with a Maxx C or with any of the 3 single monsters in x1 present in the Side Deck
 
  • In the Side Deck it is possible to substitute the 3x Nibiru, The Primal Being with 1/2x more Artifact Lancea and one or two traps as Lost Wind and/or Witch's Strike or better alternatives.
Other possibly useful cards: - Mystical Space Typhoon to be increased if necessary - Effect Veiler to be increased if necessary - Cosmic Cyclone - Lightning Storm - Forbidden Droplet - Dark Ruler No More - Lost Wind - Witch's Strike - Anti-Spell Fragrance - Dimensional Barrier - Floodgate Trap Hole - There Can Be Only One - Compulsory Evacuation Device - Fiendish Chain - Torrential Tribute - Black Horn of Heaven - Maxx C - Mistake - Vanity's Emptiness - Macro Cosmos - Time Seal - Guiding Ariadne (take inspiration from this) - Any version of the barrier statue - Other versions of Solmen Judgement - Other versions of Mirror Force (especially Quaking Mirror Force) - Any card contrasting the current meta - Any improvement to the Extra Deck bringing in some usable cards Please leave a comment and let me know what you think!

deck_name: Tearalaments - Branded / Post Power of the Elements
deck_excerpt: The Branded version of a really unique deck. Enjoy!
deck_description: Despite the domination of the Splight archetype, Tearalaments made their own steps in the OCG and had a bit of success. The deck's standard play revolves around normal summoning Tearalaments Reinoheart, the by using her effect Tearalaments Shaylen, Tearalaments Haufenis or Tearalaments Meiru is sent to the GY for their fusion summoning effect to activate. The usual target is Tearalaments Kitkalos who searches the trap card Tearalaments Metanoise. Branded fusion also synergises with the archetype since it allows the player to send a Tearalaments monster to the GY and thus trigger it's effect to go for the play mentioned above. As most meta decks, Tearalaments can also afford to run a respectable amount of handtraps. Concerning the Shaddoll monsters on the list, they are used as materials for the summon of El Shaddoll Winda, even on your opponent's main phase thanks to Tearlaments Haufenis's quick effect!

deck_excerpt: This is the version I'm currently running and improving, actually looks better than the one initially identified as the definitive goal.
deck_description:
In progress, until I buy the missing cards for the final version (but actually, this deck is becoming better than the other one). I realized it often happens that the opponents manage to remove my set spells/traps before coming to the Battle Phase, therefore it's important to have cards that stop them before it happens rather than having defences from attacks as Dimensional Prison, therefore having only the Storming Mirror Force to directly defend from attacks should be ok. Remarkable possible modifications:
  • Consider adding one or more Solemn Strike
  • Gozen Match in substitution of or Rivalry of Warlords in the Side Deck (since it wouldn't affect negatively my monsters)
  • Run 3x copies instead of 2x of the floodgates (There Can Be Only One / Rivalry of Warlords / Gozen Match)
  • Play 1x Time Seal?
  • Evenly Matched, Nibiru the Primal Being, Ghost Belle & Haunted Mansion?
  • Add 1/2/3x Ghost Belle & Haunted Mansion in the Side Deck
Modifications currently in the testing phase: (v.4 w.r.t. v.2)
  • Moved Heavenly Zephyr - Miradora from Side Deck to Main Deck and removed Sauravis, the Ancient and Ascended
  • Adding 1x The Winged Dragon of Ra - Sphere Mode to the Side Deck
  • Removed 2x Raigeki and added 2x Dark Bribe
  • Substituted 1x Mystical Space Typhoon with 1x Lightning Storm
  • Added 1x Lord of the Heavenly Prison to the Main Deck which is now made of 41 cards
  • Substituted Morphing Jar with Morphing Jar #2
  • Added a 3rd copy of Dark Bribe in Side Deck by removing 1x Artifact Lancea
  • Added a 2nd copy of Cosmic Cyclone in Side Deck by removing 1x Artifact Lancea
Modifications waiting to be tested, but still accepted as very valid:
  • Add a 2nd The Winged Dragon of Ra - Sphere Mode in Side Deck
  • Add 1x or 2x Evenly Matched (maybe move 1x Starlight Road and/or 1x Floodgate Trap Hole/Storming Mirror Force to Side Deck to make space)
  • Consider moving 1x Starlight Road to Side Deck if need to make room for other cards (as a 2nd Lost Wind, or 1x Moon Mirror Shield, or 1x Macro Cosmos, or 3rd Dark Bribe, or 1/2x Dimension Shifter)
  • Consider removing the 1x Book of Moon since it doesn't work on Links (add a 2nd copy or Lost Wind?)
  • Consider running 2x or 3x Dimension Shifter directly in Main Deck (or Side Deck)
  • Morphing Jar #2 and Effect Veiler could be removed in favour of other useful cards probably
Notes:
  • Torrential Tribute is to counter the stall caused by Mystic Mine decks

deck_excerpt: Fluffal Deck for Master Duel Fusion Format
deck_description: Fluffal is an Anime deck that has been in the game since 2016 made up of Fairy and Demon-Type monsters and make Fusion Summon in the traditional way, that is, using monsters from field and hand with the iconic Polymerization. What I like most about this deck is that you feel that Fluffal has a high ceiling of moves, even more considering that the deck doesn't use any LINK-2 Enabler to make moves, but you rotate the engine around your cards. And for that it is subdivided into three Archetypes: "Fluffal" Cards, "Edge Imp" Cards and "Frightfur" Cards and since practically all fusions are semi-generic and need at least 1 "Fluffal" and 1 "Edge Imp "Monster to be Made this is a typical big engine to play. The only LINK Monster missing when playing Fluffal in Fusion Format is Cross-Sheep for bringing back from the GY a name necessary to make a certain Fusion Summon for example. Despite having received excellent support over the years, Fluffal's focus in Fusion Format is to go Second Always because turn 1 you don't have many ways to interact with the opponent being at most passing with Edge Imp Scythe + Fluffal Penguin that makes the move of Summon Cruel Whale on your opponent's turn allowing you to destroy 1 card on each side of the field and draw 2 cards and discard 1 with Fluffal Penguin. This is not a linear deck, each Starter Hand will change the way you run the engine and make field presence and advantage. It's like playing a puzzle, and that's why this is a deck that, even with simple effects cards, is quite complex to play correctly. The deck has a lot of Search Power, Draw Power and Recycling needed to play since it's a Fusion deck that doesn't "CHEAT" in the mechanics because you still Fusion Summon through Polymerization, at most you have Frightfur Fusion that allows you banish Fusion Materials from the GY to make Fusions from the Extra Deck as a Fusion Summon Enabler, otherwise everything you do is in the race and so you need to know how to manage resources as efficiently as possible because you will most of the time need it Draw half of your deck in one turn to be able to Fusion Summon. Because you need to Fusion Summon with Polymerization and in general "Frightfur" Fusion Monsters are semi-generic because it requires an "Edge Imp" Monster and a "Fluffal" Monster as material you will come across several Main Deck cards that generate advantage like the Pot of Greed and Engage! level such as: Fluffal Wings, Fluffal Penguin, Frightfur Patchwork and especially Toy Vendor which is a Continuous Spell with two Soft Once Per Turn effects (once per copy) being an absurd card in terms of advantage for Fluffal's Archetype. As this is a very old Archetype several of the cards especially the Extra Deck monsters have Soft Once Per Turn effects so whenever you bring a different copy of them to the field you will be able to use their effects again. //////////////////////////////////////////////// Details during Fluffal's Fusion Format Gameplay: As I don't have the Cross-Sheep summon I have to use Frightfur Repair as an extender as soon as possible and it hurts to have several push moves but that's ok for this version only Fusion Summon. The trick behind Frightfur Repair is that you can use your first effect of returning a "Frightfur" Fusion to the Extra Deck and giving Monster Reborn because in the Normal version of Fluffal you always want to send it straight to the GY with the Cruel Whale but in Fusion Format you need to take advantage of the card's first effect as well. For that you need to make Cruel Whale using Edge Imp Chain as material and activate its effect to Add Frightfur Repair from Deck to hand and use Cruel Whale send Frightfur Daredevil to GY and gain ATK Boost to be able to use Repair first eff and return Daredevil to the Extra Deck and reborn from Fluffal Penguin for example to use its Special from Hand effect again. That way you not only extend your rolls but you will also have the second effect of Frightfur Repair available on the next turn. When you have several cards in your hand that don't help you at all, it's very good to start discarding them to see new cards with Toy Vendor. Even if Super Polymerization doesn't have good targets against the opponent's deck you can simply use Super Polymerization on your Monsters during the Battle Phase to guarantee OTK when using for example Frightfur Kraken and Fluffal Dog as material to make the Sabre-Tooth that enters giving Reborn from Kraken. Another use of Super Polymerization is taking the target out of an Infinite Impermanence for example so that your Fusion monster like Frightfur Tiger resolves and destroys your opponent's cards. Interesting to see how to make your chain link with the deck because several Main Deck monsters trigger effs when sent to the GY as Fusion Materials so if you are facing a deck of Omninegate monsters like Invoked Mechaba you can "Chain Block" the most important effects for them to resolve. Predaplant Dragostapelia is very easy to make with any "Frightfur" Fusion and the Edge Imp Chain added with Frightfur Patchwork. //////////////////////////////////////////////// Simple Deck Combo Lines: They are more about small combinations of cards that make a certain advantage to allow you to connect the pieces necessary to make Fusion Summon. The combo changes a lot as the Draws happen so it's more about understanding the gameplay than memorizing moves. //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 1: (Bear + Wings ) = (Dog + Bear/Wings) = (Toy Vendor and Fluffal Wings Interaction) Activate Fluffal Bear Effect Set Toy Vendor from Deck Activate Toy Vendor Toy Vendor effect discard Fluffal Wings and Draw 1 and Special or Discard (depends on luck) Wings effect target Bear - Banish Bear = Draw 1 and Send Toy Vendor to Draw 1 Toy Vendor effect to Search a card Final Board: 3 Draws + 1 search, being 1 of the Draws depends on luck. //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 2: Foolish Burial Goods ( Toy Vendor and Dolphin Interaction) (This same combo can be done with Double Toy Vendor/Toy Vendor + Fluffal Bear because you activate one and discard the other to use the DRAW effect or any Staple like Super Polymerization/Forbidden Droplet and Twin Twisters that can send Toy Vendor to GY) Activate Foolish Burial Goods Send Toy Vendor to GY Toy Vendor Effect Add Fluffal Dolphin Normal Summon Dolphin and Dolphin effect Set Toy Vendor and Mill Fluffal Wings to GY Set Activate Toy Vendor Toy Vendor effect discard 1 "FLUFFAL" from hand to Draw 1 and Special or Discard Wings effect target "FLUFFAL" you discard - Banish it = Draw 1 and Destroy Toy Vendor to Draw 1 (can only activate Wings eff if you discard a Fluffal) Toy Vendor effect to Search a card Final Board: 3 Draws + 1 search, being 1 of the Draws depends on luck. //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 3: Edge Imp Scythe + Penguin (Opponent's Turn) (Best Edge Imp Scythe move possible) Edge Imp Scythe eff Fusion Cruel Whale and Fluffal Penguin eff cl1 and Cruel Whale eff to Destroy cl2 and Cruel Whale eff cl3 tgt itself to Boost ATK Send Frightfur Repair to GY and Edge Imp Scythe protect Cruel Whale from Destruction and DRAW 2 Discard 1 //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 4: Penguin + Frightfur Patchwork (Often you just want to Fusion Summon a Frightfur Cruel Whale for example to take Advantage of the Fusion Materials effs like Edge Imp Chain and Fluffal Penguin to get access to new cards that help you have more play options then anyway in weak hands the deck has a great ability to see new cards and make better combos) Activate Frightfur Patchwork Add Edge Imp Chain and Polymerization Fusion Summon Cruel Whale with Fluffal Penguin and Edge Imp Chain Edge Imp Chain cl1 Penguin cl2 Edge Imp Chain search "Frightfur Fusion" or "Frightfur Repair" dependently the Gamestate (Sometimes the Draw 2 and Discard 1 is Draw 1 and Search 1 because you send Toy Vendor to GY) https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=813757-37309406 Final Board: Cruel Whale /in Hand: 2 Draws 1 Discard + 1 search for "Frightfur Fusion" or "Frightfur Repair" //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 5: (Dog + Edge Imp Chain) (Blind Second) (Played through Fluffal Bear and Toy Vendor discard EdgeImpChain) NS Fluffal Dog and eff Add Bear and eff discard to GY to Set Toy Vendor from Deck Activate Toy Vendor and eff Discard Edge Imp Chain to DRAW 1 and Special or Discard Edge Imp Chain eff Add Frightfur Patchwork and Activate Patchwork Add Polymerization and Edge Imp Sabres Activate Polymerization and Fusion Cruel Whale (using Dog and Edge Imp Sabres) ***Cruel Whale eff Destroy Toy Vendor and Opponent's Card ***Toy Vendor eff Add Fluffal Dolphin and Cruel Whale eff tgt itself send Frightfur Repair to GY to Extend Plays Frightfur Repair eff banish from GY to Special Dolphin from Hand Fluffal Dolphin eff Set Toy Vendor and Foolish Fluffal Wings Activate Toy Vendor and eff discard 1 Card to DRAW 1 and Special or Discard Wings eff banish itself and Bear from GY to DRAW 2 and Send Toy Vendor to GY and Toy Vendor eff Add Fluffal Sheep SS Sheep from Hand and eff Return Dolphin to SS Edge Imp Chain from GY Previously Gamestate: Cruel Whale + Sheep + Edge Imp Chain /in Hand: 2 DRAWS + Dolphin /in GY: Edge Imp Sabres + Scythe If you have Polymerization = Fusion Frightfur Kraken using Sheep and Edge Imp Chain or bring in GY's Edge Imp Sabres to make Frightfur Tiger instead. //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 6: Dog + Polymerization ( in the Grind Game) (Fluffal Sheep and Edge Imp Chain Interaction - This combo could only be done with the Fluffal Dog + Edge Imp Chain in GY but we don't have LINK Monsters to send the Edge Imp Chain to the GY so you need to Fusion Summon it to trigger its effect) NS Fluffal Dog and eff Add Fluffal Sheep and SS Sheep and eff Return Dog to Hand and SS Edge Imp Chain from GY Activate Polymerization Fusion Frightfur Kraken (using Sheep and Edge Imp Chain) and Edge Imp Chain eff Add Frightfur Patchwork Activate Patchwork Add Polymerization and Edge Imp Scythe Activate Polymerization Fusion Cruel Whale (using Dog and Scythe) and Cruel Whale eff Destroy itself and Opponent's Card(Edge Imp Scythe Protect) Cruel Whale eff tgt Kraken send 1 Frightfur Monster from Extra Deck or Frightfur Repair to GY Gamestate: Kraken + Cruel Whale //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 6. 1: Dog + Patchwork (in the Grind Game) ***NS Fluffal Dog and eff Add Fluffal Cat and Activate Frightfur Patchwork Add Polymerization and Edge Imp Chain (you could also add Fluffal Penguin if you want to generate card advantage instead of doing one more Fusion Summon with Polymerization) Activate Polymerization Fusion Frightfur Kraken (using Edge Imp Chain and Cat) Edge Imp Chain eff cl1 Add Frightfur Fusion and Frightfur Cat eff cl2 Add Polymerization to Hand (Can use Kraken's effect to send an opponent's monster to the GY) Activate Polymerization Fusion Sabre-Tooth (using Dog and Kraken) and Sabre-Tooth eff Reborn Kraken (can use interaction effect again) Activate Frightfur Fusion banishing Material from GY for yet another fusion Gamestate: Saber-Tooth + Kraken + Frightfur Fusion //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 7: (Toy Vendor + Edge Imp Chain) + any Fluffal Monster (As you have access to Edge Imp Sabres as fusion material here you can make Frightfur Tiger to destroy your own Toy Vendor and gain Search effect) Activate Toy Vendor and eff Discard Edge Imp Chain DRAW 1 CARD and Special or Discard Edge Imp Chain eff Add Frightfur Patchwork and Activate Patchwork Add Polymerization and Edge Imp Sabres (Assuming you have access to a Fluffal Monster in your hand like Fluffal Penguin for example) Activate Polymerization Fusion Frightfur Tiger(using Edge Imp Sabres and Penguin) ***Frightfur Tiger eff target and Destroy 1 Opponent's Card and TOY VENDOR cl1 and Penguin eff DRAW 2 Discard 1 cl2 ***Toy Vendor eff Add Fluffal Dog/Fluffal Dolphin (Some Fluffal monster to be your Normal Summon depending on the rest of your hand) //////////////////////////////////////////Combo 8: (Dog + Patchwork ) + Foolish Burial Goods (Example of how to rotate the deck when opening with an excellent hand) Activate Foolish Burial Goods send Toy Vendor and eff Add Fluffal Dolphin Activate Frightfur Patchwork Add Polymerization and Edge Imp Chain NS Fluffal Dog and eff Add Fluffal Penguin and Activate Polymerization Fusion Cruel Whale(using Penguin and Edge Imp Chain) ***Penguin eff DRAW 2 Discard 1 cl1 and Edge Imp Chain eff Add Frightfur Repair cl2 Cruel Whale eff send Frightfur Fusion Monster from Extra Deck to GY and Activate Frightfur Repair to return the Fusion to Extra Deck and Reborn Penguin Penguin eff SS Dolphin and eff Set Toy Vendor and Send Fluffal Wings to GY Wings eff banish Dog DRAW 2 and Send Toy Vendor to GY and eff Add Fluffal Sheep (depends on the cards in your hand) ////////////////////////////////////////////////Comments about the presented Combos: A very good move for you to make is to use Frightfur Tiger eff or Frightfur Cruel Whale eff to destroy your own Toy Vendor to gain its Search effect and if you haven't even Normal Summoned you can add the Fluffal Dolphin that will set the Toy Vendor back field and send Fluffal Wings or Edge Imp Sabres to the GY. A card that works similar to what I said above is Eldlich the Golden Lord, which also can trigger eff from Search from Toy Vendor without having to spend your Normal Summon since you discard it from your hand with Toy Vendor to draw 1 card and then it comes back from the GY to the field when sending the Toy Vendor to the GY for Search eff trigger. Going Second is out of Floodgates and in Grind Game instead of Fluffal Dog add directly the monster you want you can add Fluffal Bear and set another Toy Vendor to use Golden Lord eff and with Toy Vendor add the Target you wanted with Dog having the Golden Lord on the field. But I think he will be banned from the Fusion Event Banlist so I'm not even using it in the Main Deck. Cruel Whale is one of the last supports this deck has received over the years and is a perfect card for Fluffal's deck strategy: Spot Removal on both turns with Edge Imp Scythe, Combo Enabler sending Frightfur Repair to GY and OTK Tool that will boost the ATK of your Fusion monsters. Some OTK options: Making Frightfur Sabre-Tooth using Frightfur Kraken as material and giving Reborn from Kraken to the field grants you an OTK of 8400damage as Kraken can attack twice and each "Frightfur" fusion gains 400ATK from Sabre-Tooth. Another way to OTK is to make Frightfur Kraken + Frightfur Tiger which will boost 300ATK for each "Fluffal" and "Frightfur" monster so you get a 600ATK boost for both and do an OTK of 8100damage. Cruel Whale using his ATK Boost effect on Frightfur Kraken makes him reach 3300ATK and already grants another OTK. So you can see that Frightfur Kraken is a very strong enabler to finish the game and has synergy with the main Archetype fusions for that. //////////////////////////////////////////////// Technoplay: ////////////////Main Deck Cards: When you manage to Reborn GY's Fluffal Penguin you see how versatile he is and can use his effect to Special Summon from Hand again since it's Soft Once Per Turn(SOFT). Fluffal Dog allows you to make a really cool move of adding Fluffal Sheep and returning Fluffal Dog to hand to Reborn Edge Imp Chain for example allowing you to make another Fusion Summon when having access to the material that was missing. Same goes for Fluffal Dolphin set Toy Vendor and Send Fluffal Wings play for GY because you can add Fluffal Sheep with Toy Vendor. And when returning Fluffal Dog or Fluffal Dolphin you guarantee a Follow Up for the next turn to be your Normal Summon which makes Fluffal Sheep even better. The Fluffal Dolphin eff to set the Toy Vendor in the field if you have already used Fluffal Wings eff in GY you can just send Edge Imp Sabres to the GY and there is a very cool Trick to use the Edge Imp Sabres effect and return a "Fluffal " Monster to the top of the Deck and with the Toy Vendor set by the Dolphin you Draw and Special Summon this "Fluffal" to be another Extender. Fluffal Dolphin can recycle Frightfur Fusion back into the deck in Grind Game so even if you use a copy there are ways you can reuse it throughout the game. It is also a good effect to Chain Block the Fusion you bring to the field and for you to be able to resolve Frightfur Patchwork in the Grind Game because it is necessary to have Polymerization in the deck to activate. Fluffal Own and Fluffal Cat are cards that will allow you to continue to do more Fusion Summon when accessing Polymerization during your turn to take control of the game. Your Opponent can use Ghost Belle on the Fluffal Wings effect because it banishes a Fluffal from the GY as an effect resolution and not as a cost. Edge Imp Chain is one of the main pieces for you to maintain card advantage while Fusion Summoning and is a great discard also giving search Frightfur Patchwork or Frightfur Fusion or Frightfur Repair. Edge Imp Scythe is a kind of Hand Trap in the opponent's turn by Fusion Summoning Cruel Whale to destroy a card it controls and if you only control Cruel Whale you can protect it from destruction with Scythe's own effect in the GY then you take a card from the opponent while guaranteeing a body on the Cruel Whale table that can even use the second effect of sending Frightfur Repair to the GY and you have one more Extender on your turn. The best Fluffal Monster option to use in conjunction with Edge Imp Scythe for Fusion Summon is Fluffal Penguin which gives you 2 Draws and 1 Discard. Toy Vendor is Soft Once Per Turn both effects and you don't need to Special the Fluffal Monster, you can simply add it to the hand and Special Summon any other Monster in your hand. If you need Frightfur Repair in the GY and you have already made Toy Vendor plays you can simply use Foolish Burial Goods send Repair for Extender plays. Royal Penguins Garden is a Continuous Spell that allows you to do excellent Combos in the deck but at this point it doesn't exist in Master Duel. ////////////////Extra Deck Cards: If you activate Frightfur Fusion while controlling Cruel Whale you can chain its effect just to send a Fusion from the Extra Deck to the GY and be able to use it with Frightfur Fusion to make Sabre-Tooth without having to banish any Fusions in field guaranteeing OTK. If you pass to the opponent with Edge Imp Scythe and Fluffal Monster in Hand and Frightfur Sabre-Tooth in Field: Activate Edge Imp Scythe eff Fusion Sabre-Tooth (using Sabre-Tooth and Scythe and Fluffal Monster) = Sabre-Tooth(with Protection from Destruction by Battle or Card Effects) This is a way to field a monster that is very difficult for most decks to take out of the field, ensuring it survives your opponent's turn and buys you time to rejoin the game. And you can still take advantage of this protection when using the Cruel Whale effect by choosing the Saber-Tooth on your side of the field to be destroyed but as it has the protection only the opponent's card will be destroyed. Virtually all Archetype Frightfur fusions are Soft Once Per Turn (SOFT), that is, every time you Summon a different copy of the same card, you can use its effects again either by sending your opponent's monsters to the GY with Frightfur Kraken, or continue to ATK Boost your fusions with Cruel Whale. And this has great synergy with Sabre-Tooth because whenever you give Reborn from the Fusion you used to make it, that fusion can use its effects again on the field. The Frightfur Kraken effect to send a monster to gy doesn't allow you to attack directly with it for the rest of the turn but if Sabre-Tooth gives Reborn the Kraken again it will be able to give two direct atk as it is considered a different card. Instant Fusion has the role of just bringing the Frightfur Sheep to the field with the advantage of being treated as a Fusion Summoned Card so if you use it to make the Sabre-Tooth you can Reborn it back to the field and be able to attack with it and still have the Floating effect if it is destroyed by an opponent's card. Also it allows you to make Predaplant Dragostapelia using Frightfur Patchwork Add Edge Imp Chain and Polymerization and also Edge Imp Chain trigger eff to add Frightfur Fusion to the hand for example. Another detail about the Frightfur Sheep is that you attack a monster stronger than it on purpose just to bring it back and attack with Boost 800ATK being able to take several strong bugs from the opponent. //////////////////////////////////////////////// Issues of the version focused on Fusion Monsters Only: You need to do the first Fusion Summon for the deck to be able to continue playing and as there is no Cross-Sheep you have difficulties in triggering eff of Edge imp Chain to add Patchwork that is needed to do the Cruel Whale which can be Double Extender in addition to interaction because you can destroy Toy Vendor and send Frightfur Repair to GY. Disregard the Side Deck, these are just examples of Staples that can be used in the Main Deck.

A Spyral deck can work at it's best when a good balance of cards are on the field and in the graveyard. It can survive against meta-decks that can negate your ass multiple times and with the right luck, you can still have some resources to still have a strategy to win. The main first move strategy is to have 2 Spyral cards on the field to summon Double Helix. Use Spyral Drone to find out the top card on your opponent's deck is so you can correctly activate other Spyral cards' effects. After summoning Spyral Drone, you should hope that you have Super Agent in your hand to special summon on the field or cards that can bring him to your hand like Reinforcement of the Army or Spiral Resort. There is other tricks to manage to have other Spyral cards special summoned on your first turn: -One for One can have you have 2 Drones on the field (if something happens that would have O.F.O. negated, the monster would still be discarded. Managing to discard a Spyral Rescue can special summon the monster from the grave yard. -Magicians' souls can send a Spyral Master Plan to the graveyard and send Spyral Rescue in your hand (and one other spyral trap) to the grave yard so you could use Spyral Rescue in the graveyard to special summon Master Plan. (This is probably the best way since it could burn out your opponent's hand traps Like Effect Veiler or Ash Blossom and the result of sending cards in the grave yard would still happen, though obviously you wont draw cards from Magician's Souls' effect.) -Managing to discard a Spyral monster and having Big Red in your hand can special summon that Spyral Monster. Most people would like to keep Big Red for an emergency, but its good material to special summon Spyral Sleeper. With the right cards and with this strategy, you can have a good collection of cards in your hand so having Sleeper and with multiple Spyral cards already in the graveyard, you could also have Spyral Sleeper on the field on your first turn. -Before summoning Drone, summon Quick Fix instead. Activate his effect by adding Big Red to your hand then sacrifice him to summon Linkuriboh. Using his effect in the graveyard can have Quick Fix special summon himself by discarding a card in your hand (you need to discard a spyral monster). After gaining another card from Quick Fix, use Big Red to special summon that discard Spyral Monster from the graveyard. (Warning: Quick Fix would be sent to the Banishment during Link Summoning) Those are just few ways to get a head start on the first or second turn. By the end of your turn, you'd want Spyral Double Helix and Spyral Resort on the field. In a situation where you have no cards left and just managed to summon Spyral Double Helix, have his effect special summon Spyral Master Plan. After gaining a card from Master Plan, preferably Spyral Rescue, Link Summon another Double Helix to activate Master Plan's effect in the grave yard to draw a Spyral Resort and any Spyral Monster to your hand.  Depending on hand you started out with, you should have the right card to prepare for your opponent's next turn: -If you haven't used Super Agent's effect to be special summoned, draw him and summon him. -If you only have Double Helix on the field, draw Spyral Gear: Last Resort to keep Double Helix from dying. -If you have a good amount of cards on your spell and trap zone, draw Spyral Sleeper -If you already have a Spyral Resort and you summoned Master Plan, you don't have to make the extra link summon unless to have an extra Resort and a extra Spyral Monster. -If you managed to special summon Master Plan without Double Helix's effect, special summon Quick Fix to add Utility Wire and/or Fully Armed. (You could have both by link summoning Quick fix for Linkuriboh , then using Quick Fix's effect to bring him back from the graveyard. However he will be banished next time he is destroyed. There are other back up strategies in case your opponent negates you hard enough to almost run out of options with your Spyral Cards. -The Numeron Network and the Numeron XYZ monsters is good for a last ditch comeback. -Underworld Goddess and Mekk-Knight is used as move to destroy your opponent's nearly invincible monster depending on the situation. Even if the Numeron XYZ monsters can't be used to attack, they can still be used as material. -Security Dragon can be used to send your opponent's nearly invincible monster back to their hand. By the off chance that you were unable to summon Double Helix but still have 2 effect monsters on the field, Code Breaker Virus Swordsman can be used to link together with Security Dragon. -Slifer is good to have during matches that are drawn out. Spyral Resort, Master Plan, Spyral Mission: Assault, and Double Helix regularly draw cards to your hand to generate Slifer's attack points (once I managed to have it up to 12,000atk) and the ways to have monsters on your field can be used as materials to tribute summon Slifer to the field. -Big Eye would be used on a rare occasion if you'd managed to have both Master Plans on the field. Thats everything I can think of for strategy off the top of my head and the more you practice with your deck, the more flexible your own strategy can be. Its my first time adding a deck to this website and its already waaaaaaaaaay too long to read, but this deck has brought me to Platinum Rank 1. Any feed back and ways I can improve this deck would be awesome.

deck_excerpt: Fast shark XYZ that will crumble under the weight of a single handtrap. Rated Toadally Awesome by many.
deck_description: Fast shark XYZ that will crumble under the weight of a single handtrap. Main deck lacks handtraps because they are expensive. I've been playing a version of this deck with handtraps in Master Duel and it works well enough. Starters: Beautunaful Princess, Buzzsaw Shark, Lantern Shark Boss monsters: Utopic Draco Future, Silent Honor ARK, Silent Honor DARK, Stealth Kragen Usually I summon Bahamut Shark and detach to summon Toadally Awesome for that toadally sick negate. If I'm lucky enough I can get out another Rank 4, then I use the two Rank 4s to summon Utopic Future -> Utopic Draco Future. If you're holding XYZ Remora in your starting hand don't detach, special summon Remora and then you'll get back the two detached monsters. Set Whitefish Salvage as soon as you get it. You win if it's destroyed (add fish from deck to hand) and you win if it stays on the field (add fish from GY to hand every turn). Remember to special summon Silent Sea Nettle from your hand BEFORE special summoning Silent Angler. If you hold XYZ Revive Splash, probably set it. After getting Utopic Draco Future out, I usually get out No. 4 Stealth Kragen if I'm in good shape, or No. 101 Silent Honor ARK if I'm in bad shape.     Sphere Kuriboh is the only handtrap you'll ever need.

deck_excerpt: Virtual World p.u.n.k. list that passes on the Halqdon line in favor of some budget options.
deck_description: The PUNK engine is a neat little set of monsters that synergize really nicely with VW. They have level 3 psychics (making them E-Tele targets) whose combo line is pretty competent and good at baiting negates. Normally, the PUNKs are used to make Halqdon lines, but for this list we opted for a pair of Rank 2 monster: Gossip Shadow and Break Sword. Gossip Shadow lets us set up a negate under Nibiru, and Break Sord is a great equalizer going second.  If you didn't want to run the PUNKs, I would recommend replacing them with Pot of Desires and another handtrap.

deck_excerpt: A pile deck that uses multiple archetypes to facilitate Karakuri plays.  Featured archtype: Karakuri, Machina, Theroins', P.U.N.K., Infinitrack, Mor
deck_description: Note: Ban list destroyed this deck. Will remain up, but only feasible in traditional format.  Really fragile, but not  as  fragile as the base Karakuri Strategy.  The plan is to go into Halq, get 001, then go into Auroradon. From there, you synchro into a Burei and bring out a Saizan to create another Burei. You Synchro Climb into Bureido using Gamas (Remember to use Gama in GY to draw 2), and then go into Bureibu.  Card Selection Breakdown:  The summary above can be the result of a single e-Tele (or just a Ze Amin Normal Summon). Of course, depending on your opening hand, the strategy might differ a bit. Here  is why I run the cards I do.  Karakuri: Base for the deck. You generally don't want to draw into your Ninishi and Gamas. Kunamzan is best left in the deck, and you should only go into it when you have no other play  other than Ready/Insta fusion  + Kunamzan into a River Stormer.  Theorins': King Reggie is a safety net against interruptions. Having him on the board while you combo off is great for preventing Nibiru or a disruption. Remember, if Halq fizzles, you're pretty much fucked. I would run 3, but I found myself drawing into 2 Reggies when I only needed the one.  P.U.N.K: Main Combo Starter. A single E-Tele can take you from Ze Amin to a Bureibu. Standard combo is  Ele-Tele -> Ze Amin -> Madame Spider -> Halq (into 001)  -> Auroradon -> 2 Bureis -> 2 Bureidos -> Bureibu and a Bureido  Machina: Great for setting up Reggie and getting bricks into your GY. Drawing into Redeployment and a Machina isn't generally bad, as you do run an Overdrive. You use Overdrive to recycle your Halq and other options. If you get into the fabled turn 3 and beyond, you can do a pretty nice loop  of Recycling Tunneler with Overdrive to get back even more resources. Citadel is also an amazing piece of interruption.  Infinitrack: There mostly for Tunneler. Dozer and Trencher are cuttable, but Dozer searches out the Tunneler and I find myself in a lot of situations where I need to get myself back into the grind. I usually search Dozer w/ Heavy Forward to deck thin. I also pitch it for Theorins when I can.  Vernalizers: Extenders. Them being able to retrieve ANY earth is amazing. I don't want to draw into them too often tho. Never use these as your first move, as they'll lock you out of Halq, Auroradon and Baronne. Only use them to continue your combos once you're sure you have no other play.  Morphtronic: There to get you into Halq if you don't draw into any P.U.N.Ks.  Ready/Insta Fusion: As mentioned previously, here when you need an extra body on the field. You run Gyroid and Cyber Saurus because they're Earth Machines.  Using Kunamzan doesn't lock you out of them  and Tunneler can recycle them - so they're perfect.  Destrudo: Another Tuner for Halq  Extra deck:  Run what you'll go into. The extra deck space isn't that right, as you  can cut Infinitrack Goliath and Earth Slicer. I never go into them, and if I do, I'm probably losing that game anyways. However, Earth Slicer can be great going second.  You'll generally use up most of the Karakuris in your Combos, although I do find myself with a Single Bureibu left, often. Naturia Beast is perfect, and shuts down most decks - you can go into it with a Ninishi Special Summon with a Karakuri Synchro, and then normal summoning Inashichi.  Baronne is a great card, and you can go into it with a Ninishi + Machina Fortress. It's worth mentioning that it is Generic, so any  other combination of  cards in the deck can lead up to it.

Basic Phantom Knight deck but with a smaller adventurer engine. I am only running 2x rite and 1x enchantress because enchantress is searchable off of Cherubini, and I run a lot of level 3 extenders so it is pretty easy to get to Cherubini. This gives me 3 cards I can open with that can start off the engine, and like around 20 different level 3s to make Cherubini to search enchantress. I run Dracoback because if you use it to discard for dragoons effect, it attaches to the token for a free bounce. I run 1 of all of the common handtraps because I run 3x Crossout. I also run the one scythe because I can cross it out, and if I do draw it I can set it and pop it off of Rusty's effect by reviving a break sword in grave to a zone he points to. I also choose to run dragoon over DPE beacause he is a tower and is harder to get around that DPE. Everyone a;ways forgets about the double pop+burn and that alone has ended games. Drawing red eyes fusion happens moderately often and it basically useless in hand, because Verte cannot get it into grave from the hand. If I do open red-eyes fusion, I can go through combo and dump Edge Imp Sabres, then use Edege Imp to put Red-Eyes Fusion back into the deck and Special summon itself,  then make Verte off of Cherubini + Edge or go into Rusty and continue combo. It's pretty solid and pretty consistent and you can basically play forever with stuff in the graveyard so the grind game is super good. I also has a really good OTK through Arc Rebellion and its pretty easy to play through a bunch of stuff and still end on arc rebellion for the OTK, especially if your opponent payed 2000 for verte. There are definitely better decks but I like PK so this is what I'm running to keep up with the meta decks running around.

deck_excerpt: Modern rendition of the old Duel Terminal Archetype!
deck_description: Write your deck strategy here... A current Attempt to modernize genex for the modern era. It abuses certain cards like r-genex oracle, genex undine and summoner monk+genex blastfan for powerful synchro and link plays. The endymion package is played to gain counters for abductor to search guitarr for additional normal summons. Many combos rely on halqifibrax+ auroradon.     Genex Undine Line: Normal Undine, dump rosenix search controller, banish rosenix for token, token make link spider and summon controller, link controller and undine into cherubini, cherubini dump carboneddon, banish carboneddon summon labradorite dragon, link labradorite, cherubini, and link spider into appollousa.  Summoner can summon blastfan, searching either oracle for a halq play, or birdman to make an easy lvl 7 synchro.
You want to go second only with this build. Triple Tactics Talent, Red Reboot, and Lightning Storm can be swap out if you want a more control based deck or the code talker package.

deck_excerpt: A Skull Servant deck with Lightsworn support.
deck_description: A very straightforward Skull Servant deck where everything in the main deck is generally focused towards milling your hand and deck in order to buff up your King of the Skull Servants to insane degrees. Everything in the extra deck essentially serves as your toolbox or possible combo extenders if you're having issues with gas, which may be a problem since one of the main weaknesses of the deck is a bit of an inconsistency issue due to having to run three-ofs for every monster in the Skull Servant archetype, with half the monsters being unable to start any combos. Splashing in the Lightsworn support helps alleviate this issue, by giving access to powerful spells that will thin your deck, as well as easier synchro summons. While this deck isn't meta, it can still play through a lot of interrupts and OTK your opponent. Or, if you want to play more conservatively, you're able to still build beefy skeletons with modest protection that can really wall the other player.
